Upping the Ante: Elliott and Mullins face off on the Punchestown battlefield
Upping the Ante: Elliott and Mullins face off on the Punchestown battlefield
Sunday Business Post
April 21, 2018
Copyright 2018 Post Publications Ltd. All Rights Reserved
Length: 693 words
Byline: Johnny Ward
Highlight: As Willie Mullins strives to overtake Gordon Elliott at this week’s festival, can he draw inspiration from - 
of all people - Stalin? 
Body
‘Comrades, it is in strenuous circumstances that we are today celebrating the 24th anniversary of the October 
Revolution. The perfidious attack of the German brigands and the war which has been forced upon us have created 
a threat to our country. The war you are waging is a war of liberation, a just war. Let the manly images of our great 
ancestors – Aleksandr Nevsky, Dmitri Donskoy, Kuzma Minin, Dmitri Pozharsky, Aleksandr Suvorov and Mikhail 
Kutuzov – inspire you in this war!”
Preparing last week to write this piece with an eye on the Punchestown Festival commencing this Tuesday, I 
happened upon a World War II documentary and found it hard not to draw parallels between Joseph Stalin’s 1941 
speech and Willie Mullins’ challenge over the next seven days.
Mullins has wallowed in a decade- long spell as champion trainer – the race had long become a non-event – but his 
position of comfort seems to be gone forever. Gordon Elliott pushed him to the wire last season, and the Co Meath 
trainer, who won the Grand National for the second time last weekend, is now favourite to gain his first crown.
Stalin’s speech was especially significant because he smashed his own rules and evoked the spirit of past heroes 
of a Russian empire that was the antithesis of Bolshevism. Similarly, Mullins will make a mockery of his rules next 
week, more of this later on.
By the time the action starts in Co Kildare, Mullins will trail Elliott by approximately €500,000, little more than the 
figure that he faced (and conquered) 12 months ago. Jockeys’ and trainers’ title battles can be of little interest to 
anyone other than the participants. This is different.
A clip did the rounds after Aintree that epitomised Michael O’Leary: mischievous, cunning, entertaining, 
opportunistic. Late boarding the flight home, he promptly took the flight attendants’ phone and told all passengers 
Upping the Ante: Elliott and Mullins face off on the Punchestown battlefield
they were getting a free drink. Apologising that the delay was due to his having to collect his trophy for winning the 
National, he cautioned that his rare display of generosity had a limit: one drink per customer.
Given that the Ryanair chief executive’s success had quite a bit to do with free advertising, it was strangely 
reassuring to think that, despite his being a billionaire, old habits tend to linger on. And O’Leary will have a greater 
say than he might have envisaged in the outcome of the title race.
Next September will mark two years since the controversial businessman pulled the plug on his arrangement with 
Mullins. Publicly, the split was relatively amicable at the time and no different since, though it is hardly worth saying 
that the respective camps going their separate ways left a bit of a sour taste in the mouth of each.
O’Leary spread the 60 Mullins horses around five different trainers, but the bulk of his eggs have been in Elliott’s 
basket since. He wants Elliott to win the title at Mullins’ expense – and that is natural.
So if Samcro abandons novice company to take on the seniors in Friday’s €250,000 Champion Hurdle, one can 
only wonder was the title battle some part of the consideration, as he would probably win and thus deny the Mullins-
trained Melon and, potentially, stablemate Min.
In any case, this makes sense for Samcro: it will tell us more about whether he should stay hurdling or go chasing. 
Elliott pitched Labaik at that race as a novice 12 months ago – even if the circumstances were a little different (he 
had refused to race earlier in the week).
Elliott is willing to deviate from the norm when matters are of grave importance.
And this week, Mullins will run top-rung horses who raced last Tuesday at Fairyhouse’s rearranged meeting. He 
tends to give all his string at least three weeks between races.
Thus Saldier will tackle Saturday’s champion four-year-old hurdle. He ran a blinder on Tuesday when third, coming 
on from his Triumph run (especially in terms of his jumping), and he looks a cracking each-way wager at 16/1, with 
Paddy Power considering that there is surely more to come from him.
1pt each-way, Saldier in AES Champion 4YO Hurdle at Punchestown, 16/1 (scale 1-5)
Invested in 2018: 23 pts
Profit/Loss: +13 pts
Still running: 9 pts
Load-Date: April 21, 2018
End of Document
The secret start-up
The secret start-up
Sunday Business Post
April 21, 2018
Copyright 2018 Post Publications Ltd. All Rights Reserved
Length: 1990 words
Byline: Post Reporter
Highlight: There's huge enthusiasm for the start-up at a dream meeting of potential investors in New York, where 
even Bono hears about his plans
Body
In a New York minute, everything can change
After six and a half years of ups and downs, I found myself in London to meet a proper VC, at the bar in the Ritz no 
less. I was wearing new clothes bought with the few bob the gregarious Dublin businessman had given me. It had 
felt like Communion money: once I got it, I just had to spend it. I bought the essentials in Dunnes, and a jacket in 
H&M to tie it all together.
The VC I was to meet was part of a large investment firm in the US. I Googled him and learned that the firm had a 
few billion under management – whatever that meant. The investor himself – we’ll call him Richard Smiley – was in 
his early fifties. He was an all-American kinda guy, well put together, with a bright happy vibe.
What stood out was that he had a big pearly white smile. He didn’t seem to have an ounce of the melancholia that I 
had. Everything to him was just “great”. He was the type who would take regular breaks to the Hamptons on his 
yacht with his well-manicured family. For recreation he’d like a bit of tennis or racquetball.
“So, tell me all about it. I want to hear the story from you. Where do you want to take it?” all said with a big smile. I 
told him the fun, colourful story, complete with the grand ambition that I had rehearsed so well at the incubator.
“Well listen, I think it’s really greet [his “greats” would sound like “greets”]. I just love it. I think there is huge potential 
here too. I just can’t believe I haven’t heard about it until now. It’s amazing.” Big smile.
Not for the first time in this story, I couldn’t believe what I was hearing. I was sitting opposite a VC who had possible 
access to big funds who was telling me how great everything was.
The secret start-up
“So, let me cut to the chase. Here is what I want to do. We want to invest maybe a quarter of a million. But we think 
you are going to need more. So what we want to do is get three or four other investors involved and raise maybe a 
million dollars. You’re going to need it if you really want to grow it.”
A million dollars! I’d had to borrow the money for the Ryanair flight to the meeting, now a million dollars was being 
dangled in front of my eyes by a VC I’d met about 40 minutes ago.
“Let me get back to New York and work on rounding up other investors. But really, it’s so greet. I hope we can make 
it happen.”
Back in Dublin I exchanged emails with Richard Smiley as he asked more detailed questions about the operations. 
He became a bit more of a stickler. “Now, I need you to be specific here,” still with the smiley tone.
A few days had passed when my phone rang. It was a US number. I picked up. The voice was a droll American.
“Hello, is this secret start-up man?”
He didn’t say that obviously. But you know what I mean.
“It’s Bob Ziegfield.”
Bob Ziegfield! Bob was one of the biggest, and smartest, investors in the world our start-up occupied. He was co-
founder of one of the world’s biggest platforms. It was surreal. He was a rock-star investor. If you met him, you’d 
probably ask for his autograph. I paced around my apartment.
“Listen, I just heard about what you’re doing, and it’s really something remarkable.”
After six years of nobody important really catching onto what we were doing, it was incredible to be hearing this 
from, frankly, a dream investor. I was thinking, “Yes, that’s what I have been saying for the last six years. It’s 
amazing.”
After asking me where I saw it going, he told me what he wanted to do.
“Listen, this is something we want to be part of. You have an opportunity to take it in so many ways. There is a huge 
brand potential. We want to invest. Now it’s up to you. We can do this alone or we can work with your other investor 
in the round. What would you like?”
What would I like? I was being given options now. I thought quickly. If I was being heartless I could have jumped 
exclusively in with Bob Ziegfield. He had it all. But Richard Smiley in London had clearly spread the word so I 
thought it best that I continue with his strategy to build a round of investment with three or four investors.
“Okay, great. We’re in. We’ll get in touch with Richard Smiley and work on building the round with him.”
Three days later I had another phone call. “Hello. It’s Kevin Zucker.”
Kevin Zucker, the man who revolutionised online dating, calling me! He offered me the same feedback.
“It’s great. We want to be part of it. But listen, we need to know who we are investing in. You have to come to New 
York and meet us. We’ll organise a meeting for all the investors. Can you come over here next week? We want to 
move fast.”
It really did happen that fast (not counting the six years prior). A week later, I was in New York. I crashed on a 
friend’s sofa. I felt I like I was in the waiting room to the rest of my life . . . next to be called. I met Richard, Bob and 
Kevin in a slick, colourful office on Broadway and East 3rd Street. It was a boardroom surrounded by glass. The 
outer walls had lots of colourful trinkets representing the kind of worlds they invested in. There was a Damien Hirst 
Mickey Mouse head made out of bubblegum, and a Banksy for good measure. The sun shone brightly outside. It 
was all just so cool. It was the New York big-investor meeting dream.
The secret start-up
Despite the colour all around, Ziegfield, who was in his sixties, didn’t smile much. He had little or no outward 
warmth. He looked dead serious. I guess that’s what business is when you get to a certain level. It’s dead serious. 
Kevin Zucker was much older, late seventies maybe. He was very craggy-faced. I sensed he was just in it to hit the 
jackpot, as he had with many other investments. I didn’t get any feeling that he really ‘got it’.
The meeting with the investors was solid, if unspectacular. They were all on board.
“When are you leaving town?” Bob asked.
“Thursday.”
“Let’s try to set him up to meet Linda Murphy,” Bob said peering over his spectacles to the assistant taking notes.
I didn’t know who Linda Murphy was, but I was happy to meet anyone.
My four days in New York to meet the investors were still four days in New York, a city that casts a special mystique 
over many. I felt I should make the most of the trip, as I didn’t know when I’d return. And so the nights were long 
and full of revelry.
The day before I was due to fly home to Dublin, I woke up in a fright. I’d had a blackout from the night before. Who 
knows what happened. Blackouts had become common in my life. I was disorientated as I filled a pint glass of 
water trying to get my bearings, trying to remember what I had to do.
Damn, I have to meet Linda Murphy at 8am! Who meets that early?
I looked at the clock. It was 7.43am. Fuck.
I wanted to throw up in the back of the cab, which I instructed to step on the gas to take me to the Gramercy Park 
Hotel for our conversation. If you don’t know the Gramercy Park area of New York, it is very classical – old 
brownstone buildings with lush, leafy trees. And sitting at the centre of it is the five-star Gramercy Park Hotel. It’s a 
nice setting, to say the least.
I wobbled into the cafe/restaurant where I was to meet Linda. My hangover was overpowering. I must only have 
slept only two or three hours. It was one of my worst in recent memory, and that’s saying a lot. I knew there was 
going to be no hiding it.
The concierge brought me to the table where Linda was already seated. I wasn’t late. I never am. It was 8am on the 
dot. Linda was in her late fifties and had an unassuming presence. She looked like your sweetest aunt. After we 
greeted each other, I had to tell the truth.
“Linda, I have to be honest with you. I apologise, but I was out a bit late last night and am a bit worse for wear.”
“You’re Irish, right? I expected as much. Have a coffee and you’ll be fine. I’m a Murphy don’t forget, so I have some 
understanding.”
That put me a bit at ease. Linda wasn’t Irish, for the record. She just had an Irish surname.
We had a good banter between us. I loved her vibe more than anyone else I’d met on the trip. I told her my whole 
story as my body raced on coffee and booze. When I get talking in that state, I can be like a runaway train, as 
thoughts fill my head. I get delirious. The mission then is to stay deliriously entertaining, and not delirious like a 
madman. It’s a tough balance. The talking distracted me from my hangover pain.
“I love it,” Linda said. “What an amazing story. It’s what it should all be about.”
After chatting for an hour I realised that I didn’t really know who Linda was. I vaguely knew she was involved in one 
of the biggest companies in our industry, but I didn’t know what her exact role was.
The secret start-up
“Linda, this is a bit embarrassing, but do you mind me asking what it is you actually do?”
In hindsight, I think she might have found a bit of charm in that. I’m sure she wasn’t used to people meeting her 
blindly.
“Well, I started at the company at the very beginning, 30 years ago. I worked my way up to the chief executive 
position of that, and the other companies under the umbrella, where I was for the past 20 years. I just stepped down 
a few months ago.”
Who was I sitting next to? Who was I blabbering to? Who had I presented myself hungover to, like a fool? This 
woman was literally at the very top of the tree. This woman was an industry legend. She was almost an icon in her 
own right. Think Sheryl Sandberg, but cooler. And here I was just chatting away to her full of banter like she was 
anyone. You would think my new knowledge was good reason to change my conversational approach, but it was 
too late. I just acted like what she told me had no major impact.
“Wow, that’s mad,” I said before going straight back to our regular tone of conversation. After a two-hour chat she 
told me that she had to leave, as she had to go to another meeting.
“Where you off to?” I asked casually, as a friend might.
“Oh, Bono’s in town,” she responded nonchalantly. “Something about Africa . . .”
Bono! Don’t hate me, readers, but I am an unapologetic U2 lover – a proper super fan. It was hard for me to keep 
my cool in that moment.
When Linda left, I scrambled for my phone to look her up. Her profile defied belief. She was on the Forbes list of 
100 most powerful women in the world. If I was to put together a dream list of people to be involved in my company, 
she would probably be number one. She was the person I had been looking for my whole life. But it was only 
coffee, I reasoned.
After the meeting I emailed my other investors and told them how well the meeting had gone with Linda. Bob 
Ziegfield responded quickly.
“If you really think you got on well with her, I would offer her 5 per cent equity if she could be an adviser on your 
board. Every company in America wants her,” he advised.
I decided to email her just to say that I enjoyed our meeting. It was genuine.
“Linda, really enjoyed meeting you and our conversation. Sorry again for being so hungover.” To my surprise she 
wrote back immediately.
“Don’t be silly. It was great to meet you. I loved your story. By the way, I just met Bono. He loves what you do too. 
He’s a fan. Please let me invest.”
Incredible. Whatever anyone wants to say about Bono, the one thing I have noticed about him in interviews is that 
he rarely, if ever, has a bad word to say about anyone. Many have something bad to say about him, but he 
manages to respond with positivity. I think there is something to be learned in that. If you don’t have anything nice 
to say, don’t say anything at all. And let’s face it, that’s not something the Irish excel at.
I can only conclude that when asked about what we did by Linda, Bono thought it right to give a positive plug for an 
Irish company. I would be amazed if he knew too much more about us beyond that.
Regardless, I think that one little email from Linda telling me of Bono’s endorsement was the high point of my 12 
years of start-up turmoil. It’s the little things.
The secret start-up
Ps: the names in these sections have been changed, so don’t go googling them. They don’t exist. Except for Bono . 
. .
itsme@thesecretstartup.com

Frequent flyer should come down to earth Letters
Frequent flyer should come down to earth; Letters
Financial Times (London, England)
April 21, 2018 Saturday
Edition 1, 
Copyright 2018 The Financial Times Limited All Rights Reserved
Section: BUSINESS; Pg. 8
Length: 75 words
Body
Forget conventional air travel; your writer Nick Remsen (Life & Arts, April 14/15) is surely on another planet if he 
thinks readers can afford to copy his "frequent flyer's ultimate checklist".
The total cost of his suggestions is £13,046! Does he live in the real world? Currently, Ryanair offers flights from 
London Stansted to Bremen for £4.99. Mr Remsen could make 2,614 of those journeys for the price of his 
selfpampering.
Leaf Kalfayan London N7, UK
Load-Date: April 20, 2018
End of Document
Frequent flyer should come down to earth Letters
Frequent flyer should come down to earth; Letters
Financial Times (London, England)
April 21, 2018 Saturday
Edition 1, National Edition
Copyright 2018 The Financial Times Limited All Rights Reserved
Section: LETTERS; Pg. 10
Length: 75 words
Body
Forget conventional air travel; your writer Nick Remsen (Life & Arts, April 14/15) is surely on another planet if he 
thinks readers can afford to copy his "frequent flyer's ultimate checklist".
The total cost of his suggestions is £13,046! Does he live in the real world? Currently, Ryanair offers flights from 
London Stansted to Bremen for £4.99. Mr Remsen could make 2,614 of those journeys for the price of his 
selfpampering.
Leaf Kalfayan London N7, UK
Load-Date: April 20, 2018
End of Document
Ryanair ( RYAAY ) Rating Lowered to Sell at Zacks Investment Research
Ryanair (RYAAY) Rating Lowered to Sell at Zacks Investment Research
American Banking and Market News
April 20, 2018 Friday
Copyright 2018 American Banking and Market News All Rights Reserved
Length: 756 words
Body
Ryanair logo Ryanair (NASDAQ:RYAAY) was downgraded by            Zacks Investment Research  from a "buy" 
rating to a "sell" rating in a report released on Friday.  
According to Zacks, "Ryanair operates an ultra-low cost, scheduled airline serving short-haul, point-to-point routes 
largely in Europe from its bases in airports across Europe. The company offers over 1,600 scheduled short-haul 
flights per day serving airports largely throughout Europe, with a principal fleet of Boeing 737-800 aircraft.   " 
Other research analysts have also recently issued research reports about the company. Sanford C. Bernstein 
upgraded Ryanair from an "underperform" rating to a "market perform" rating in a research note on Monday, 
January 8th. BidaskClub upgraded Ryanair from a "hold" rating to a "buy" rating in a research note on Tuesday, 
January 23rd. UBS upgraded Ryanair from a "neutral" rating to a "buy" rating in a research note on Thursday, 
January 11th. Finally, ValuEngine  upgraded Ryanair from a "hold" rating to a "buy" rating in a research note on 
Friday, February 2nd. Three research analysts have rated the stock with a sell rating, two have given a hold rating, 
four have assigned  a buy rating and one  has given a strong buy rating to the stock. The company presently has an 
average rating of "Hold" and a consensus price target of $110.00. 
Shares of NASDAQ RYAAY  opened at $115.50 on Friday. Ryanair has a 1-year low of $87.66 and a 1-year high of 
$127.61. The company has a quick ratio of 1.61, a current ratio of 1.61 and a debt-to-equity ratio of 0.77. The stock 
has a market capitalization of $27,521.79, a PE ratio of 20.12, a P/E/G ratio of 1.87 and a beta of 0.64.  
Ryanair (NASDAQ:RYAAY) last issued its earnings results on Monday, February 5th. The transportation company 
reported $0.52 earnings per share for the quarter, topping the Thomson Reuters' consensus estimate of $0.50 by 
$0.02. Ryanair had a return on equity of 32.17% and a net margin of 20.99%. The company had revenue of $1.65 
billion during the quarter, compared to the consensus estimate of $1.68 billion.  research analysts anticipate that  
Ryanair will post 7.32 EPS for the current fiscal year.  
Ryanair declared that its board has approved a stock buyback program on Monday, February 5th that allows the 
company to repurchase  outstanding  shares. This repurchase authorization allows the transportation company to 
reacquire shares of its stock through open market purchases. Stock  repurchase programs are typically an 
indication that the company's board believes its stock is undervalued.  
Several large investors have recently added to or reduced their stakes in RYAAY. Shine Investment Advisory 
Services Inc. raised its stake in  Ryanair by 1,715.1% during the fourth quarter. Shine Investment Advisory Services 
Ryanair ( RYAAY ) Rating Lowered to Sell at Zacks Investment Research
Inc. now owns 962 shares of the transportation company's stock valued at $100,000 after buying an additional 909 
shares in the last quarter.  Cornerstone Advisors Inc. raised its stake in  Ryanair by 1,350.7% during the fourth 
quarter. Cornerstone Advisors Inc. now owns 1,088 shares of the transportation company's stock valued at 
$113,000 after buying an additional 1,013 shares in the last quarter.  US Bancorp DE raised its stake in  Ryanair by 
168.2% during the fourth quarter. US Bancorp DE now owns 1,172 shares of the transportation company's stock 
valued at $122,000 after buying an additional 735 shares in the last quarter.  Assetmark Inc. raised its stake in

stock valued at $138,000 after buying an additional 516 shares in the last quarter.  Finally, Tower Research Capital 
LLC TRC acquired a new stake in  Ryanair during the fourth quarter valued at approximately $148,000. Institutional 
investors and hedge funds own  42.35% of the company's stock.   
About Ryanair
Ryanair Holdings plc, together with its subsidiaries, provides scheduled-passenger airline services in Ireland, the 
United Kingdom, continental Europe, Morocco, and Israel. It also offers various ancillary services, such as non-flight 
scheduled services and Internet-related services; and markets accommodation services and travel insurance 
through its Website, as well as engages in the in-flight sale of beverages, food, and merchandise.

European ADRs Move Lower in Thursday Trading
European ADRs Move Lower in Thursday Trading
MT Newswires Live Briefs
April 19, 2018 Thursday 10:58 AM EST
Copyright 2018 MT Newswires All Rights Reserved
Length: 230 words
Body
 American depositary receipts of European stocks were trading 0.35% lower at 142.18 on the Bank of New York 
Mellon Europe ADR Index on Thursday.
In continental Europe, the gainers were led by pharmaceutical company Oasmia Pharmaceutical (OASM), and 
VEON Com (VEON), a provider of communications services, which rose 4.9% and 4.6% respectively. They were 
followed by automation company ABB (ABB), and biotech firm Zealand Pharma (ZEAL), which climbed 4.5% and 
4.1%.
The decliners in continental Europe were led by ASML (ASML), a manufacturer of chip-making equipment, and 
semiconductor company STMicroelectronics (STM), which lost 3.2% and 2.9% respectively. They were followed by 
healthcare companies Novartis (NVS), and Novo Nordisk (NVO), which fell 2.7% and 1.5%.
In the UK and Ireland, the gainers were led by biotech firm Shire (SHPG), and bank HSBC (HSBC), which were up 
7.6% and 2.2% respectively. They were followed by biopharmaceutical companies Adaptimmune Therapeutics 
(ADAP), and Akari Therapeutics (AKTX), which rose 2.1% and 2.0%.
The decliners in the UK and Ireland were led by consumer goods companies British American Tobacco (BTI), and 
Unilever (UL), which were off 5.5% and 2.6% respectively, followed by telecommunications provider BT Group (BT), 
and Irish airline operator Ryanair (RYAAY), which dropped 1.1% and 0.6%.

Ryanair balks at Irish union recognition demands
Ryanair balks at Irish union recognition demands
Business World (Digest)
April 18, 2018 Wednesday
Copyright 2018 Media World Ltd. All Rights Reserved
Section: WORLD
Length: 309 words
Byline: Business World
Body
 Ryanair, which pledged to recognise unions to avert widespread strikes late last year, has balked at Irish union 
FORSA/IALPA's demands to be recognised as the representative for pilots in its home market.
Ryanair Chief People Officer Eddie Wilson in a letter dated April 13 seen by Reuters told FORSA/IALPA that a 
number of changes it had suggested to a draft agreement were "totally unacceptable now or at any time in the 
future".
The budget airline has been in talks to formalise union recognition in several European countries since its decision 
in December to recognise unions for the first time in its 32-year history.
Pilots in Britain and Italy - its two largest markets - have reached agreement and Ryanair said last month that a deal 
was close in Spain. However, progress has been slower in Portugal and Ireland.
The areas of disagreement with the Irish union included rostering, dispute resolution and Ryanair's requirement that 
the union recognises its low cost model, according to Wilson's letter.
Wilson said Europe's largest low-cost carrier would not move or resile from its proposed draft agreement and 
suggested it meet the union soon to finalise that agreement.
He also criticised the union for taking a month to respond to its proposal, saying the "glacial pace" of the talks was 
frustrating.
A spokesman for FORSA/IALPA said it does not comment while industrial relations negotiations are ongoing. A 
spokesman for Ryanair said it does not comment on negotiations with its staff.
Ryanair balks at Irish union recognition demands
Ryanair expects some disruption to flights where it is struggling to reach agreements, Chief Executive Michael 
O'Leary has warned.
It cancelled a number of flights to and from airports in Portugal last month after a strike by some of its cabin crew.
Ryanair operates from 87 airports across 36 countries in Europe and North Africa. (Reuters)
Source: www.businessworld.ie
Load-Date: May 9, 2018
End of Document
European ADRs Move Higher in Tuesday Trading
European ADRs Move Higher in Tuesday Trading
MT Newswires Live Briefs
April 17, 2018 Tuesday 11:05 AM EST
Copyright 2018 MT Newswires All Rights Reserved
Length: 246 words
Body
 American depositary receipts of European stocks were trading 0.36% higher at 142.01 on the Bank of New York 
Mellon Europe ADR Index on Tuesday.
In continental Europe, the gainers were led by network infrastructure provider Nokia (NOK), and biotech firm 
Zealand Pharma (ZEAL), which rose 4.2% and 2.7% respectively. They were followed by hotel booking site Trivago 
(TRVG), and pharmaceutical company Oasmia Pharmaceutical (OASM), which were up 2.6% and 2.5%. 
The decliners in continental Europe were led by telecommunications provider Telecom Italia (TI), and 3D printer 
maker voxeljet (VJET), which lost 2% and 1% respectively. They were followed by online dating company Spark 
Networks (LOV), and bank Banco Bilbao Vizcaya Argentaria (BBVA), which dropped 0.9% and 0.6%. 
In the UK and Ireland, the gainers were led by biopharmaceutical company GW Pharmaceuticals (GWPH), which 
surged 10.3%, followed by biopharmaceutical company Akari Therapeutics (AKTX), which climbed 6.2%. Gene 
therapy company Nightstar (NITE), and biopharmaceutical firm Amarin (AMRN) rose 3.4% and 3.1% respectively.
The decliners in the UK and Ireland were led by airline operator Ryanair (RYAAY), and biopharmaceutical company 
Midatech Pharma (MTP), which fell 3.7% and 1.8% respectively. They were followed by biopharmaceutical firm 
Adaptimmune Therapeutics (ADAP), and consumer goods company British American Tobacco (BTI), which were 
down 1.8% and 1.2%.
Price: 5.86, Change: +0.25, Percent Change: +4.37
Load-Date: April 18, 2018
End of Document
INTERVIEW:  E Ajay Singh, managing director, SpiceJet The last five years has been nothing short of 
tumultuous for SpiceJet, having undergone a back-from-the-de....
INTERVIEW:  E Ajay Singh, managing director, SpiceJet; The last five years 
has been nothing short of tumultuous for SpiceJet, having undergone a 
back-from-the-dead fairytale after surviving a near collapse in 2014. Today, 
the low-cost carrier has completed its turnaround, with a clear focus to keep 
on growing.
Flight International
April 17, 2018
Copyright 2018 Reed Business Information Ltd. All Rights Reserved
Section: FLIGHTGLOBAL.COM
Length: 2068 words
Body
The last five years has been nothing short of tumultuous for SpiceJet. Having undergone a back-from-the-dead 
fairytale after surviving a near collapse in 2014, the airline has completed its turnaround, with a clear focus to keep 
growing.
In an unforgiving domestic sector crowded with around 10 established players, SpiceJet is one of four low-cost 
carriers that also compete with full-service stalwarts such as Air India and Jet Airways, as well as start-ups like 
Vistara. Data from India’s Directorate General of Civil Aviation shows that SpiceJet has, over the past three years, 
consistently been ranked among India’s top five airlines in terms of domestic market share.
With two consecutive years of profits under its belt, scars from the carrier's near-death experience are starting to 
fade. Its rise-from-the-ashes story has one man to thank – founder Ajay Singh.
Bryan van der Beek
At SpiceJet's headquarters in Gurgaon, New Delhi, the 52-year-old tells FlightGlobal he started SpiceJet in 2004 
because he saw "a great need for maturity" in Indian aviation. Then, about 16 million people commuted daily by 
train in India – about the same as the number of air passengers in an entire year.
In the telecommunications industry at that time, the entrepreneur saw "a golden opportunity" – and seized it.
"We had seen the impact of reducing tariffs to generate demand [in the telecommunications sector]. Therefore, it 
seemed to me that if you had a model where cost in aviation was kept low and tickets were sold at a reasonable 
price, there would be immense demand in this country," he recalls.
INTERVIEW:  E Ajay Singh, managing director, SpiceJet The last five years has been nothing short of 
tumultuous for SpiceJet, having undergone a back-from-the-de....
"That model seemed to exist in Europe with Ryanair and EasyJet and at Southwest Airlines in the United States. I 
thought there was a possibility of replicating those models [in India]."
DARKEST DAYS
Although SpiceJet was loss-making in its initial years of operations, the carrier was profitable before its ownership 
change in 2010. The next four years, however, saw its performance go downhill.
Indian media tycoon Kalanithi Maran, through KAL Airways, which was part of his Sun Group conglomerate, initially 
held a 38.7% stake in the carrier in 2010. Maran and KAL's stake, however, ballooned to 86.2% by 2014 after 
aggressive share acquisitions.
By 2010, Singh held only a 4.13% stake in the carrier he founded. He eventually exited SpiceJet after selling that 
stake in the open market.
By 2014, SpiceJet had amassed losses totalling over $360 million. To compound the situation, the carrier had at its 
peak in the same year, carried a debt of around Rs20.2 billion ($310 million). The airline was eventually grounded 
on 16 December 2014 after it had to cancel 230 flights, largely due to companies refusing to refuel its aircraft on 
account of payment defaults.
The carrier did not stay on the ground for long. Partial operations resumed three days later when Singh returned as 
SpiceJet's white knight, backed by private equity. Had SpiceJet been permanently grounded, it would have become 
the second major Indian carrier to collapse in three years, following the demise of Kingfisher Airlines in 2012.
Bryan van der Beek
Singh says that when SpiceJet was sold to Maran, it was profitable and also had "significant reserves". He also 
reveals that he was approached by Maran to buy back the airline as there were plans for it to shut down.
"I felt there was still a great potential that still existed in the aviation sector. Even at that time, there was still less 
than 3% of people flying in the country. There was an opportunity and the market could still grow. SpiceJet was a 
brand that most people in the country already knew, and therefore, it would be relatively easy for me to take that 
brand forward [rather] than to start something else," he says.
"A little bit of it was also emotional – it was a brand that I helped start and it was painful to see the brand fall into 
such disarray. I wanted to make sure the brand survived."
When Singh started his second stint with SpiceJet in fiscal 2015, the carrier had a total debt of around Rs17.1 
billion. By fiscal 2017, that figure was reduced to Rs9.5 billion.
FROM THE ASHES
Upon his return, Singh’s top priority was to restore the airline's credibility. There was an urgent need to instill 
confidence in passengers that the airline was there to stay, and to clearly communicate the steps being taken to 
remain airborne.
"Nobody wanted to book seats or do business with us, be it partners or suppliers We had to explain to people our 
plan [to restart full operations]. Why would they book tickets in advance if they felt the airline was not going to be 
there?"
The airline chief also made the decision to wet-lease several aircraft in the initial phase of the restart, which though 
an "expensive option", was necessary to "maintain the sanity" of its schedules.
INTERVIEW:  E Ajay Singh, managing director, SpiceJet The last five years has been nothing short of 
tumultuous for SpiceJet, having undergone a back-from-the-de....
The next step was to lower the cost of operations that had soared in the preceding years, and to increase its 
revenue and load factors. To that end, it had to renegotiate engineering and fuel contracts; consolidate its network 
by quickly axing unprofitable routes; and implement measures to boost ancillary revenues.
For fiscal 2017, SpiceJet's CASK ex-fuel stood at Rs2.43 ($0.04), down 20% from a year ago. Its RASK, 
meanwhile, came in at Rs3.76. Ancillary revenues made up 15% of its total income, up from a mere 5% when the 
carrier was first launched.
Aircraft utilisation has also risen, with its Boeing 737 fleet operating more than 13h daily and its Bombardier Q400 
turboprops logging more than 11h. The carrier adds that its load factors have been over 90% for the past 33 
months, and that its on-time performance is also among the best in India.
Bryan van der Beek
Singh says SpiceJet’s "resounding" financials are proof that it has learnt from past experiences. While the carrier 
has not released its full 2018 financials, the first nine months ended 31 December 2017 saw it post an operating 
profit of Rs5.2 billion, up 48.5% year-on-year. Net profit was Rs5.2 billion, up 34%.
Since taking over from Maran, Singh has led SpiceJet to record full-year net profits of $69 million and $64 million in 
fiscal 2016 and 2017, respectively.
"It is about the basics – you need to get your operations right; continuously work to reduce CASK; continuously 
work on increasing the RASK. But ultimately, it's about credibility and confidence. You need to make sure that you 
live up to the commitments made to the public, and at the same time infuse confidence in your own team and 
partners that there is a bright future ahead."
NEW AIRCRAFT
Singh believes that India's aviation market still has a long way to go to reach its full potential – particularly on the 
international sectors, since there is growing affluence among the middle class. As such, SpiceJet is "seriously 
looking" at soaring its wings beyond the 7h mark.
He shares that there is a dedicated team within its revenue department studying further international expansion, 
and that the carrier is keen to reach more points within Southeast Asia, as well as make its first foray into Europe.
FlightGlobal schedules data shows that SpiceJet predominately operates domestic services, although its network 
also reaches Bangkok, Dubai, Muscat, Kabul, Colombo and Male.
"We will only [have more international services] if we can bring cost down to a level [middle-class passengers] can 
afford and we can be profitable. India is a strategic location between ASEAN and African countries where 
economies are growing, and Europe where there are traditional holiday destinations."
Singh has pointed out the Boeing 787 and Airbus A350 as suitable types with which to start intercontinental 
services, but says their price tags have thus far prevented such a move. Now, the broad plan is to start long-haul 
international services only after the airline receives most of its outstanding aircraft orders.
Flight Fleets Analyzer shows the carrier has 60 aircraft in service, comprising 38 737NGs and 22 Q400s. It is set to 
grow exponentially with its backlog of 167 aircraft (122 737 Max 8s, 20 737 Max 10s and 25 Q400s) on order.
Delivery of the Max will start from August and the carrier plans to add up to 15 of the narrowbody type, as well as 
six to nine Q400s by the end of 2018. For the next two years, it will take about 25 737s and 15 Q400s through sale-
and-leasebacks. Financing options for deliveries from 2020 are still being looked at.
INTERVIEW:  E Ajay Singh, managing director, SpiceJet The last five years has been nothing short of 
tumultuous for SpiceJet, having undergone a back-from-the-de....
The carrier is also sitting on a letter of intent for 20 additional Max 10s, with options for 50 units of an unspecified 
type (widely reported to be widebodies) and 25 Q400s. Should its LOIs be fully exercised, SpiceJet would have a 
total orderbook of around 260 aircraft.
However, it still needs to catch up to match the scale of its largest low-cost rival, IndiGo. Flight Fleets Analzyer 
shows IndiGo operates a fleet of 156 A320s and ATR 72s and has a staggering 398 more aircraft on order. On the 
full-service front, dominant players Air India and Jet Airways operate a fleet of 129 and 119 aircraft, respectively.
HAMPERED BY AIRPORTS
Despite the optimism in SpiceJet's own ambitions, Singh laments India's failure to keep its airport infrastructure 
competitive against the likes of Dubai and Singapore – particularly in the area of transforming its gateways into 
major air hubs.
For years, India has seen hub leakage to Dubai International airport (on to Europe and the USA) and Singapore’s 
Changi airport (on to Southeast Asia and Australia), and Singh firmly believes "the time is right" for India to build its 
own international hubs.
Bryan van der Beek
"There was no real plan from private and government-owned players to compete with the international hubs. No 
other base carriers took advantage of Air India's growing weaknesses as a hub carrier. But with Air India's 
privatisation, other full-service and low-cost airlines looking at long-haul low-cost operations need to ensure enough 
domestic capacity to hub out of India."
He points to India's metro airports such as those in Delhi, Bengaluru and Hyderabad, as well as the upcoming Navi-
Mumbai International, not only as international hub options, but also as growth opportunities for SpiceJet.
In the near term, the majority of India's airports are expected to have greater domestic links, especially to tier-two 
and tier-three destinations that have seen an economic boom. Connections will also be boosted by the country’s 
Regional Connectivity Scheme (RCS) – launched in October 2016 with the objective of facilitating and stimulating 
regional air connectivity by making air travel more affordable.
To date, the airline has launched four routes under the scheme, and Singh says he is "very happy" with their 
performance and yields that have done “very well”.
"We had expected that the routes would pick up over several months, but they have picked up much faster than 
that," he continues. "Our RCS routes have been operating at around 90%-plus load factor. The three-year 
exclusivity [for each RCS route] has been useful for us. We also wanted first-mover advantage given the amount of 
growth in such areas. Should there be a third round of RCS bidding, we will definitely do it."
SpiceJet's network strategy is to focus on profitability and to launch services on potentially high-yield routes that 
can feed into its hubs.
LONG-TERM VISION
In the meantime, Singh says he has been trying to instill a culture of freedom and independence within the 
company, while preserving “the mentality of a start-up”.
"We have key people in revenue, finance and airports [departments] who run it like it is their own business. They do 
not refer to me other than for broad directions. But we should not get too complacent and need to consistently work 
at reducing cost and increasing revenue. There must always be a little sense of desperation in the company."
INTERVIEW:  E Ajay Singh, managing director, SpiceJet The last five years has been nothing short of 
tumultuous for SpiceJet, having undergone a back-from-the-de....
With a staff-strength of around 8,000, the carrier is also planning for its future manpower needs. It is building its own 
training campus, which will be completed by the end of the next financial year. The facility is expected to reduce 
training costs by half.
While Singh is open to potential foreign investments into the carrier, he says there is no rush on account of the 
carrier's healthy profits over the past years.
Looking ahead, he also rules out any form of early exit: "I am here for the long term. This is a great business to be 
in, there are many opportunities still around. I would like to be here for the foreseeable future."
Load-Date: April 20, 2018
End of Document
INTERVIEW:  E Ajay Singh, managing director, SpiceJet The last five years has been nothing short of 
tumultuous for SpiceJet, having undergone a back-from-the-de....
INTERVIEW:  E Ajay Singh, managing director, SpiceJet; The last five years 
has been nothing short of tumultuous for SpiceJet, having undergone a 
back-from-the-dead fairytale after surviving a near collapse in 2014. Today, 
the low-cost carrier has completed its turnaround, with a clear focus to keep 
on growing.
Flight International
April 17, 2018
Copyright 2018 Reed Business Information Ltd. All Rights Reserved
Section: FLIGHTGLOBAL.COM
Length: 2068 words
Body
The last five years has been nothing short of tumultuous for SpiceJet. Having undergone a back-from-the-dead 
fairytale after surviving a near collapse in 2014, the airline has completed its turnaround, with a clear focus to keep 
growing.
In an unforgiving domestic sector crowded with around 10 established players, SpiceJet is one of four low-cost 
carriers that also compete with full-service stalwarts such as Air India and Jet Airways, as well as start-ups like 
Vistara. Data from India’s Directorate General of Civil Aviation shows that SpiceJet has, over the past three years, 
consistently been ranked among India’s top five airlines in terms of domestic market share.
With two consecutive years of profits under its belt, scars from the carrier's near-death experience are starting to 
fade. Its rise-from-the-ashes story has one man to thank – founder Ajay Singh.
Bryan van der Beek
At SpiceJet's headquarters in Gurgaon, New Delhi, the 52-year-old tells FlightGlobal he started SpiceJet in 2004 
because he saw "a great need for maturity" in Indian aviation. Then, about 16 million people commuted daily by 
train in India – about the same as the number of air passengers in an entire year.
In the telecommunications industry at that time, the entrepreneur saw "a golden opportunity" – and seized it.
"We had seen the impact of reducing tariffs to generate demand [in the telecommunications sector]. Therefore, it 
seemed to me that if you had a model where cost in aviation was kept low and tickets were sold at a reasonable 
price, there would be immense demand in this country," he recalls.
INTERVIEW:  E Ajay Singh, managing director, SpiceJet The last five years has been nothing short of 
tumultuous for SpiceJet, having undergone a back-from-the-de....
"That model seemed to exist in Europe with Ryanair and EasyJet and at Southwest Airlines in the United States. I 
thought there was a possibility of replicating those models [in India]."
DARKEST DAYS
Although SpiceJet was loss-making in its initial years of operations, the carrier was profitable before its ownership 
change in 2010. The next four years, however, saw its performance go downhill.
Indian media tycoon Kalanithi Maran, through KAL Airways, which was part of his Sun Group conglomerate, initially 
held a 38.7% stake in the carrier in 2010. Maran and KAL's stake, however, ballooned to 86.2% by 2014 after 
aggressive share acquisitions.
By 2010, Singh held only a 4.13% stake in the carrier he founded. He eventually exited SpiceJet after selling that 
stake in the open market.
By 2014, SpiceJet had amassed losses totalling over $360 million. To compound the situation, the carrier had at its 
peak in the same year, carried a debt of around Rs20.2 billion ($310 million). The airline was eventually grounded 
on 16 December 2014 after it had to cancel 230 flights, largely due to companies refusing to refuel its aircraft on 
account of payment defaults.
The carrier did not stay on the ground for long. Partial operations resumed three days later when Singh returned as 
SpiceJet's white knight, backed by private equity. Had SpiceJet been permanently grounded, it would have become 
the second major Indian carrier to collapse in three years, following the demise of Kingfisher Airlines in 2012.
Bryan van der Beek
Singh says that when SpiceJet was sold to Maran, it was profitable and also had "significant reserves". He also 
reveals that he was approached by Maran to buy back the airline as there were plans for it to shut down.
"I felt there was still a great potential that still existed in the aviation sector. Even at that time, there was still less 
than 3% of people flying in the country. There was an opportunity and the market could still grow. SpiceJet was a 
brand that most people in the country already knew, and therefore, it would be relatively easy for me to take that 
brand forward [rather] than to start something else," he says.
"A little bit of it was also emotional – it was a brand that I helped start and it was painful to see the brand fall into 
such disarray. I wanted to make sure the brand survived."
When Singh started his second stint with SpiceJet in fiscal 2015, the carrier had a total debt of around Rs17.1 
billion. By fiscal 2017, that figure was reduced to Rs9.5 billion.
FROM THE ASHES
Upon his return, Singh’s top priority was to restore the airline's credibility. There was an urgent need to instill 
confidence in passengers that the airline was there to stay, and to clearly communicate the steps being taken to 
remain airborne.
"Nobody wanted to book seats or do business with us, be it partners or suppliers We had to explain to people our 
plan [to restart full operations]. Why would they book tickets in advance if they felt the airline was not going to be 
there?"
The airline chief also made the decision to wet-lease several aircraft in the initial phase of the restart, which though 
an "expensive option", was necessary to "maintain the sanity" of its schedules.
INTERVIEW:  E Ajay Singh, managing director, SpiceJet The last five years has been nothing short of 
tumultuous for SpiceJet, having undergone a back-from-the-de....
The next step was to lower the cost of operations that had soared in the preceding years, and to increase its 
revenue and load factors. To that end, it had to renegotiate engineering and fuel contracts; consolidate its network 
by quickly axing unprofitable routes; and implement measures to boost ancillary revenues.
For fiscal 2017, SpiceJet's CASK ex-fuel stood at Rs2.43 ($0.04), down 20% from a year ago. Its RASK, 
meanwhile, came in at Rs3.76. Ancillary revenues made up 15% of its total income, up from a mere 5% when the 
carrier was first launched.
Aircraft utilisation has also risen, with its Boeing 737 fleet operating more than 13h daily and its Bombardier Q400 
turboprops logging more than 11h. The carrier adds that its load factors have been over 90% for the past 33 
months, and that its on-time performance is also among the best in India.
Bryan van der Beek
Singh says SpiceJet’s "resounding" financials are proof that it has learnt from past experiences. While the carrier 
has not released its full 2018 financials, the first nine months ended 31 December 2017 saw it post an operating 
profit of Rs5.2 billion, up 48.5% year-on-year. Net profit was Rs5.2 billion, up 34%.
Since taking over from Maran, Singh has led SpiceJet to record full-year net profits of $69 million and $64 million in 
fiscal 2016 and 2017, respectively.
"It is about the basics – you need to get your operations right; continuously work to reduce CASK; continuously 
work on increasing the RASK. But ultimately, it's about credibility and confidence. You need to make sure that you 
live up to the commitments made to the public, and at the same time infuse confidence in your own team and 
partners that there is a bright future ahead."
NEW AIRCRAFT
Singh believes that India's aviation market still has a long way to go to reach its full potential – particularly on the 
international sectors, since there is growing affluence among the middle class. As such, SpiceJet is "seriously 
looking" at soaring its wings beyond the 7h mark.
He shares that there is a dedicated team within its revenue department studying further international expansion, 
and that the carrier is keen to reach more points within Southeast Asia, as well as make its first foray into Europe.
FlightGlobal schedules data shows that SpiceJet predominately operates domestic services, although its network 
also reaches Bangkok, Dubai, Muscat, Kabul, Colombo and Male.
"We will only [have more international services] if we can bring cost down to a level [middle-class passengers] can 
afford and we can be profitable. India is a strategic location between ASEAN and African countries where 
economies are growing, and Europe where there are traditional holiday destinations."
Singh has pointed out the Boeing 787 and Airbus A350 as suitable types with which to start intercontinental 
services, but says their price tags have thus far prevented such a move. Now, the broad plan is to start long-haul 
international services only after the airline receives most of its outstanding aircraft orders.
Flight Fleets Analyzer shows the carrier has 60 aircraft in service, comprising 38 737NGs and 22 Q400s. It is set to 
grow exponentially with its backlog of 167 aircraft (122 737 Max 8s, 20 737 Max 10s and 25 Q400s) on order.
Delivery of the Max will start from August and the carrier plans to add up to 15 of the narrowbody type, as well as 
six to nine Q400s by the end of 2018. For the next two years, it will take about 25 737s and 15 Q400s through sale-
and-leasebacks. Financing options for deliveries from 2020 are still being looked at.
INTERVIEW:  E Ajay Singh, managing director, SpiceJet The last five years has been nothing short of 
tumultuous for SpiceJet, having undergone a back-from-the-de....
The carrier is also sitting on a letter of intent for 20 additional Max 10s, with options for 50 units of an unspecified 
type (widely reported to be widebodies) and 25 Q400s. Should its LOIs be fully exercised, SpiceJet would have a 
total orderbook of around 260 aircraft.
However, it still needs to catch up to match the scale of its largest low-cost rival, IndiGo. Flight Fleets Analzyer 
shows IndiGo operates a fleet of 156 A320s and ATR 72s and has a staggering 398 more aircraft on order. On the 
full-service front, dominant players Air India and Jet Airways operate a fleet of 129 and 119 aircraft, respectively.
HAMPERED BY AIRPORTS
Despite the optimism in SpiceJet's own ambitions, Singh laments India's failure to keep its airport infrastructure 
competitive against the likes of Dubai and Singapore – particularly in the area of transforming its gateways into 
major air hubs.
For years, India has seen hub leakage to Dubai International airport (on to Europe and the USA) and Singapore’s 
Changi airport (on to Southeast Asia and Australia), and Singh firmly believes "the time is right" for India to build its 
own international hubs.
Bryan van der Beek
"There was no real plan from private and government-owned players to compete with the international hubs. No 
other base carriers took advantage of Air India's growing weaknesses as a hub carrier. But with Air India's 
privatisation, other full-service and low-cost airlines looking at long-haul low-cost operations need to ensure enough 
domestic capacity to hub out of India."
He points to India's metro airports such as those in Delhi, Bengaluru and Hyderabad, as well as the upcoming Navi-
Mumbai International, not only as international hub options, but also as growth opportunities for SpiceJet.
In the near term, the majority of India's airports are expected to have greater domestic links, especially to tier-two 
and tier-three destinations that have seen an economic boom. Connections will also be boosted by the country’s 
Regional Connectivity Scheme (RCS) – launched in October 2016 with the objective of facilitating and stimulating 
regional air connectivity by making air travel more affordable.
To date, the airline has launched four routes under the scheme, and Singh says he is "very happy" with their 
performance and yields that have done “very well”.
"We had expected that the routes would pick up over several months, but they have picked up much faster than 
that," he continues. "Our RCS routes have been operating at around 90%-plus load factor. The three-year 
exclusivity [for each RCS route] has been useful for us. We also wanted first-mover advantage given the amount of 
growth in such areas. Should there be a third round of RCS bidding, we will definitely do it."
SpiceJet's network strategy is to focus on profitability and to launch services on potentially high-yield routes that 
can feed into its hubs.
LONG-TERM VISION
In the meantime, Singh says he has been trying to instill a culture of freedom and independence within the 
company, while preserving “the mentality of a start-up”.
"We have key people in revenue, finance and airports [departments] who run it like it is their own business. They do 
not refer to me other than for broad directions. But we should not get too complacent and need to consistently work 
at reducing cost and increasing revenue. There must always be a little sense of desperation in the company."
INTERVIEW:  E Ajay Singh, managing director, SpiceJet The last five years has been nothing short of 
tumultuous for SpiceJet, having undergone a back-from-the-de....
With a staff-strength of around 8,000, the carrier is also planning for its future manpower needs. It is building its own 
training campus, which will be completed by the end of the next financial year. The facility is expected to reduce 
training costs by half.
While Singh is open to potential foreign investments into the carrier, he says there is no rush on account of the 
carrier's healthy profits over the past years.
Looking ahead, he also rules out any form of early exit: "I am here for the long term. This is a great business to be 
in, there are many opportunities still around. I would like to be here for the foreseeable future."
Load-Date: April 19, 2018
End of Document
Air Berlin fall triggers big shift at Tegel German market experiences significant change in the wake of carrier's 
collapse, with EasyJet and others adding capac....
Air Berlin fall triggers big shift at Tegel; German market experiences 
significant change in the wake of carrier's collapse, with EasyJet and others 
adding capacity
Flight International
April 17, 2018
Copyright 2018 Reed Business Information Ltd. All Rights Reserved
Section: NEWS FOCUS
Length: 861 words
Body
Attendees at this year’s ILA Berlin show arrive in the German capital after a period of intense change in the 
country’s airline market.
The effects of this are most keenly felt at Berlin Tegel, where the familiar red and white livery of defunct Air Berlin 
has been replaced by other airlines backfilling capacity.
The fragmented nature of Air Berlin’s model, established through a series of acquisitions, means its fall has rippled 
across various market segments – and beyond Germany.
After Abu Dhabi’s Etihad pulled the plug on further investment in Air Berlin, the German carrier initiated insolvency 
proceedings last summer, sparking the break-up of the group.
Overall short-haul capacity in Germany – defined as flights within the European Economic Area and Switzerland – 
is set to climb slightly over the summer. FlightGlobal schedules data for April-September shows seat capacity rising 
by about 2%. That is lower than the 4% growth last summer, though, and the 7%-plus increase in the summer of 
2016 – a year in which Ryanair expanded rapidly in the German market.
Air Berlin, together with Niki, had its largest presence at Tegel and Düsseldorf airports, accounting for more than 
half of its short-haul capacity last summer.
Easy pickings
The largest chunk of that has been taken up by EasyJet. The UK budget carrier began operations at Tegel in 
January after completing a deal to acquire assets including aircraft and airport slots from Air Berlin’s administrators.
Air Berlin fall triggers big shift at Tegel German market experiences significant change in the wake of carrier's 
collapse, with EasyJet and others adding capac....
For a cost of 40 million ($49 million), EasyJet agreed to lease up to 25 former Air Berlin Airbus A320s for operations 
from Tegel, recruit 1,000 flightcrew formerly with the Oneworld member, and acquire other assets including the 
slots.
EasyJet, which had already been active at Berlin Schönefeld, is now the biggest operator at Tegel and has 
launched 10 new routes from the site, three of which have switched from the German capital’s other airport.
Eurowings is the other big mover – even accounting for capacity formerly operated under the Germanwings name. 
Factoring in the mainline operation, plus siblings Austrian Airlines and Swiss – all of which will operate increased 
capacity this summer – Lufthansa Group will be the biggest overall operator on short-haul European routes 
from Tegel.
Air Berlin had already operated some capacity for Eurowings under a wet-lease agreement, but the latter’s capacity 
at Tegel has been boosted by its acquisition of German regional carrier LGW from the administrators of its failed 
rival.
Laudamotion and Ryanair, meanwhile, have announced a series of flights to be operated by the former from Tegel. 
Laudamotion will station four aircraft in Berlin from the start of June to operate 17 routes largely drawn from former 
Niki destinations.
It is a different story at Düsseldorf, where short-haul European capacity is set be down more than 10% year-on-year 
this summer. Last summer Air Berlin and Niki operated about 40 routes from the west German site, most of which 
had one or more carriers on them.
Eurowings has made the most gains at the airport, and is now comfortably the largest operator from Düsseldorf.
But Lufthansa and Condor will also increase their capacity from the German hub this summer. The latter is 
expanding after its parent, Thomas Cook, acquired assets from the Air Berlin Aviation subsidiary.
While EasyJet and Ryanair lead the way in terms of seat capacity from Berlin overall, neither has made significant 
inroads at Düsseldorf.
Ryanair was a vocal critic of the deal allowing Lufthansa to acquire assets from Air Berlin. The Irish carrier’s chief 
executive, Michael O’Leary, speaking in Brussels in early March, returned to this theme. He said Ryanair wanted to 
grow in Germany, but that it was “very hard to base more aircraft in those airports, because you have Lufthansa 
[and its ex-Air Berlin slots] and Eurowings sitting there like bed-blockers, blocking all the morning slots”.
Not everything went Lufthansa’s way, however, as it failed to secure approval for a deal to acquire Niki in Austria.
And ultimately, once legal issues scuppered IAG’s bid for the carrier, Ryanair ended up acquiring it by striking a 
deal with the successful bidder, Niki Lauda, for an initial 24.9% stake in the business, eventually rising to 75% if 
competition approval is granted.
shout lauda
Ryanair is paying 50 million for the stake, and will provide another 50 million for “year-one start-up and operating 
costs”, along with “financial and management support”.
Chief operations officer Peter Bellew cites Ryanair’s desire to accelerate growth in Austrian, German and Swiss 
markets as a key consideration behind its Niki purchase.
“We’ve also been growing quickly [in the German market],” Bellew says. “We’ve nearly increased by a third there in 
the last 18 months or so. We feel there’s loads of business there.”
While Air Berlin’s demise may be keenly felt by some, for others its departure has been a golden opportunity.
Air Berlin fall triggers big shift at Tegel German market experiences significant change in the wake of carrier's 
collapse, with EasyJet and others adding capac....
Break-up of Oneworld member was seized on by bigger competitors
Stefan Boness/Ipon/SIPA/REX/Shutterstock

growing quickly [in
the German market].
We feel there’s loads
of business there”
Peter Bellew
Chief operations officer, Ryanair

GAM’s Gallagher looks to next leg of Europe's rally
GAM’s Gallagher looks to next leg of Europe's rally
Citywire
April 17, 2018 Tuesday 2:40 PM GMT
Copyright 2018 Citywire Financial Publishers All Rights Reserved
Length: 906 words
Byline: Hamza Ali
Highlight: Citywire A-rated manager of £1.8 billion GAM Star Continental European Equity fund, believes Spanish 
and Italian stocks will pick up the baton.
Body
 
Niall Gallagher, manager of the £1.8 billion GAM Star Continental European Equity  fund, believes that Europe’s 
recovery will gather strength, with Spanish and Italian stocks picking up the baton.
Last year marked a watershed for European compnay earnings, with stocks either matching or beating expectations 
after six years of disappointment.
That was reflected in a strong showing from European markets, which beat the returns of the US and UK, and the 
rallying euro.
‘We’ve been optimistic for a while, we picked up cyclical names early 2014 when European economies started 
doing better and have progressively become more optimistic,' said Gallacher.
‘To take advantage for the recovery, we are currently very cyclically positioned in our fund and overweight domestic 
European earnings,’ said the Citywire A-rated manager.
The recovery in Europe has helped the fund enjoy its longest period of outperformance since 2007, with the fund 
returning 40% over three years to the end of February, compared to 32% from the MSCI Europe ex-UK benchmark.
Holding on
Despite the move into cyclicals, turnover in the portfolio remains low.
‘We have a low name turnover, with only a handful of companies coming into the portfolio and a handful coming 
out. A lot of the holdings in the portfolio I have held for a very long time,’ explained Gallagher (pictured).
‘Inditex (ITX.MC), Ryanair (RYA.I), Hexagon (HEXAb.ST), LVMH (LVMH.PA), Grafton Group (GFTU_u), 
Kingspan (KSP) and Paddy Power Betfair (PPB), I have held for something like 15 years.’
GAM’s Gallagher looks to next leg of Europe's rally
These core holdings, which Gallagher likes for their above-average returns on capital employed, make up the 
majority of the fund, which has a total of 35 stocks.
The portfolio’s current active share is 87% compared to its benchmark, and Gallagher is happy to stick to his guns.
‘I’m not looking to rotate the portfolio too much, rather shift it through time; for example, right now, that’s why I’m a 
little bit more cyclical and a bit less international,’ he said.
‘The fund is currently made up of cyclical growth from its European earnings and fast growing structural growth 
outside of Europe in luxury and tech sectors.’
The cyclical names are mainly in the construction and building materials, automotive and banking sectors. These 
sectors will stand to benefit from a strong growth in earnings should Europe’s recovery pick up pace, he said.
‘We have two house builders, Aedas (AEDAS.MC) in Spain and Cairn Homes (CRN) in Ireland. Both are new 
companies founded in the last few years that have similar business models. They bought non-performing loans 
from banks, structured these loans so that they took over the collateral, which was typically a land bank of a bust 
real estate developer that was seized by a bank or a national “bad bank”.
‘The reason why we think that is a good business model is because both Spain and Ireland are in the midst of a 
housing crisis, because house building slowed to a crawl after the financial crisis and there is a lot of demand for a 
new land bank with a pristine balance sheet and lots of cash.’
Recovery spreads
The geographic allocation of the fund also reflects the fund manager’s view on the European recovery.
‘We have a fair exposure to Spanish and Italian names, reflecting our view that the recovery has only just got 
underway there. In Spain this comes from names like Aedas and media company Mediaset España (TL5.MC) as 
well as core holdings like Caixabank (CABK.MC) and clothing retailer Inditex,' said Gallagher.
‘Conversely, we are very underweight Switzerland and have only one investment in power company Schindler 
(SCHP.S). The reason is simply that we believe the Swiss companies are seriously expensive.’
The fund’s earnings split is also tilted towards Europe, with 55% in domestic earnings.
‘Typically our exposure to overseas earnings is 50-50, but as we have taken a positive view on earnings growth 
potential in Europe we have increased our exposure,’ explained Gallagher.
Despite this bias towards European earnings, the fund’s two most recent purchases are both value plays targeting 
international earnings.
‘We have been adding Bayer (BAYGn.DE) over the past year or so. The new chief executive announced that he 
was buying Monsanto, which was a change in the company’s policy,’ said Gallagher.
‘Up until that point they had been selling off their chemical businesses and focusing on pharma. The announcement 
caught a lot of shareholders by surprise and the share price took quite a big hit off the back of that.
‘We are positive on the Monsanto acquisition and believe that the agricultural economics sector is an interesting 
one. If you combine Monsanto’s seed developments with Bayer’s chemical intellectual property then you get a firm 
that controls more than a quarter of the world’s seed and pesticides market.’
Another name that has made it into the fund is luxury jewellery maker, Pandora 
‘Controversially, we’ve also started buying Pandora (PNDORA.CO) in recent months,’ said Gallagher.
GAM’s Gallagher looks to next leg of Europe's rally
‘The stock was out of favour because it is seen as quite faddy and the company had been a little slow in renewing 
its rolling stock.
‘We’ve gained a lot of comfort from speaking to the company that it is speeding up its innovation to improve 
replenishment and the brand’s strong presence in its established markets dispel the idea that it’s faddy. Last year, 
sales slowed down but they were still pretty decent, they are still growing revenue and growing profits.’ 
Load-Date: April 18, 2018
End of Document
GAM’s Gallagher optimistic for European recovery
GAM’s Gallagher optimistic for European recovery
Citywire
April 17, 2018 Tuesday 2:40 PM GMT
Copyright 2018 Citywire Financial Publishers All Rights Reserved
Length: 878 words
Byline: Hamza Ali
Highlight: Niall Gallagher, manager of the £1.78 billion GAM Star Continental European Equity fund believes that 
Europe’s recovery is ‘well and truly on’.
Body
Niall Gallagher, manager of the £1.78 billion GAM Star Continental European Equity  fund believes that Europe’s 
recovery is ‘well and truly on’.
In his opinion, Europe has shrugged off Brexit and the spectre of the eurozone debt crisis, so that corporate 
earnings, which had been depressed for a very long time, are growing steadily.
‘We’ve been optimistic for a while, we picked up cyclical names early 2014 when European economies started 
doing better and have progressively become more optimistic.
‘To take advantage for the recovery, we are currently very cyclically positioned in our fund and overweight domestic 
European earnings,’ said the Citywire A-rated manager.
The recovery in Europe has helped the fund enjoy its longest period of outperformance since 2007, with the fund 
returning 40.4% over three years to 28 February, compared to the 31.98% delivered by its benchmark, the MSCI 
Europe ex UK index.
Holding on
Despite the move into cyclicals, turnover in the portfolio remains low.
‘We have a low name turnover, with only a handful of companies coming into the portfolio and a handful coming 
out. A lot of the holdings in the portfolio I have held for a very long time,’ explained Gallagher.
‘Inditex, Ryanair, Hexagon, LVMH, Grafton Group, Kingspan and Paddy Power, I have held for something like 15 
years.’
These core holdings, which deliver ‘above average returns on capital employed’ according to Gallagher, make up 
the majority of the fund, which has a total of 35 stocks.
GAM’s Gallagher optimistic for European recovery
The portfolio’s current active share is 87% compared to its benchmark, and Gallagher is happy to stick to his guns. 
He estimates that only 15-20% of the fund’s allocation is geared to take advantage of the change in economic 
cycle.
‘I’m not looking to rotate the portfolio too much, rather shift it through time; for example, right now, that’s why I’m a 
little bit more cyclical and a bit less international,’ he said.
He added: ‘The fund is currently made up of cyclical growth from its European earnings and fast growing structural 
growth outside of Europe in luxury and tech sectors.’
The cyclical names are mainly in the construction and building materials, automotive and banking sectors. These 
sectors will stand to benefit from a strong growth in earnings as Europe’s recovery picks up pace.
‘We have two house builders, Aedas in Spain and Cairn Homes in Ireland. Both are new companies founded in the 
last few years that have similar business models. They bought non-performing loans from banks, structured these 
loans so that they took over the collateral, which was typically a land bank of a bust real estate developer that was 
seized by a bank or a national “bad bank”.
‘The reason why we think that is a good business model is because both Spain and Ireland are in the midst of a 
housing crisis, because house building slowed to a crawl after the financial crisis and there is a lot of demand for a 
new land bank with a pristine balance sheet and lots of cash.’
New recovery
The geographic allocation of the fund also reflects the fund manager’s view on European recovery.
‘We have a fair exposure to Spanish and Italian names, reflecting our view that the recovery has only just got 
underway there. In Spain this comes from names like Aedas and media company Mediaset España as well as core 
holdings like Spanish CaixaBank and clothing retailer Inditex,’ said Gallagher.
‘Conversely, we are very underweight Switzerland and have only one investment in power company Schindler. The 
reason is simply that we believe the Swiss companies are seriously expensive.’
The fund’s earnings split is also tilted towards Europe, with 55% in domestic earnings.
‘Typically our exposure to overseas earnings is 50-50, but as we have taken a positive view on earnings growth 
potential in Europe we have increased our exposure,’ explained Gallagher.
Despite this bias towards European earnings, the fund’s two most recent purchases are both value plays targeting 
international earnings.
‘We have been adding Bayer over the past year or so. The new CEO announced that he was buying Monsanto, 
which was a change in the company’s policy,’ said Gallagher.
‘Up until that point they had been selling off their chemical businesses and focusing on pharma. The announcement 
caught a lot of shareholders by surprise and the share price took quite a big hit off the back of that.
‘We are positive on the Monsanto acquisition and believe that the agricultural economics sector is an interesting 
one. If you combine Monsanto’s seed developments with Bayer’s chemical intellectual property then you get a firm 
that controls more than a quarter of the world’s seed and pesticides market.’
Another name that has made it into the fund is luxury jewellery maker, Pandora.
‘Controversially, we’ve also started buying Pandora in recent months,’ said Gallagher.
‘The stock was out of favour because it is seen as quite faddy and the company had been a little slow in renewing 
its rolling stock.
GAM’s Gallagher optimistic for European recovery
‘We’ve gained a lot of comfort from speaking to the company that it is speeding up its innovation to improve 
replenishment and the brand’s strong presence in its established markets dispel the idea that it’s faddy. Last year, 
sales slowed down but they were still pretty decent, they are still growing revenue and growing profits.’

European ADRs Move Higher in Monday Trading
European ADRs Move Higher in Monday Trading
MT Newswires Live Briefs
April 16, 2018 Monday 11:21 AM EST
Copyright 2018 MT Newswires All Rights Reserved
Length: 229 words
Body
 American depositary receipts of European stocks were trading 0.13% higher at 141.69 on the Bank of New York 
Mellon Europe ADR Index on Monday.
In continental Europe, the gainers were led by pharmaceutical company Oasmia Pharmaceutical (OASM), and 
geophysical equipment company CGG (CGG), which rose 6.0% and 1.2% respectively. Also rising were 
biopharmaceutical company DBV Technologies (DBVT), and software vendor Talend (TLND), which were up 1.5% 
and 0.3%. 
The decliners in continental Europe were led by furniture maker Natuzzi (NTZ), and 3D printer company voxeljet 
(VJET), which lost 3.6% and 2.4% respectively. They were followed by biopharmaceutical firm Forward Pharma 
(FWP),which dropped 2.3%. 
In the UK and Ireland, the gainers were led by biopharmaceutical firm GW Pharmaceuticals (GWPH), and 
telecommunications giant BT (BT), which climbed 1.5% and 1.2% respectively. They were followed by airline 
operator Ryanair (RYAAY), and cruise line operator Carnival (CUK), which rose 1.1% and 1.0%. 
The decliners in the UK and Ireland were led by communications company WPP (WPP), and biopharmaceutical 
company Adaptimmune Therapeutics (ADAP), which fell 5.9% and 2.9% respectively. They were followed by 
biopharmaceutical firm Akari Therapeutics (AKTX), and pharmaceutical company AstraZeneca (AZN), which shed 
1.9% and 1.8%.
Price: 1.59, Change: +0.09, Percent Change: +5.95
Load-Date: April 17, 2018
European ADRs Move Higher in Monday Trading
End of Document

positive and negative news coverage by reviewing more than twenty million news and blog sources. Accern ranks 
coverage of publicly-traded companies on a scale of -1 to 1, with scores nearest to one being the most favorable. 
Ryanair earned a coverage optimism score of 0.18 on Accern's scale. Accern also assigned news stories about the 
transportation company an impact score of 45.6791880943703 out of 100, indicating that recent news coverage is 
somewhat unlikely to have an impact on the company's share price in the next several days.  Here are some of the

through open market purchases. Shares buyback plans are often an indication that the company's management
