Ryanair announces corporate partnership with National Gallery of Ireland
Ryanair announces corporate partnership with National Gallery of Ireland
Business World (Digest)
April 16, 2018 Monday
Copyright 2018 Media World Ltd. All Rights Reserved
Section: GENERAL
Length: 320 words
Byline: Robert McHugh
Body
It was announced today that Ryanair has formed a new three year Premier Corporate Partnership with the National 
Gallery of Ireland in Dublin. The partnership, which runs until 2020, will enable Ryanair to support the arts under its 
“Always Getting Better” programme.
The newly refurbished Gallery, which was founded in 1854, is located on Dublin’s Merrion Square West and is one 
of Ireland’s leading institutions of cultural importance, attracting over a million visitors per year.
The partnership follows similar collaborations with Trinity College Dublin, where Ryanair sponsors a Professor of 
Entrepreneurship, and its ongoing support for ISPCC Childline, Ryanair’s official charity partner, as part of its 
expanding CSR programme.
Speaking today, Director of Development at the National Gallery of Ireland, Gabrielle Murphy said, "We are 
delighted to have Ryanair as one of our new Premier Corporate Partners. As a Corporate Partner, Ryanair will 
enjoy a range of benefits for its staff, the opportunity to attend  exciting behind the scenes visits and private tours, 
as well as the chance to hold its own events at the Gallery. The support from Ryanair allows the Gallery to host 
world class exhibitions as well as to invest more in its permanent collection and public engagement programme."
Ryanair’s Head of Communications, Robin Kiely added, "We are pleased to have entered into this partnership with 
the National Gallery of Ireland, which enables Ryanair to support one of Ireland’s leading institutions of cultural 
importance. The Gallery’s renewed focus on the visitor experience, reopening of the historic wings, and resumption 
of a full programme of exhibitions, events and educational activities will see it grow from strength to strength. We 
are delighted to make our contribution to its continued development and we encourage our 13 million annual Dublin 
customers to pay a visit."
Ryanair announces corporate partnership with National Gallery of Ireland
Source: www.businessworld.ie
Load-Date: May 4, 2018
End of Document
Ryanair (RYAAY) Upgraded to "Buy" by
Ryanair (RYAAY) Upgraded to "Buy" by
American Banking and Market News
April 16, 2018 Monday
Copyright 2018 American Banking and Market News All Rights Reserved
Length: 743 words
Body
Ryanair logo Ryanair (NASDAQ:RYAAY) was upgraded by equities research analysts at  from a "hold" rating to a 
"buy" rating in a note issued to investors on Tuesday, July 25th,            Marketbeat Ratings  reports. 
Other equities analysts have also issued research reports about the stock. UBS lowered shares of Ryanair from a 
"buy" rating to a "neutral" rating in a research report on Friday, June 2nd. ValuEngine  upgraded shares of Ryanair 
from a "hold" rating to a "buy" rating in a research note on Tuesday, June 6th. Citigroup downgraded shares of 
Ryanair from a "buy" rating to a "neutral" rating in a research note on Wednesday, May 31st. Goldman Sachs 
upgraded shares of Ryanair from a "neutral" rating to a "buy" rating and raised their price objective for the stock 
from $67.56 to $109.00 in a research note on Thursday, June 15th. Finally, Sanford C. Bernstein began coverage 
on shares of Ryanair in a research note on Monday, June 26th. They issued an "underperform" rating and a $83.00 
price objective on the stock. Two investment analysts have rated the stock with a sell rating, two have assigned  a 
hold rating, five have issued  a buy rating and one  has assigned  a strong buy rating to the company's stock. 
Ryanair presently has a consensus rating of "Buy" and an average target price of $110.00. 
RYAAY  traded up $0.77 during midday trading on Tuesday, hitting $122.14. 57,233 shares of the company's stock 
traded hands, compared to its average volume of 331,356. The firm has a market cap of $28,428.25, a PE ratio of 
21.14, a PEG ratio of 0.84 and a beta of 0.64. The company has a debt-to-equity ratio of 0.77, a quick ratio of 1.61 
and a current ratio of 1.61. Ryanair has a one year low of $84.75 and a one year high of $127.61.  
Ryanair (NASDAQ:RYAAY) last issued its quarterly earnings data on Monday, February 5th. The transportation 
company reported $0.52 earnings per share for the quarter, beating the consensus estimate of $0.50 by $0.02. The 
firm had revenue of $1.65 billion for the quarter, compared to analyst estimates of $1.68 billion. Ryanair had a net 
margin of 20.99% and a return on equity of 32.17%.  sell-side analysts anticipate that  Ryanair will post 7.29 
earnings per share for the current fiscal year.  
Ryanair announced that its Board of Directors has approved a share buyback program on Monday, February 5th 
that permits the company to repurchase    shares. This repurchase authorization permits the transportation 
company to repurchase shares of its stock through open market purchases. Stock  repurchase programs are 
usually an indication that the company's leadership believes its shares are undervalued.  
Hedge funds have recently made changes to their positions in the stock. State Street Corp raised its holdings in  
Ryanair by 35.0% in the 4th quarter. State Street Corp now owns 324,522 shares of the transportation company's 
stock worth $27,016,000 after purchasing an additional 84,140 shares during the period.  Capstone Asset

Management Co. grew its holdings in  Ryanair by 8.2% in the first quarter. Capstone Asset Management Co. now 
owns 13,017 shares of the transportation company's stock valued at $1,080,000 after purchasing an additional 990 
shares during the period.  Fox Run Management L.L.C. purchased a new stake in  Ryanair in the first quarter 
valued at approximately $282,000.  Reliance Trust Co. of Delaware grew its holdings in  Ryanair by 22.5% in the 
first quarter. Reliance Trust Co. of Delaware now owns 9,615 shares of the transportation company's stock valued 
at $798,000 after purchasing an additional 1,764 shares during the period.  Finally, Huntington National Bank grew 
its holdings in  Ryanair by 4.3% in the first quarter. Huntington National Bank now owns 2,722 shares of the 
transportation company's stock valued at $226,000 after purchasing an additional 111 shares during the period. 
Hedge funds and other institutional investors own  42.35% of the company's stock.   
About Ryanair
Ryanair Holdings plc, together with its subsidiaries, provides scheduled-passenger airline services in Ireland, the 
United Kingdom, continental Europe, Morocco, and Israel. It also offers various ancillary services, such as non-flight 
scheduled services and Internet-related services; and markets accommodation services and travel insurance 
through its Website, as well as engages in the in-flight sale of beverages, food, and merchandise.

Ryanair (RYAAY) Stock Rating Lowered by BidaskClub
Ryanair (RYAAY) Stock Rating Lowered by BidaskClub
American Banking and Market News
April 15, 2018 Sunday
Copyright 2018 American Banking and Market News All Rights Reserved
Length: 735 words
Body
Ryanair logo Ryanair (NASDAQ:RYAAY) was downgraded by equities research analysts at            BidaskClub  
from a "strong-buy" rating to a "buy" rating in a research note issued on Tuesday, July 25th. 
Several other brokerages also recently issued reports on RYAAY.  upgraded Ryanair from a "hold" rating to a "buy" 
rating in a research report on Tuesday, July 25th. Sanford C. Bernstein began coverage on Ryanair in a research 
report on Monday, June 26th. They set an "underperform" rating and a $83.00 price objective for the company. 
Goldman Sachs upgraded Ryanair from a "neutral" rating to a "buy" rating and lifted their price objective for the 
stock from $67.56 to $109.00 in a research report on Thursday, June 15th. ValuEngine  upgraded Ryanair from a 
"hold" rating to a "buy" rating in a research report on Tuesday, June 6th. Finally, UBS cut shares of Ryanair from a 
"buy" rating to a "neutral" rating in a research note on Friday, June 2nd. Two analysts have rated the stock with a 
sell rating, two have assigned  a hold rating, five have assigned  a buy rating and one  has assigned  a strong buy 
rating to the company's stock. The stock  has an average rating of "Buy" and a consensus price target of $110.00. 
Shares of Ryanair stock  traded down $0.02 during trading on Tuesday, hitting $121.37. 92,310 shares of the 
company were exchanged, compared to its average volume of 248,339. The company has a debt-to-equity ratio of 
0.77, a current ratio of 1.61 and a quick ratio of 1.61. Ryanair has a fifty-two week low of $84.75 and a fifty-two 
week high of $127.61. The company has a market capitalization of $28,624.00, a P/E ratio of 21.14, a P/E/G ratio of 
0.84 and a beta of 0.64.  
Ryanair (NASDAQ:RYAAY) last issued its quarterly earnings data on Monday, February 5th. The transportation 
company reported $0.52 earnings per share (EPS) for the quarter, topping the Thomson Reuters' consensus 
estimate of $0.50 by $0.02. Ryanair had a return on equity of 32.17% and a net margin of 20.99%. The firm had 
revenue of $1.65 billion during the quarter, compared to the consensus estimate of $1.68 billion.  research analysts 
expect that  Ryanair will post 7.29 EPS for the current fiscal year.  
Ryanair announced that its board has approved a stock buyback program on Monday, February 5th that permits the 
company to repurchase    shares. This repurchase authorization permits the transportation company to repurchase 
shares of its stock through open market purchases. Shares repurchase programs are often a sign that the 
company's board believes its shares are undervalued.  
A number of hedge funds have recently added to or reduced their stakes in RYAAY. State Street Corp grew its 
stake in shares of  Ryanair by 35.0% during the 4th quarter. State Street Corp now owns 324,522 shares of the 
transportation company's stock valued at $27,016,000 after buying an additional 84,140 shares during the period.

additional 111 shares during the period. 42.35% of the stock is owned by hedge funds and other institutional 
investors.   
About Ryanair
Ryanair Holdings plc, together with its subsidiaries, provides scheduled-passenger airline services in Ireland, the 
United Kingdom, continental Europe, Morocco, and Israel. It also offers various ancillary services, such as non-flight 
scheduled services and Internet-related services; and markets accommodation services and travel insurance 
through its Website, as well as engages in the in-flight sale of beverages, food, and merchandise.

INM’s many ‘persons of interest’ deserve answers from a probe
INM’s many ‘persons of interest’ deserve answers from a probe
Sunday Business Post
April 14, 2018
Copyright 2018 Post Publications Ltd. All Rights Reserved
Length: 597 words
Byline: Post Editors
Body
Jacqueline O’Brien is a senior counsel who represented the Moriarty Tribunal. Jerry Healy also worked as a senior 
counsel for the Moriarty Tribunal. The tribunal’s final report was published in March 2011. According to the report, 
Michael Lowry “delivered” the state’s second mobile phone licence for the businessman Denis O’Brien. Moriarty 
found that O’Brien transferred £447,000 to various Lowry-controlled accounts; arranged for a $50,000 loan for Fine 
Gael (it was returned) and supported Lowry in obtaining a £420,000 bank loan. Both men have rejected the 
tribunal’s findings, but have not formally challenged them in court.
Between 2010 and 2015, Nick Cooper was corporate services director for Cable & Wireless, which has a significant 
stake in the mobile phone business in the Caribbean and is a competitor of Digicel, the telecoms business 
controlled by O’Brien. James Osbourne, who died last year, was a veteran of the Irish boardroom, serving on the 
board of Ryanair and bookseller Eason. He was also a former chairman of Independent News & Media, before 
being ousted at the annual general meeting in 2012. O’Brien, the largest single shareholder, voted against his re-
election.
Karl Brophy is a former INM journalist and executive, who now runs his own public relations firm, Red Flag. He is 
embroiled in a lengthy legal battle with O’Brien over an alleged conspiracy to damage the planned flotation of 
Digicel in 2015. He has strenuously denied the allegations.
Mandy Scott is the executive office manager of Red Flag. She formerly worked as executive personal assistant to 
Gavin O’Reilly, when O’Reilly was chief executive of INM. Writing in this newspaper last week, O’Reilly said that 
Scott, in that role, had “full access to all my emails and files, automatically.”
Joe Webb is a former chief executive of INM’s Irish division, before leaving the company in 2013. Vincent Crowley 
is a former chief executive of INM. He now serves on the board of a number of publicly listed companies. Donal 
Buggy is a former chief financial officer of INM, while Ann Marie Healy and Andrew Donagher also worked with the 
company.
INM’s many ‘persons of interest’ deserve answers from a probe
Brendan O’Connor is a journalist and broadcaster, who is currently deputy editor of the Sunday Independent. 
Maeve Sheehan is a well-regarded journalist with the Sunday Independent. Sam Smyth is an investigative 
journalist, columnist and radio broadcaster, who held a variety of senior roles in INM. He exposed a political scandal 
that led to the resignation of Lowry as a minister, with revelations that businessman Ben Dunne had financed an 
extension to Lowry’s home. Rory Godson is a former journalist, Goldman Sachs adviser and now runs his own 
financial PR consultancy, representing a string of blue chip corporate clients.
This diverse and scattered list of 19 names are united by one thing: an alleged data breach at INM. The Director of 
Corporate Enforcement has stated in an affidavit that the 19 “persons of interest” were the focus of an alleged data 
breach in 2014.
In a statement last week, INM stated: “INM does not know whether any such searches were in fact undertaken or 
for what purpose but based on the limited information currently available to INM it seems possible that they were. 
INM also does not know to whom any results of any such searches might have been provided.”
Tomorrow the ODCE will ask the High Court to appoint inspectors to investigate activities at INM. One part of that 
will be the breach – why it happened, and who the information was shared with. The 19 names deserve answers.
So too the employees at INM, past and present.
Load-Date: April 14, 2018
End of Document
Zacks Investment Research Upgrades Ryanair (RYAAY) to Buy
Zacks Investment Research Upgrades Ryanair (RYAAY) to Buy

https://www.marketbeat.com/logos/ryanair-holdings-plc-logo.jpgZacks Investment Research[1] upgraded shares of 
Ryanair (NASDAQ:RYAAY) from a hold rating to a buy rating in a research report report published on Wednesday 
morning. Zacks Investment Research[2] currently has $138.00 price target on the transportation company's stock.  
According to Zacks, 'Ryanair operates an ultra-low cost, scheduled airline serving short-haul, point-to-point routes 
largely in Europe from its bases in airports across Europe. The company offers over 1,600 scheduled short-haul 
flights per day serving airports largely throughout Europe, with a principal fleet of Boeing 737-800 aircraft. '           
https://bit.ly/potstockwebinar Several other research analysts have also weighed in on the stock. 
BidaskClub raised shares of Ryanair from a buy rating to a strong-buy rating in a research note on Wednesday, 
February 21st. Credit Suisse Group lowered shares of Ryanair from an outperform rating to a neutral rating in a 
research note on Monday, December 18th. ValuEngine[3] raised shares of Ryanair from a hold rating to a buy 
rating in a research note on Friday, February 2nd. UBS raised shares of Ryanair from a neutral rating to a buy 
rating in a research note on Thursday, January 11th. Finally, Sanford C. Bernstein raised shares of Ryanair from an 
underperform rating to a market perform rating in a research note on Monday, January 8th. Two research analysts 
have rated the stock with a sell rating, two have issued a hold rating, five have given a buy rating and one has 
issued a strong buy rating to the company. Ryanair presently has an average rating of Buy and a consensus target 
price of $110.00. Shares of NASDAQ RYAAY[4] opened at $121.37 on Wednesday. The stock has a market 
capitalization of $28,624.00, a PE ratio of 17.59, a price-to-earnings-growth ratio of 0.84 and a beta of 0.64. The 
company has a debt-to-equity ratio of 0.77, a quick ratio of 1.61 and a current ratio of 1.61. Ryanair has a 1 year 
low of $84.75 and a 1 year high of $127.61. Ryanair (NASDAQ:RYAAY) last issued its earnings results on Monday, 
February 5th. The transportation company reported $0.52 earnings per share (EPS) for the quarter, beating the 
consensus estimate of $0.50 by $0.02. The company had revenue of $1.65 billion for the quarter, compared to 
analyst estimates of $1.68 billion. Ryanair had a net margin of 20.99% and a return on equity of 32.17%. analysts 
expect that Ryanair will post 7.29 EPS for the current year.  Ryanair announced that its Board of Directors has 
approved a stock repurchase program on Monday, February 5th that authorizes the company to buyback 
outstanding shares. This buyback authorization authorizes the transportation company to repurchase shares of its 
stock through open market purchases. Stock buyback programs are generally a sign that the company's board 
believes its stock is undervalued.  A number of hedge funds have recently made changes to their positions in 
RYAAY. Shine Investment Advisory Services Inc. raised its holdings in Ryanair by 1,715.1% during the 4th quarter.

IAG snaps up Norwegian Air stake ? BA owner pounces on long-haul disrupter ; ? Move designed to spark 
talks on 'full offer'
IAG snaps up Norwegian Air stake; ? BA owner pounces on long-haul 
disrupter ; ? Move designed to spark talks on 'full offer'
Financial Times (London, England)
April 13, 2018 Friday
Edition 1, 
Copyright 2018 The Financial Times Limited All Rights Reserved
Section: COMPANIES AND MARKETS;NEWS; FRONT PAGE; Pg. 11
Length: 411 words
Byline: RICHARD MILNE ; OSLO MARK ODELL
Body
British Airways owner International Airlines Group is weighing up a takeover offer for Norwegian Air Shuttle after 
acquiring a 4.6 per cent stake in the lowcost carrier that has disrupted Europe's airline industry by launching cheap 
long-haul flights.
IAG said it had bought the stake to start talks with Norwegian, "including the possibility of a full offer" for the airline, 
whose stock leapt on the news. It said no discussions had yet taken place and cautioned that it was not certain to 
make a takeover offer.
IAG has taken advantage of weakness in Norwegian's shares to make its move. The low-cost airline has faced 
increasing questions on its finances as its rapid growth put pressure on costs. It continues to lose money despite 
the fact the rest of the industry is in good shape.
Norwegian said that there had been no talks and that it had only found out about IAG's purchase from the media.
"Norwegian believes that interest from one of the largest international aviation groups demonstrates the 
sustainability and potential of our business model and global growth," it said.
IAG was created from the merger of BA and Spain's Iberia in 2010 as part of a consolidation drive in the European 
industry. Subsequently it bought Aer Lingus of Ireland in 2015.
IAG snaps up Norwegian Air stake ? BA owner pounces on long-haul disrupter ; ? Move designed to spark 
talks on 'full offer'
Norwegian has expanded rapidly, first becoming the number three in European low-cost airlines behind Ryanair 
and easyJet before starting long-haul flights to the US and Asia.
Low-cost carriers have enjoyed success in short-haul markets since Southwest Airlines of the US pioneered the 
approach in the 1970s. But the long-haul market, where costs among the legacy airlines are already low, has 
proved harder to crack.
Some analysts believe Norwegian is succeeding and said IAG would be very interested in its long-haul operations. 
Norwegian's biggest long-haul base is at Gatwick in BA's backyard.
The UK flag carrier, and rivals Lufthansa and Air France-KLM, are responding with their own lower-cost offerings. 
Kenneth Sivertsen, an analyst at Pareto Securities in Oslo, said: "It will be a challenge for carriers like BA to build a 
low-cost long-haul operation, due to a lot of legacy costs. The fit is extremely good between IAG and Norwegian."
Shares in Norwegian closed up 47 per cent yesterday, giving it a market capitalisation of NKr10bn ($1.3bn).
Lex page 10 Analysis page 15
4.6% Stake acquired in the airline, which is a low-cost long-haul pioneer 47% Stock price rise for Norwegian Air 
Shuttle yesterday

British Airways parent IAG eyes offer for rival Norwegian after buying stake
British Airways parent IAG eyes offer for rival Norwegian after buying stake
Financial Times (London, England)
April 13, 2018 Friday
Edition 1, National Edition
Copyright 2018 The Financial Times Limited All Rights Reserved
Section: NEWS; FRONT PAGE; Pg. 1
Length: 385 words
Byline: RICHARD MILNE
Body
British Airways owner International Airlines Group is weighing up a takeover offer for Norwegian Air Shuttle after 
acquiring a 4.6 per cent stake in the low-cost carrier that has disrupted Europe's airline industry by launching cheap 
long-haul flights. IAG said it had bought the stake to start talks with Norwegian, "including the possibility of a full 
offer" for the airline, whose stock leapt on the news. It said no discussions had yet taken place and cautioned that it 
was not certain to make a takeover offer. 
IAG has taken advantage of weakness in Norwegian's shares to make its move. The low-cost airline has faced 
increasing questions on its finances as its rapid growth put pressure on costs. It continues to lose money despite 
the fact the rest of the industry is in good shape. Norwegian said that there had been no talks and that it had only 
found out about IAG's purchase from the media. "Norwegian believes that interest from one of the largest 
international aviation groups demonstrates the sustainability and potential of our business model and global 
growth," it said. IAG was created from the merger of BA and Spain's Iberia in 2010 as part of a consolidation drive 
in the European industry. Subsequently, it bought Aer Lingus of Ireland in 2015. Norwegian has expanded rapidly, 
first becoming the number three in European low-cost airlines behind Ryanair and easyJet before starting long-haul 
flights to the US and Asia. Low-cost carriers have enjoyed success in short-haul markets since Southwest Airlines 
of the US pioneered the approach in the 1970s. But the long-haul market has proved harder to crack. Some 
analysts believe Norwegian is succeeding and said that IAG would be very interested in its long-haul operations. 
Norwegian's biggest long-haul base is at Gatwick in BA's backyard. The UK flag carrier, and rivals Lufthansa and 
Air France-KLM, are responding with their own lower-cost offerings. Kenneth Sivertsen, an analyst at Pareto 
Securities in Oslo, said: "It will be a challenge for carriers like BA to build a low-cost long-haul operation, due to a lot 
British Airways parent IAG eyes offer for rival Norwegian after buying stake
of legacy costs. The fit is extremely good between IAG and Norwegian." Shares in Norwegian closed up 47 per cent 
yesterday, giving it a market capitalisation of NKr10bn ($1.3bn). Lex page 12 Route to long-haul travel page 17
Load-Date: April 12, 2018

Norwegian gives IAG a route to long-haul travel Airlines. Consolidation ; British Airways ' owner eyes possibility 
of a full offer as it takes stake in budget c....
Norwegian gives IAG a route to long-haul travel; Airlines. Consolidation ; 
British Airways' owner eyes possibility of a full offer as it takes stake in 
budget carrier
Financial Times (London, England)
April 13, 2018 Friday
Edition 1, National Edition
Copyright 2018 The Financial Times Limited All Rights Reserved
Section: COMPANIES AND MARKETS;BUSINESS; Pg. 17
Length: 857 words
Byline: PETER CAMPBELL
Body
In the battle for the skies over the Atlantic, International Airlines Group is eyeing another co-pilot.
The owner of British Airways has taken a 4.61 per cent stake in Norwegian Air Shuttle, the low-cost airline that 
launched ultra-cheap US flights from Europe, leading to a scramble among established performers to mimic 
offerings or risk losing passengers. It said that it would "initiate discussions with Norwegian, including the possibility 
of a full offer for Norwegian".
IAG, which also owns Vueling, Aer Lingus and Iberia, brings with it financial muscle to help nurse Norwegian's 
wounds, which include deep losses and a debt mountain of NKr22.3bn ($2.9bn).
But its investment, or even a full takeover, does not solve the Scandinavian carrier's most fundamental problem - 
how to make money flying passengers across the Atlantic for less than £70.
"Unless you have the right business model, deeper pockets only help you fund losses for longer," said Jonathan 
Wober, analyst at CAPA Centre for Aviation.
IAG has timed its approach as its quarry looks to raise badly needed finances to help it deal with increasing levels 
of red ink.
Norwegian gives IAG a route to long-haul travel Airlines. Consolidation ; British Airways ' owner eyes possibility 
of a full offer as it takes stake in budget c....
Last year, Norwegian booked a loss of NKr299m against a profit of NKr1.14bn a year earlier - its third year of losses 
in the past four. Michael O'Leary, chief executive of rival Ryanair, even went as far as to predict last September that 
Norwegian would run out of cash in "four to five months".
The move also comes at a time of consolidation among European airlines, driven by corporate failures as years of 
discounting drive the need for scale.
EasyJet, which recently bought the collapsed airline Air Berlin's operations at Tegel Airport, is vying with Lufthansa 
to buy out Alitalia, which the Italian government is seeking to keep running.
In its brief statement yesterday, IAG offered little insight into the rationale for its move, leaving analysts and industry 
insiders to speculate over the myriad reasons it might want to invest in another low-cost carrier.
BA, which missed out on the low-cost short-haul bonanza in Europe by selling its cut-price Go brand to easyJet, is 
keen to avoid a similar mis-step when it comes to the lucrative long-distance market.
IAG has launched Level, a Spainbased low-cost service offering hand luggage-only flights to the US, but the 
fledgling operation remains a long way behind Norwegian in its share of the budget market.
"Growing that to scale organically is very, very difficult," said Daniel Roeska, an analyst at Bernstein.
IAG may also bring a degree of business restraint to Norwegian, where years of rapid growth have led it to plan 
ventures as varied as domestic flights in Argentina and leasing aircraft to other carriers - on top of operating its 
existing European short-haul network while pioneering long-haul budget travel.
"They have been fighting battles on many fronts for too long," said Mr Wober at CAPA.
The move may also give Norwegian the chance to offload some of the 200 aircraft it ordered in 2012 to other IAG 
brands, Mr Roeska at Bernstein suggested.
Norwegian's strategy of avoiding larger airports and flying "point to point" from cities such as Edinburgh or Dublin 
avoids the costs of the "hub and spoke" model offered by larger performers, but leaves potential customers the 
problem of reaching those secondtier airports.
IAG's network of short-haul flights would offer additional travel options, regardless of whether the businesses merge 
fully.
At the same time, Norwegian has built a formidable presence at Gatwick, rivalling BA's position at the UK's 
secondbiggest airport.
"A partnership that looks to maximise the synergies of the two networks, minimise duplications of capacity and 
investment on key routes, and use IAG's travel management capabilities to improve Norwegian's expertise in this 
area, could all provide some of the benefits of consolidation without the likely high cost of a deal," Mr Roeska wrote 
in a note yesterday.
He believes IAG would be gambling if it bought the airline outright because it has no proof that synergies will work 
and the business can be run profitably.
But the risk in creating synergies now is it drives up the value of the business - making it even more expensive if 
IAG does want a full takeover.
Ultimately, the move brings Norwegian funding at a time when it was looking to raise more capital by selling some 
aircraft and putting its frequent flyer scheme up for sale.
Norwegian gives IAG a route to long-haul travel Airlines. Consolidation ; British Airways ' owner eyes possibility 
of a full offer as it takes stake in budget c....
Stephen Furlong, at Davy Research, said: "Norwegian has been doing in lowcost long-haul what Ryanair did in 
lowcost short-haul. The difference is that Ryanair did it with conservative financial leverage. Norwegian needed a 
partner with muscle. Perhaps this is it."

Financial Times (London, England)
April 13, 2018 Friday
Edition 1, 
Copyright 2018 The Financial Times Limited All Rights Reserved

Body

of a full offer as it takes stake in budget c....

Norwegian /IAG: pioneering for the fjords Twitter : @FTLex Email: lex@ft.com
Norwegian/IAG: pioneering for the fjords; Twitter: @FTLex Email: 
lex@ft.com
Financial Times (London, England)
April 13, 2018 Friday
Edition 1, National Edition
Copyright 2018 The Financial Times Limited All Rights Reserved
Section: EDITORIAL; OPINION; LEADING ARTICLES; Pg. 12
Length: 325 words
Body
International Airlines Group has good strategic reasons for wanting to buy Norwegian Air, the latest pioneer of low-
cost long-haul air travel. The chance to irritate Ryanair merely adds spice. Michael O'Leary, whose rehab from 
motormouth appears a work in progress, said last year he expected Norwegian to go under. Proving him wrong 
might amuse Willie Walsh, chief executive of IAG.
Cynics will suspect that keeping a handle on transatlantic competition would be the main motive for IAG. The 
group's largest airline, British Airways, fought ferociously in its time with Virgin Atlantic and Laker Airways.
The latter, a forerunner of Norwegian, went bust in 1982. Bears think the newbie is flirting with the same fate. Net 
debt of NKr22.3bn ($3bn) at the last record date was 13 times forecast earnings before interest, tax, depreciation 
and amortisation. The short-sellers targeting Norwegian have had their pips squeezed by the 47 per cent rise in the 
shares yesterday.
At this market worth of $1.3bn, the fjords flyer has an enterprise value of $4.3bn. If IAG were to bid successfully at 
this price, the takeout would be at some 19 times 2018 ebitda, according to broker Davy's data. That looks steep, 
given IAG paid 17 times for Aer Lingus in 2015 after lengthy haggles. The multiple should contract to just 9 times 
using a 2019 forecast.
That is a very guessy guesstimate, given the unreliability of Norwegian's earnings. Founder Bjorn Kjos, who owns 
15 or 20 per cent, depending on which database you believe, flies the business by the seat of his pants. Norwegian 
made a NKr300m net loss last year. A rights issue was too small to buffer against any big new reversals.
Norwegian /IAG: pioneering for the fjords Twitter : @FTLex Email: lex@ft.com
Buying a 4.6 per cent stake without warning is a funny way for IAG to make friends. But Norwegian needs hefty 
financial support as much as BA needs to protect its cheerless cross-pond service. Norwegian, blue in mood like 
Monty Python's parrot, might otherwise become an ex-airline.
Load-Date: April 12, 2018
End of Document

lex@ft.com

financial support as much as BA needs to protect its cheerless cross-pond service. Norwegian, blue in mood like

Sam set to leave his Stayers Hurdle rivals in a right spin
Sam set to leave his Stayers Hurdle rivals in a right spin
City A.M.
April 13, 2018 Friday
Edition 1, National Edition
Copyright 2018 City A.M. All Rights Reserved
Section: SPORT; Pg. 36
Length: 285 words
Body
PUNTERS get their last chance to boost the Grand National coffers in tomorrow's Ryanair Stayers Hurdle (4.20pm) 
and this race has been very kind to them over the years.
Big Buck's won it four years running from 2009 to 2012, while no winner has been priced bigger than 5/1 in the past 
decade.
SAM SPINNER was strongly fancied for last month's Stayers' Hurdle at Cheltenham and although he ran 
respectably to finish fifth, the race wasn't really run to suit.
In hindsight, I'm sure Joe Colliver wishes he'd made it more of a test, but the horse will have learned plenty from it 
and Aintree's long home straight should be perfect for him.
Jedd O'Keefe's six-year-old has had a brilliant season, bolting up in a competitive handicap at Haydock before 
landing the Grade One Long Walk Hurdle at Ascot in December.
Ground conditions will be ideal for him and I can see him leading from pillar to post. Anything above 2.2 on 
BETDAQ represents value.
Wholestone is a good horse, but most of his best form has come at Cheltenham, including when third in the 
aforementioned Stayers' Hurdle last time.
There's no reason to suggest he won't handle Aintree - and he'll be fine on the ground - but I'm not sure he's quite 
as classy as Sam Spinner.
The Betway Mersey Novices' Hurdle (2.25pm) is a fascinating contest and at the prices I'm going to take ON THE 
BLIND SIDE to beat Black Op.
Sam set to leave his Stayers Hurdle rivals in a right spin
Nicky Henderson's runner was forced to miss Cheltenham, but that could be a blessing in disguise.
He's unbeaten, handles soft ground and both the track and trip should be ideal.
He will be around the 3.3 mark on BETDAQ which I'd much rather take than the 2.1 about Black Op.
POINTERS TOMORROW On The Blind Side 2.25pm Aintree Sam Spinner 4.20pm Aintree

Alliancebernstein L.P. Trims Position in Ryanair Holdings plc (RYAAY)
Alliancebernstein L.P. Trims Position in Ryanair Holdings plc (RYAAY)
Watchlist News
April 12, 2018 Thursday 8:27 AM EST
Copyright 2018 Newstex LLC All Rights Reserved

Byline: Mark Dietrich
Body
Apr 12, 2018( Watchlist News: http://www.watchlistnews.com/ Delivered by Newstex)  Alliancebernstein L.P. 
decreased its stake in shares of Ryanair Holdings plc (NASDAQ:RYAAY) by 45.1% during the 4th quarter, 
according to the company in its most recent 13F filing with the Securities ...change Commission. The institutional 
investor owned 14,439 shares of the transportation company's stock after selling 11,884 shares during the period. 
Alliancebernstein L.P.'s holdings in Ryanair were worth $1,504,000 at the end of the most recent quarter. 
 A number of other hedge funds and other institutional investors also recently modified their holdings of the stock. 
Bank of Montreal Can raised its holdings in Ryanair by 625.2% during the 4th quarter. Bank of Montreal Can now 
owns 350,215 shares of the transportation company's stock worth $36,489,000 after purchasing an additional 
301,925 shares during the last quarter. AXA bought a new stake in Ryanair during the 3rd quarter worth about 
$35,271,000. Comgest Global Investors S.A.S. increased its stake in shares of Ryanair by 5.9% in the 4th quarter. 
Comgest Global Investors S.A.S. now owns 39,400 shares of the transportation company's stock valued at 
$4,105,000 after acquiring an additional 2,200 shares during the last quarter. Adelphi Capital LLP increased its 
stake in shares of Ryanair by 31.9% in the 4th quarter. Adelphi Capital LLP now owns 611,951 shares of the 
transportation company's stock valued at $63,759,000 after acquiring an additional 147,972 shares during the last 
quarter. Finally, Bank of New York Mellon Corp increased its stake in shares of Ryanair by 14.0% in the 3rd quarter. 
Bank of New York Mellon Corp now owns 135,838 shares of the transportation company's stock valued at 
$14,321,000 after acquiring an additional 16,682 shares during the last quarter. Institutional investors and hedge 
funds own 42.35% of the company's stock. https://bit.ly/potstockwebinar Shares of RYAAY[1] opened at $118.06 on 
Thursday. The company has a debt-to-equity ratio of 0.77, a current ratio of 1.61 and a quick ratio of 1.61. Ryanair 
Holdings plc has a 52-week low of $84.75 and a 52-week high of $127.61. The company has a market capitalization 
of $29,100.33, a P/E ratio of 20.57, a price-to-earnings-growth ratio of 0.85 and a beta of 0.64.  Ryanair 
(NASDAQ:RYAAY) last issued its quarterly earnings data on Monday, February 5th. The transportation company 
reported $0.52 earnings per share (EPS) for the quarter, beating the Thomson Reuters' consensus estimate of 
$0.50 by $0.02. Ryanair had a return on equity of 32.17% and a net margin of 20.99%. The business had revenue 
of $1.65 billion during the quarter, compared to analyst estimates of $1.68 billion. equities analysts forecast that 
Ryanair Holdings plc will post 7.29 EPS for the current year. Ryanair declared that its Board of Directors has 
initiated a stock buyback plan on Monday, February 5th that allows the company to repurchase shares. This 
repurchase authorization allows the transportation company to repurchase shares of its stock through open market 
purchases. Stock repurchase plans are generally a sign that the company's board believes its shares are 
undervalued.  A number of analysts have recently commented on the company. UBS raised Ryanair from a 'neutral' 
Alliancebernstein L.P. Trims Position in Ryanair Holdings plc (RYAAY)
rating to a 'buy' rating in a research note on Thursday, January 11th. Zacks Investment Research[2] raised Ryanair 
from a 'hold' rating to a 'buy' rating and set a $138.00 price target for the company in a research note on 
Wednesday. BidaskClub raised Ryanair from a 'buy' rating to a 'strong-buy' rating in a research note on Saturday, 
March 17th. ValuEngine[3] raised Ryanair from a 'hold' rating to a 'buy' rating in a research note on Friday, 
February 2nd. Finally, Credit Suisse Group cut Ryanair from an 'outperform' rating to a 'neutral' rating in a research 
note on Monday, December 18th. Two investment analysts have rated the stock with a sell rating, two have 
assigned a hold rating, five have given a buy rating and one has assigned a strong buy rating to the stock. Ryanair 
currently has a consensus rating of 'Buy' and a consensus target price of $110.00.           
https://www.watchlistnews.com/alliancebernstein-l-p-trims-position-in-ryanair-holdings-plc-ryaay/2018197.html. 
About Ryanair Ryanair Holdings plc (Ryanair Holdings) is a holding company for Ryanair Limited (Ryanair). Ryanair 
operates an ultra-low fare, scheduled-passenger airline serving short-haul, point-to-point routes between Ireland, 
the United Kingdom, Continental Europe, Morocco and Israel. Ryanair provides various ancillary services and 
engages in other activities connected with its core air passenger service, including non-flight scheduled services, 
Internet-related services, and the in-flight sale of beverages, food and merchandise.Receive News ...tings for

ratings for Ryanair and related companies with MarketBeat.com's FREE daily email newsletter[4]. [ 1]:

American Banking and Market News
April 12, 2018 Thursday
Copyright 2018 American Banking and Market News All Rights Reserved
Length: 782 words
Body
Ryanair logo Alliancebernstein L.P. decreased its stake in shares of  Ryanair Holdings plc (NASDAQ:RYAAY) by 
45.1% during the 4th quarter, according to the company in its most recent 13F filing with the Securities & Exchange 
Commission. The institutional investor  owned 14,439 shares of the transportation company's stock after selling 
11,884 shares during the period. Alliancebernstein L.P.'s holdings in Ryanair were worth $1,504,000 at the end of 
the most recent quarter.

repurchase shares of its stock through open market purchases. Stock  repurchase plans are generally a sign that 
the company's board believes its shares are undervalued.

has a consensus rating of "Buy" and a consensus target price of $110.00. 
About Ryanair
Ryanair Holdings plc (Ryanair Holdings) is a holding company for Ryanair Limited (Ryanair). Ryanair operates an 
ultra-low fare, scheduled-passenger airline serving short-haul, point-to-point routes between Ireland, the United 
Kingdom, Continental Europe, Morocco and Israel. Ryanair provides various ancillary services and engages in 
other activities connected with its core air passenger service, including non-flight scheduled services, Internet-
related services, and the in-flight sale of beverages, food and merchandise.

Tension over Syria weighs on London market LONDON REPORT
Tension over Syria weighs on London market; LONDON REPORT
City A.M.
April 12, 2018 Thursday
Edition 1, National Edition
Copyright 2018 City A.M. All Rights Reserved
Section: FEATURES; Pg. 15
Length: 315 words
Body
RENEWED caution among investors dented Britain's top share index yesterday as Western forces discussed 
possible military action against Syria, although strong results from Tesco pushed its shares higher.
The FTSE 100 was down 0.1 per cent, though it remained near the six-week high it reached on Tuesday after 
several days of gains.
"Western military action against Syria seems imminent - and that is obviously going to lead to lots of worse things 
than yield curves being flattened/leveled entirely if it happens," Rabobank analysts said in a note.
Energy stocks tumbled as crude prices dipped, though escalating tension in the Middle East kept Brent above $70 a 
barrel.
The silver lining was Britain's biggest retailer Tesco , which topped the FTSE 100, jumping 5.6 per cent to a two-
year high after it beat its profit forecast.
"There's less of a threat from Lidl and Aldi and people are gravitating back to things like Tesco," said Paul Mumford, 
fund manager at Cavendish Asset Management, referring to German discount retailers. The escalation of tensions 
over a chemical attack in Syria weighed on travel stocks after air traffic control agency Eurocontrol warned airlines 
to exercise caution in the eastern Mediterranean due to possible air strikes into Syria in the next 72 hours.
Budget airlines Easyjet and Ryanair declined 0.3 and 0.8 per cent, while cruise operator Carnival dropped 1.7 per 
cent and Intercontinental Hotel fell 0.7 per cent.
High dividend-paying consumer staples stocks such as Unilever, Diageo and Reckitt Benckiser, which investors 
usually reach for in times of market stress, all fell. Traders said strengthening pound was clouding the case for 
buying these big exporters which benefit from a weaker sterling/dollar exchange rate.
Tension over Syria weighs on London market LONDON REPORT
Among smaller companies, shares in online fashion retailer Asos dropped eight per cent, hitting more than three-
month low, after results
Graphic
 
Shares in budget airline Easyjet suffered light turbulence yesterday

European ADRs Move Higher in Wednesday Trading
European ADRs Move Higher in Wednesday Trading
MT Newswires Live Briefs
April 11, 2018 Wednesday 11:15 AM EST
Copyright 2018 MT Newswires All Rights Reserved
Length: 219 words
Body
 American depositary receipts of European stocks were trading 0.09% higher at 141.82 on the Bank of New York 
Mellon Europe ADR Index on Wednesday.
In continental Europe, the gainers were led by hotel booking site Trivago (TRVG), up 3.8%, followed by gene 
therapy Cellectis (CLLS), and Deutsche Bank (DB), which climbed 2.1% and 1.6%.
The decliners in continental Europe were led by telecommunications provider Telecom Italia (TI), and 
semiconductor company STMicroelectronics (STM), which were down 3.5% and 1.1% respectively. They were 
followed by brewing company AB InBev (BUD), and pharmaceutical firm Sanofi (SNY), which lost 0.9% and 0.7%.
In the UK and Ireland, the gainers were led by gene therapy company Nightstar (NITE), and biopharmaceutical firm 
Adaptimmune Therapeutics (ADAP), which rose 6.9% and 4.5% respectively. They were followed by 
biopharmaceutical company GW Pharmaceuticals (GWPH), and mining company Randgold Resources (GOLD), 
which were up 2.3% and 2.0%.
The decliners in the UK and Ireland were led by biopharmaceutical firms NuCana (NCNA) and Midatech Pharma 
(MTP), which dropped 13.5% and 5.1% respectively. They were followed by biopharmaceutical company Verona 
Pharma (VRNA), and airline operator Ryanair (RYAAY), which lost 3.7% and 2.3%.

investors on Wednesday. The brokerage currently has a $138.00 price objective on the transportation company's 
stock. Zacks Investment Research[2]'s price target would suggest a potential upside of 15.84% from the company's 
previous close.  According to Zacks, 'Ryanair operates an ultra-low cost, scheduled airline serving short-haul, point-
to-point routes largely in Europe from its bases in airports across Europe. The company offers over 1,600 
scheduled short-haul flights per day serving airports largely throughout Europe, with a principal fleet of Boeing 737-
800 aircraft. '           https://bit.ly/potstockwebinar Other equities research analysts also recently issued research

Zacks Investment Research Upgrades Ryanair ( RYAAY ) to Buy
Zacks Investment Research Upgrades Ryanair (RYAAY) to Buy
American Banking and Market News
April 11, 2018 Wednesday
Copyright 2018 American Banking and Market News All Rights Reserved
Length: 864 words
Body
Ryanair logo Ryanair (NASDAQ:RYAAY) was upgraded by            Zacks Investment Research  from a "hold" 
rating to a "buy" rating in a research note issued to investors on Wednesday. The firm presently has a $138.00 
price objective on the transportation company's stock.            Zacks Investment Research 's price target suggests a 
potential upside of 15.58% from the company's current price.  
According to Zacks, "Ryanair operates an ultra-low cost, scheduled airline serving short-haul, point-to-point routes 
largely in Europe from its bases in airports across Europe. The company offers over 1,600 scheduled short-haul 
flights per day serving airports largely throughout Europe, with a principal fleet of Boeing 737-800 aircraft.   " 
Several other research analysts also recently commented on the company. BidaskClub raised Ryanair from a "buy" 
rating to a "strong-buy" rating in a report on Saturday, March 17th. ValuEngine  raised Ryanair from a "hold" rating 
to a "buy" rating in a report on Friday, February 2nd. UBS raised Ryanair from a "neutral" rating to a "buy" rating in 
a report on Thursday, January 11th. Sanford C. Bernstein raised Ryanair from an "underperform" rating to a 
"market perform" rating in a report on Monday, January 8th. Finally, Credit Suisse Group downgraded Ryanair from 
an "outperform" rating to a "neutral" rating in a report on Monday, December 18th. Two equities research analysts 
have rated the stock with a sell rating, two have given a hold rating, five have given a buy rating and one  has 
assigned  a strong buy rating to the company's stock. The stock presently has an average rating of "Buy" and a 
consensus price target of $110.00. 
Shares of RYAAY  traded down $2.47 on Wednesday, hitting $119.40. The company's stock had a trading volume 
of 72,075 shares, compared to its average volume of 339,689. The company has a market capitalization of 
$29,100.33, a P/E ratio of 20.75, a PEG ratio of 0.85 and a beta of 0.64. The company has a debt-to-equity ratio of 
0.77, a current ratio of 1.61 and a quick ratio of 1.61. Ryanair has a fifty-two week low of $84.75 and a fifty-two 
week high of $127.61.  
Ryanair (NASDAQ:RYAAY) last announced its earnings results on Monday, February 5th. The transportation 
company reported $0.52 EPS for the quarter, topping the consensus estimate of $0.50 by $0.02. The business had 
revenue of $1.65 billion for the quarter, compared to the consensus estimate of $1.68 billion. Ryanair had a return 
on equity of 32.17% and a net margin of 20.99%.  sell-side analysts anticipate that  Ryanair will post 7.29 EPS for 
the current fiscal year.  
Ryanair declared that its board has initiated a stock repurchase program on Monday, February 5th that permits the 
company to buyback  outstanding  shares. This buyback authorization permits the transportation company to buy 
Zacks Investment Research Upgrades Ryanair ( RYAAY ) to Buy
shares of its stock through open market purchases. Shares buyback programs are often an indication that the 
company's board believes its shares are undervalued.  
A number of large investors have recently bought and sold shares of the business. Bank of New York Mellon Corp 
raised its position in shares of  Ryanair by 14.0% during the 3rd quarter. Bank of New York Mellon Corp now owns 
135,838 shares of the transportation company's stock valued at $14,321,000 after acquiring an additional 16,682 
shares during the last quarter.  Great West Life Assurance Co. Can raised its position in shares of  Ryanair by 4.1% 
during the 3rd quarter. Great West Life Assurance Co. Can now owns 26,862 shares of the transportation 
company's stock valued at $2,723,000 after acquiring an additional 1,062 shares during the last quarter.  Legal & 
General Group Plc raised its position in shares of  Ryanair by 5.1% during the 3rd quarter. Legal & General Group 
Plc now owns 71,814 shares of the transportation company's stock valued at $7,570,000 after acquiring an 
additional 3,500 shares during the last quarter.  BRITISH COLUMBIA INVESTMENT MANAGEMENT Corp bought 
a new stake in shares of  Ryanair during the 3rd quarter valued at $362,000.  Finally, Cubist Systematic Strategies 
LLC raised its position in shares of  Ryanair by 52.5% during the 3rd quarter. Cubist Systematic Strategies LLC now 
owns 7,892 shares of the transportation company's stock valued at $832,000 after acquiring an additional 2,718 
shares during the last quarter. 42.35% of the stock is currently owned by hedge funds and other institutional 
investors.  
About Ryanair
Ryanair Holdings plc (Ryanair Holdings) is a holding company for Ryanair Limited (Ryanair). Ryanair operates an 
ultra-low fare, scheduled-passenger airline serving short-haul, point-to-point routes between Ireland, the United 
Kingdom, Continental Europe, Morocco and Israel. Ryanair provides various ancillary services and engages in 
other activities connected with its core air passenger service, including non-flight scheduled services, Internet-
related services, and the in-flight sale of beverages, food and merchandise.

Lufthansa : well grounded Twitter : @FTLex Email: lex@ft.com
Lufthansa: well grounded; Twitter: @FTLex Email: lex@ft.com
Financial Times (London, England)
April 11, 2018 Wednesday
Edition 1, National Edition
Copyright 2018 The Financial Times Limited All Rights Reserved
Section: LETTERS; Pg. 12
Length: 396 words
Body
The notion of a 28-hour working week and hefty pay rises sounds outlandish in Germany, land of punctilious 
productivity. But unions are serious about demanding a bigger share of the country's economic spoils. Volkswagen 
has already made a deal.
Lufthansa, Germany's largest airline, is the latest to be hit by disputes. The strike by airport ground workers is 
directed at the public sector, not Lufthansa. But there is no point flying an aircraft if passengers cannot get off with 
their bags. A one-day strike is not a real threat when Lufthansa is still flying high on its best set of full-year results to 
date. But if the "warning" stoppage turns into longer discord, it will be. Labour battles have dragged on performance 
in the past. A pilot strike in 2014 resulted in a profit warning and sharp share price fall.
Back then, the airline was in the midst of a restructuring drive to cut (EURO)1.5bn in costs and faced intense 
competition from local carriers. The fruits of those savings plus the recent collapse of rivals Monarch, Air Berlin and 
Alitalia puts it in a different position now. Operating profit rose 70 per cent to a record high of almost (EURO)3bn in 
2017 - double that of rival Air France-KLM. A chunky purchase of about half of Air Berlin has increased revenue, 
passenger numbers and capacity. Adjusted operating margins are just over 8 per cent.
Past troubles still hamper valuations. Despite last year's outperformance, Lufthansa is still valued at a discount to 
peers. At the same multiple, shares would be 7 per cent higher than now.
That does not mean 2018 will be a breeze. If discontent worsens, the airline will face pressure on labour costs and 
its pension deficit. Fuel prices have increased by about a quarter in the past year, meaning margins are under 
pressure across the industry.
Lufthansa : well grounded Twitter : @FTLex Email: lex@ft.com
And while Lufthansa cashed in on Air Berlin's woes, so did easyJet and Ryanair. Both have kick-started German 
operations.
That leaves Lufthansa in an awkward position. It expects fuel prices to rise by (EURO)700m this year and has said 
cost cuts will "largely" offset the rise, but not quite. Competition means it cannot raise prices to make up the 
difference.
That suggests earnings before the usual adjustments will be flat this year.
The airline's increased dominance of German airspace will not become clear until this pressure eases. Expect next 
year to be better.
Load-Date: April 10, 2018
End of Document
Lufthansa : well grounded Twitter : @FTLex Email: lex@ft.com
Lufthansa: well grounded; Twitter: @FTLex Email: lex@ft.com
Financial Times (London, England)
April 11, 2018 Wednesday
Edition 1,

Section: LETTERS; Pg. 10

Body
The notion of a 28-hour working week and hefty pay rises sounds outlandish in Germany, land of punctilious 
productivity. But unions are serious about demanding a bigger share of the country's economic spoils. Volkswagen 
has already made a deal.

directed at the public sector, not Lufthansa. But there is no point flying an aircraft if passengers cannot get off with 
their bags. A one-day strike is not a real threat when Lufthansa is still flying high on its best set of full-year results to 
date. But if the "warning" stoppage turns into longer discord, it will be. Labour battles have dragged on performance 
in the past. A pilot strike in 2014 resulted in a profit warning and sharp share price fall.
Back then, the airline was in the midst of a restructuring drive to cut (EURO)1.5bn in costs and faced intense 
competition from local carriers. The fruits of those savings plus the recent collapse of rivals Monarch, Air Berlin and 
Alitalia puts it in a different position now. Operating profit rose 70 per cent to a record high of almost (EURO)3bn in 
2017 - double that of rival Air France-KLM. A chunky purchase of about half of Air Berlin has increased revenue, 
passenger numbers and capacity. Adjusted operating margins are just over 8 per cent.
Past troubles still hamper valuations. Despite last year's outperformance, Lufthansa is still valued at a discount to 
peers. At the same multiple, shares would be 7 per cent higher than now.
That does not mean 2018 will be a breeze. If discontent worsens, the airline will face pressure on labour costs and 
its pension deficit. Fuel prices have increased by about a quarter in the past year, meaning margins are under 
pressure across the industry.
Lufthansa : well grounded Twitter : @FTLex Email: lex@ft.com
And while Lufthansa cashed in on Air Berlin's woes, so did easyJet and Ryanair. Both have kick-started German 
operations.
That leaves Lufthansa in an awkward position. It expects fuel prices to rise by (EURO)700m this year and has said 
cost cuts will "largely" offset the rise, but not quite. Competition means it cannot raise prices to make up the 
difference.
That suggests earnings before the usual adjustments will be flat this year.
The airline's increased dominance of German airspace will not become clear until this pressure eases. Expect next 
year to be better.
Load-Date: April 10, 2018
End of Document
Lufthansa chooses new German CEO for its Austrian Airlines subsidiary
Lufthansa chooses new German CEO for its Austrian Airlines subsidiary
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
April 11, 2018 Wednesday 6:33 PM GMT
Copyright 2018 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 197 words
Byline: Albert Otti in Vienna
Dateline: Vienna (dpa) - 
Body
Alexis von Hoensbroech will become Austrian Airlines' new chief executive in August, the subsidiary of German 
carrier Lufthansa announced Wednesday.
The 47-year-old manager is currently an executive board member at Lufthansa's cargo firm.
He succeeds Kay Kratky, who was likewise installed by Lufthansa to run the Austrian flag carrier. Kratky will leave 
his post upon turning 60.
"Alexis has the perfect know-how to lead Austrian Airlines in the next phase and establish it as a profitable premium 
carrier in the highly competitive Austrian market," said Harry Hohmeister, the senior Lufthansa manager who 
oversees the Swiss and Austrian Airlines subsidiaries.
Austrian Airlines' operating profit jumped 55 per cent to 101 million euros (125 million dollars) last year, thanks to 
the bankruptcies of budget carrier Air Berlin and its Austrian subsidiary Niki.
However, Niki has been re-established as Laudamotion this year, and Ryanair has announced that it plans to take 
over a majority stake of the new airline, to establish strong competition for the Lufthansa group in the German-
speaking market.
Editorial contactsEditing by: Stephen Lowman, +49 30 285231472, <international@dpa.com;
Load-Date: April 12, 2018
Lufthansa chooses new German CEO for its Austrian Airlines subsidiary
End of Document
Lufthansa chooses new German CEO for its Austrian Airlines subsidiary
Lufthansa chooses new German CEO for its Austrian Airlines subsidiary
dpa-AFX International ProFeed
April 11, 2018 Wednesday 6:34 PM GMT
Copyright 2018 dpa-AFX Wirtschaftsnachrichten GmbH All Rights Reserved
Length: 192 words
Body
       VIENNA (dpa-AFX) - Alexis von Hoensbroech will become Austrian Airlines' new chief executive in August, the 
subsidiary of German carrier Lufthansa announced Wednesday.  The 47-year-old manager is currently an executive 
board member at Lufthansa's cargo firm.  He succeeds Kay Kratky, who was likewise installed by Lufthansa to run 
the Austrian flag carrier. Kratky will leave his post upon turning 60.  'Alexis has the perfect know-how to lead 
Austrian Airlines in the next phase and establish it as a profitable premium carrier in the highly competitive Austrian 
market,' said Harry Hohmeister, the senior Lufthansa manager who oversees the Swiss and Austrian Airlines 
subsidiaries.  Austrian Airlines' operating profit jumped 55 per cent to 101 million euros (125 million dollars) last 
year, thanks to the bankruptcies of budget carrier Air Berlin and its Austrian subsidiary Niki.  However, Niki has 
been re-established as Laudamotion this year, and Ryanair has announced that it plans to take over a majority 
stake of the new airline, to establish strong competition for the Lufthansa group in the German-speaking market.

Demand springs back for carriers Steady month saw Emirates cement its position as the A380's largest 
customer, while Hawaiian left the A330-800neo high and dry ....
Demand springs back for carriers; Steady month saw Emirates cement its 
position as the A380's largest customer, while Hawaiian left the A330-800neo 
high and dry after switching its order to rival 787-9
Flight International
April 10, 2018
Copyright 2018 Reed Business Information Ltd. All Rights Reserved
Section: NEWS FOCUS
Length: 536 words
Body
TUI Travel made a commitment for two 737 Max-series aircraft
A fter what was a slow start to 2018 for commercial orders, preliminary information from Flight Fleets Analyzer 
shows that 67 aircraft were added to production backlogs during February, balanced against 12 cancellations and 
seven swaps.
Most notably, Emirates Airline confirmed an order for 20 Airbus A380s, in what was the first firm commitment for the 
widebody type to be made in more than a year. The Gulf carrier – which is by some distance the largest customer 
for the superjumbo – had in January signed a preliminary deal for 20 examples, plus 16 options.
Boeing’s 747-8 programme also received a boost, with UPS Airlines ordering 14 Freighters, along with a further four 
767-300Fs to support its operations. An undisclosed customer also placed an order for three 777s.
This activity meant February was the second busiest month of the previous 12 for widebody deals, and also one of 
the highest-profile due to cancellations. Virgin Atlantic finally dropped its long-dormant order for six A380s – a 
commitment dating back to 2001, while the sole customer for the A330neo’s -800 model, Hawaiian Airlines, axed its 
six-unit order, after signing a letter of intent to instead acquire 787-9s.
In the narrowbody sector, orders were confirmed for 20 re-engined A320neos from as-yet unannounced customers, 
while TUI Travel signed for two 737 Max-series aircraft.
New business for regional aircraft manufacturers included a follow-on order from Bangkok Airways for four ATR 72-
600s, in what was one of the few commercial deals disclosed during February’s Singapore air show.
Fleets Analyzer records the overall commercial order backlog as totalling 15,172 aircraft at the end of February: 
down 40 from the previous month.
Demand springs back for carriers Steady month saw Emirates cement its position as the A380's largest 
customer, while Hawaiian left the A330-800neo high and dry ....
Meanwhile, our information shows that 97 aircraft were delivered to 60 operators during the month – an 18% 
decrease versus February 2017. This extends a sluggish period, following an exceptionally busy conclusion seen 
last December.
European carriers led the way with deliveries, receiving a combined 32 units. This was followed by totals of 29 and 
25, respectively, for operators in the Asia-Pacific and North America regions. Almost half of the global deliveries 
were made to mainline operators.
In the widebody sector, Air Canada, Norwegian and United Airlines each took two 787s, while freight operator 
FedEx received a pair of 767s.
Narrowbody deliveries included eight 737NGs for Ryanair, which has a backlog of 35 of the legacy model and 110 
737 Max 200s. Delta Air Lines took four A321s and two 737-900s, while Southwest Airlines received four 737-800s.
Shipments made to regional operators comprised a pair of ATR 72 twin-turboprops for Mexico’s Aeromar Airlines, 
plus an Embraer 175 and an E190 that were received by KLM Cityhopper.
Fleets Analyzer shows that the global in-service commercial fleet stood at slightly more than 28,600 units at the end 
of February, of which more than 26,000 are deployed in a passenger role. The remainder includes freighters and 
combi types.
Boeing
Note: Information for known customers only
Emirates firmed an order for 20 A380s, in what was the first firm commitment for the widebody type inmore than a 
year

Brussels plans more collective legal power for consumers Corporate scandals
Brussels plans more collective legal power for consumers; Corporate 
scandals
Financial Times (London, England)
April 9, 2018 Monday
Edition 1, National Edition
Copyright 2018 The Financial Times Limited All Rights Reserved
Section: NEWS; Pg. 4
Length: 602 words
Byline: JIM BRUNSDEN
Body
Consumers hit by scandals such as emissions-test cheating by carmakers would get greater powers collectively to 
sue companies that violate their rights, under EU plans that reflect Brussels' frustration with corporaterule breaking.
The European Commission will on Wednesday propose giving consumer groups the right to seek compensation on 
behalf of large numbers of customers, opening up legal avenues that are limited or non-existent in many EU 
countries.
Brussels will also seek to increase the financial penalties for companies that break EU consumer law, saying 
national authorities should be able to levy fines of up to 4 per cent of turnover for "widespread infringements". 
Countries would be free to legislate for higher maximum penalties if they wished.
Vera Jourova, the EU's justice commissioner, said that the plans, which need approval from national governments 
and the European Parliament, would be "a moment for everyone to show their cards whether we are serious in 
drawing the consequences from 'dieselgate' and give a fair chance for compensation to consumers".
Ms Jourova fought Volkswagen , the company at the centre of the dieselgate scandal, over its refusal to 
compensate EU customers despite doing so in the US. The episode, along with others such as Ryanair's mass 
cancellations of flights in 2017, have hardened Brussels' view that the EU lacks the legal armoury to tackle cases 
affecting large numbers of people in multiple countries.
Brussels plans more collective legal power for consumers Corporate scandals
Jean-Claude Juncker, commission president, last year pledged a "new deal for consumers" that would give them 
better protection.
"It cannot be cheap to cheat, especially in the globalised world where the big companies have a huge advantage 
over individual consumers," Ms Jourova said. "We need to level these odds."
Citizens rights' groups have long called for greater collective redress powers, saying EU consumer law is 
underenforced. Only Belgium, Italy, Portugal, Spain and Sweden have well-developed and functioning procedures, 
according to the BEUC, the European consumer organisation . The German government has pledged in its coalition 
agreement to introduce a new system.
"On paper European consumers have rights, but getting them respected when things go wrong is too frequently 
mission impossible," Monique Goyens, the BEUC's director-general, said.
However business leaders said Brussels risked leading the EU towards a USstyle class-action system that would 
encourage frivolous lawsuits in search of payouts. Concern has also been expressed that Brussels was overstating 
the problems consumers faced in upholding their rights. "EU citizens already enjoy the most efficient and strongest 
consumer protection in the world," Markus Beyrer, director-general of BusinessEurope, said.
Ms Jourova said her plans contained safeguards that would protect businesses from spurious cases - notably the 
fact that collective actions would only be open to consumer organisations and other non-profit groups.
"We are not following the US model, but we will make sure EU citizens can fully benefit from their rights," she said. 
"It's not about more business, but about more fairness."
Wednesday's package will also tackle other consumer issues, notably some companies' use of lower-quality 
ingredients in food sold in central and eastern Europe, even when they were branded identically to products 
marketed in the west.
Officials said rules would clarify that it was illegal to market different products as being identical.
Other changes are aimed at the online market, including giving people clearer information about the terms and 
conditions of social media networks .
Graphic
 
Volkswagen refused to compensate EU customers over 'dieselgate'
Load-Date: April 8, 2018
End of Document

New carrier Laudamotion cuts ties with Condor , Thomas Cook
New carrier Laudamotion cuts ties with Condor, Thomas Cook
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
April 9, 2018 Monday 6:40 PM GMT
Copyright 2018 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 199 words
Byline: Albert Otti and Sandra Walder in Vienna
Dateline: Vienna (dpa) - 
Body
New Austrian budget airline Laudamotion said Monday that it is ending its cooperation with travel group Thomas 
Cook and its carrier Condor, amid Ryanair's plans to take over the Vienna-based firm.
British travel firm Thomas Cook and its Germany-based subsidiary Condor had helped to launch Laudamotion by 
marketing the nascent airline's seats on their platforms.
Austrian entrepreneur and former Formula One racer Niki Lauda originally founded the airline under the name Niki 
in 2003 and sold it to the Air Berlin group in 2011.
After Air Berlin's bankruptcy, he bought it back in January and re-established it as Laudamotion with the help of 
Thomas Cook.
However, Lauda presented large Irish carrier Ryanair as an investor only weeks later in March.
Europe's biggest low cost airline said it would buy 24.9 per cent of Vienna-based Laudamotion at first, and would 
expand its stake to 75 per cent as soon as possible, pending approval from the EU market watchdog.
Ryanair chief executive Michael O'Leary sees the investment as a way to expand business in the German-speaking 
market, which is dominated by Lufthansa.
Editorial contactsEditing by: Shane Strowmatt, +49 30 2852 31472, <international@dpa.com;
Load-Date: April 11, 2018
New carrier Laudamotion cuts ties with Condor , Thomas Cook
End of Document

       VIENNA (dpa-AFX) - New Austrian budget airline Laudamotion said Monday that it is ending its cooperation 
with travel group Thomas Cook and its carrier Condor, amid Ryanair's plans to take over the Vienna-based firm.  
British travel firm Thomas Cook and its Germany-based subsidiary Condor had helped to launch Laudamotion by 
marketing the nascent airline's seats on their platforms.  Austrian entrepreneur and former Formula One racer Niki 
Lauda originally founded the airline under the name Niki in 2003 and sold it to the Air Berlin group in 2011.  After Air 
Berlin's bankruptcy, he bought it back in January and re-established it as Laudamotion with the help of Thomas 
Cook.  However, Lauda presented large Irish carrier Ryanair as an investor only weeks later in March.  Europe's 
biggest low cost airline said it would buy 24.9 per cent of Vienna-based Laudamotion at first, and would expand its 
stake to 75 per cent as soon as possible, pending approval from the EU market watchdog.  Ryanair chief executive 
Michael O'Leary sees the investment as a way to expand business in the German-speaking market, which is 
dominated by Lufthansa.   Copyright dpa

(RYAAY)
American Banking and Market News

Body
Ryanair logo Teachers Advisors LLC trimmed its position in shares of  Ryanair Holdings plc (NASDAQ:RYAAY) by 
18.8% in the 4th quarter, according to the company in its most recent disclosure with the SEC. The fund owned 
57,632 shares of the transportation company's stock after selling 13,300 shares during the quarter. Teachers 
Advisors LLC's holdings in Ryanair were worth $6,005,000 at the end of the most recent reporting period.  
Several other hedge funds have also recently added to or reduced their stakes in the business. WCM Investment 
Management CA purchased a new position in shares of  Ryanair in the 4th quarter valued at approximately 
$368,207,000.  Renaissance Technologies LLC raised its position in shares of  Ryanair by 28.6% in the 4th quarter. 
Renaissance Technologies LLC now owns 3,473,819 shares of the transportation company's stock valued at 
$361,937,000 after purchasing an additional 772,300 shares during the last quarter.  AXA purchased a new position 
in shares of  Ryanair in the 3rd quarter valued at approximately $35,271,000.  Lazard Asset Management LLC 
raised its position in shares of  Ryanair by 12.6% in the 4th quarter. Lazard Asset Management LLC now owns 
2,905,702 shares of the transportation company's stock valued at $302,744,000 after purchasing an additional 
325,932 shares during the last quarter.  Finally, Bank of Montreal Can raised its position in shares of  Ryanair by 
625.2% in the 4th quarter. Bank of Montreal Can now owns 350,215 shares of the transportation company's stock 
valued at $36,489,000 after purchasing an additional 301,925 shares during the last quarter. 42.35% of the stock is 
owned by institutional investors and hedge funds.  
RYAAY has been the subject of several research analyst reports. Credit Suisse Group lowered shares of Ryanair 
from an "outperform" rating to a "neutral" rating in a research report on Monday, December 18th. ValuEngine  
lowered shares of Ryanair from a "buy" rating to a "hold" rating in a research report on Friday, December 15th. 
BidaskClub lowered shares of Ryanair from a "hold" rating to a "sell" rating in a research report on Wednesday, 
December 27th. Sanford C. Bernstein raised shares of Ryanair from an "underperform" rating to a "market perform" 
rating in a research report on Monday, January 8th. Finally,            Zacks Investment Research  raised shares of 
Ryanair from a "sell" rating to a "hold" rating in a research report on Thursday, January 25th. Two research analysts 
have rated the stock with a sell rating, three have given a hold rating, four have given a buy rating and one  has 
given a strong buy rating to the stock. The company currently has a consensus rating of "Hold" and an average 
price target of $109.67. 
Shares of NASDAQ RYAAY  opened at $122.26 on Friday. The company has a market cap of $29,109.76, a PE 
ratio of 21.30, a PEG ratio of 0.85 and a beta of 0.64. Ryanair Holdings plc has a 12 month low of $84.75 and a 12 
Teachers Advisors LLC Has $6.01 Million Holdings in Ryanair Holdings plc (RYAAY)
month high of $127.61. The company has a debt-to-equity ratio of 0.77, a quick ratio of 1.61 and a current ratio of 
1.61.  
Ryanair (NASDAQ:RYAAY) last released its quarterly earnings results on Monday, February 5th. The transportation 
company reported $0.52 earnings per share (EPS) for the quarter, beating analysts' consensus estimates of $0.50 
by $0.02. Ryanair had a net margin of 20.99% and a return on equity of 32.17%. The firm had revenue of $1.65 
billion for the quarter, compared to analysts' expectations of $1.68 billion.  analysts forecast that  Ryanair Holdings 
plc will post 7.29 EPS for the current fiscal year.  
Ryanair announced that its board has initiated a share repurchase plan on Monday, February 5th that authorizes 
the company to repurchase  outstanding  shares. This repurchase authorization authorizes the transportation 
company to buy shares of its stock through open market purchases. Shares repurchase plans are generally a sign 
that the company's board believes its shares are undervalued.   
Ryanair Company Profile
Ryanair Holdings plc (Ryanair Holdings) is a holding company for Ryanair Limited (Ryanair). Ryanair operates an 
ultra-low fare, scheduled-passenger airline serving short-haul, point-to-point routes between Ireland, the United 
Kingdom, Continental Europe, Morocco and Israel. Ryanair provides various ancillary services and engages in 
other activities connected with its core air passenger service, including non-flight scheduled services, Internet-
related services, and the in-flight sale of beverages, food and merchandise.

(NASDAQ:RYAAY) has trended somewhat positive on Saturday, Accern Sentiment reports. The research group 
identifies negative and positive press coverage by monitoring more than twenty million news and blog sources. 
Accern ranks coverage of publicly-traded companies on a scale of negative one to one, with scores nearest to one 
being the most favorable. 
Ryanair earned a news sentiment score of 0.18 on Accern's scale. Accern also assigned media headlines about the 
transportation company an impact score of 45.9609970284823 out of 100, meaning that recent press coverage is 
somewhat unlikely to have an effect on the stock's share price in the next several days.  These are some of the 
media headlines that may have effected Accern Sentiment Analysis's analysis:  A number of research firms recently 
weighed in on RYAAY. Zacks Investment Research[1] cut shares of Ryanair from a 'buy' rating to a 'hold' rating in a 
report on Tuesday. BidaskClub upgraded shares of Ryanair from a 'buy' rating to a 'strong-buy' rating in a research 
report on Saturday, March 17th. ValuEngine[2] upgraded shares of Ryanair from a 'hold' rating to a 'buy' rating in a 
research report on Friday, February 2nd. UBS upgraded shares of Ryanair from a 'neutral' rating to a 'buy' rating in 
a research report on Thursday, January 11th. Finally, Sanford C. Bernstein upgraded shares of Ryanair from an 
'underperform' rating to a 'market perform' rating in a research report on Monday, January 8th. Two investment 
analysts have rated the stock with a sell rating, three have assigned a hold rating, four have given a buy rating and 
one has given a strong buy rating to the stock. The company has an average rating of 'Hold' and a consensus 
target price of $109.67.  RYAAY[3] traded down $1.19 on Friday, reaching $122.26. The company had a trading 
volume of 167,630 shares, compared to its average volume of 269,669. The firm has a market capitalization of

$127.61.  Ryanair (NASDAQ:RYAAY) last announced its earnings results on Monday, February 5th. The 
transportation company reported $0.52 earnings per share (EPS) for the quarter, beating the Zacks' consensus 
estimate of $0.50 by $0.02. The firm had revenue of $1.65 billion during the quarter, compared to analyst estimates 
of $1.68 billion. Ryanair had a net margin of 20.99% and a return on equity of 32.17%. equities analysts expect that 
Ryanair will post 7.29 EPS for the current year.  Ryanair declared that its board has authorized a stock buyback

Envestnet Asset Management Inc. Has $2.91 Million Position in Ryanair Holdings plc (RYAAY)

Ryanair logo Envestnet Asset Management Inc. increased its position in shares of  Ryanair Holdings plc 
(NASDAQ:RYAAY) by 131.3% during the fourth quarter, according to its most recent filing with the Securities and 
Exchange Commission. The firm owned 27,974 shares of the transportation company's stock after acquiring an 
additional 15,878 shares during the period. Envestnet Asset Management Inc.'s holdings in Ryanair were worth

last quarter.  Finally, Tower Research Capital LLC TRC bought a new position in shares of  Ryanair in the 4th
