Ryanair takes stake in Lauda's new Austrian airline
Ryanair takes stake in Lauda's new Austrian airline
Associated Press Financial Wire
March 20, 2018 Tuesday 9:03 AM GMT
Copyright 2018 Associated Press All Rights Reserved
Section: BUSINESS NEWS
Length: 131 words
Dateline: BERLIN 
Body
BERLIN (AP) - Budget airline Ryanair says it is taking an initial 24.9 percent stake in an Austrian-based airline 
being set up by former Formula 1 driver Niki Lauda.
It plans to raise its holding to 75 percent.
LaudaMotion is the successor to Niki, long a subsidiary of bankrupt Air Berlin, which Lauda bought back after it fell 
victim to its parent's financial woes. It plans to operate scheduled and charter flights from Germany, Austria and 
Switzerland to largely Mediterranean destinations.
Ryanair said Tuesday that it plans to increase its stake to 75 percent "as soon as possible," subject to European 
Union approval.
It said that the total stake will cost it less than 50 million euros ($61.5 million), but it will invest another 50 million 
euros in startup and initial operating costs.
Load-Date: March 21, 2018
End of Document
Ryanair plans takeover of Niki successor Laudamotion
Ryanair plans takeover of Niki successor Laudamotion
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
March 20, 2018 Tuesday 11:15 AM GMT
Copyright 2018 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 171 words
Byline: Albert Otti in Vienna and Steffen Weyer in Frankfurt
Dateline: Vienna (dpa) - 
Body
Europe's biggest budget airline, Ryanair, said Tuesday that it has agreed to take over 75 per cent of Laudamotion, 
the new air carrier owned by Austrian businessman Niki Lauda.
Dublin-based Ryanair said it would buy 24.9 per cent at first and would expand its stake as soon as possible, 
pending approval from the EU market watchdog.
Laudamotion is the successor of Niki, a former subsidiary of insolvent German budget carrier Air Berlin.
Ryanair said it will pay a sum below 50 million euros (61.5 million dollars) for the 75 per cent, in addition to 50 
million dollars to fund Laudamotion's start-up and operating costs during its first year in business.
In addition, Ryanair will lease six of its aircraft and crews to Laudamotion, which will increase its fleet to 21 aircraft.
Former Formula One champion Lauda founded Niki in 2003. After selling it to the Air Berlin group in 2011, he 
bought it back in January and renamed it Laudamotion.
Editorial contactsEditing by: Niels C Sorrells, +49 30 2852 31472, <international@dpa.com;
Load-Date: March 21, 2018
End of Document
Ryanair plans takeover of Niki successor Laudamotion
Ryanair plans takeover of Niki successor Laudamotion
dpa-AFX International ProFeed
March 20, 2018 Tuesday 11:16 AM GMT
Copyright 2018 dpa-AFX Wirtschaftsnachrichten GmbH All Rights Reserved
Length: 165 words
Body
       VIENNA (dpa-AFX) - Europe's biggest budget airline, Ryanair, said Tuesday that it has agreed to take over 75 
per cent of Laudamotion, the new air carrier owned by Austrian businessman Niki Lauda.  Dublin-based Ryanair 
said it would buy 24.9 per cent at first and would expand its stake as soon as possible, pending approval from the 
EU market watchdog.  Laudamotion is the successor of Niki, a former subsidiary of insolvent German budget carrier 
Air Berlin.  Ryanair said it will pay a sum below 50 million euros (61.5 million dollars) for the 75 per cent, in addition 
to 50 million dollars to fund Laudamotion's start-up and operating costs during its first year in business.  In addition, 
Ryanair will lease six of its aircraft and crews to Laudamotion, which will increase its fleet to 21 aircraft.  Former 
Formula One champion Lauda founded Niki in 2003. After selling it to the Air Berlin group in 2011, he bought it back 
in January and renamed it Laudamotion.   Copyright dpa

(NASDAQ:RYAAY) has been trending somewhat positive this week, Accern Sentiment reports. The research firm 
identifies positive and negative media coverage by monitoring more than 20 million news and blog sources. Accern 
ranks coverage of companies on a scale of negative one to one, with scores nearest to one being the most 
favorable. 
Ryanair earned a daily sentiment score of 0.18 on Accern's scale. Accern also assigned media headlines about the 
transportation company an impact score of 46.1338463771597 out of 100, meaning that recent media coverage is 
somewhat unlikely to have an impact on the company's share price in the next several days.  Here are some of the

Pilots set up a pan-European association to challenge Ryanair
Pilots set up a pan-European association to challenge Ryanair
City A.M.
March 19, 2018 Monday
Edition 1, National Edition
Copyright 2018 City A.M. All Rights Reserved
Section: NEWS; Pg. 14
Length: 95 words
Byline: GRAHAM FAHY
Body
UNIONS representing Ryanair pilots across Europe have signed a deal to cooperate in a move that could raise the 
prospect of coordinated action, something its management has been keen to avoid.
In the agreement signed on Saturday, the unions decided to form a transnational pilot group to negotiate with 
Ryanair at a pan-European level, the European Cockpit Association said. Ryanair is in talks to formalise union 
recognition in several European countries but it has refused requests to engage with pilots on a pan-European 
basis. It did not respond to a request for comment.
Graphic
 
Ryanair averted widespread strikes ahead of Christmas last year
Load-Date: March 19, 2018

You can't fertilise an olive tree with a Goretex coat Letters
You can't fertilise an olive tree with a Goretex coat; Letters
Financial Times (London, England)
March 17, 2018 Saturday
Edition 1, National Edition
Copyright 2018 The Financial Times Limited All Rights Reserved
Section: LETTERS; Pg. 10
Length: 192 words
Body
Sir, Thank you for Charlie Porter's article "Are you fur real?" (Life & Arts, March 10). During the "rather naked than 
fur" episode in the 1990s I bought a second-hand mink coat at the Drouot auctions in Paris for a knockdown price. It 
still serves me well, which is the intention of a good coat in cold winters.
In my student years travelling to Tuscany, I watched how farmers put leftover wool from their sheep around their 
olive trees to fertilise them. My mink coat could do that too. Can you do this with Goretex and plastic sneakers? 
Sabine Liebherr Vevey, Switzerland Sir, Further to Charlie Porter's interesting and thoughtful article on fur (March 
10): we bought a marvellous fur coat for my wife many years ago at a bargain price as a result of the anti-fur 
campaign. On a trip to Milan one February she refused to take it on the grounds that we were flying Ryanair. Taking 
the metro in Milan, she was the only woman in the carriage not wearing a fur coat!
Ian Maitland London SW1, UK MORE LETTERS ON www.FT.COM Gun control in the US; eating curry in Rome 
Four steps to meaningful changes; where to look for Indian restaurants            www.ft.com/letters
Load-Date: March 16, 2018
End of Document

week low of $81.51 and a fifty-two week high of $127.35.  Ryanair (NASDAQ:RYAAY) last posted its quarterly

the quarter, topping the Zacks' consensus estimate of $0.50 by $0.02. The business had revenue of $1.65 billion 
during the quarter, compared to the consensus estimate of $1.68 billion. Ryanair had a return on equity of 32.17% 
and a net margin of 20.99%. analysts anticipate that Ryanair Holdings plc will post 7.25 EPS for the current year.

company to buyback shares. This buyback authorization permits the transportation company to repurchase shares

Hainan Airlines to begin Dublin, Edinburgh flights; Hainan Airlines plans to 
begin Dublin and Edinburgh flights on 12 June with Airbus A330s.
Flight International
March 16, 2018
Copyright 2018 Reed Business Information Ltd. All Rights Reserved

Body
Hainan Airlines plans to begin Dublin and Edinburgh flights on 12 June with Airbus A330s.
The carrier will operate Beijing-Edinburgh-Dublin and Beijing-Dublin-Edinburgh on a twice-weekly basis for each 
service.
Earlier this month, the airline had announced that it will begin thrice-weekly Changsha-London Heathrow services 
on 23 March.
FlightGlobal schedules data shows that the airline will be the only operator on the Beijing-Edinburgh and Beijing-
Dublin routes. It will compete with Aer Lingus and Ryanair on the Edinburgh-Dublin sector.

Ryanair to offer direct contracts to German pilots in next few weeks
Ryanair to offer direct contracts to German pilots in next few weeks
Business World (Digest)
March 15, 2018 Thursday
Copyright 2018 Media World Ltd. All Rights Reserved
Section: WORLD
Length: 245 words
Byline: Business World
Body
Ryanair will offer direct employment contracts within the next few weeks to all pilots in Germany who are currently 
on contracts via an agency, the budget airline said on Thursday.
The Irish carrier has come under fire from unions, especially in Germany, for its practice of employing some pilots 
via third-party agencies, such as McGinley Aviation. The airline last year decided to recognise unions in an attempt 
to improve relations with its pilots and ease a staffing crunch.
"McGinley Aviation have decided to withdraw from supplying contractor pilots for Ryanair in the German market, 
and Ryanair has now begun the process of offering these contractors direct employment," a Ryanair spokeswoman 
said.
McGinley said that after a review of operations, it would cease to provide contractors in Germany from Oct. 31.
"We continue to supply contractor pilots to all other countries in Ryanair's growing European network and look 
forward to a future continued relationship with our customer," a spokeswoman said via email.
Ryanair has so far agreed union recognition deals in Britain and Italy and hopes for similar in Spain by the end of 
the month.
Goodbody analysts said the move to offer direct contracts in Germany should help to ease relations between 
Ryanair management and the German pilots union.
A spokesman for German union Vereinigung Cockpit said it would first have to see the terms of the new direct 
contracts before commenting. (Reuters)
Ryanair to offer direct contracts to German pilots in next few weeks
Source: www.businessworld.ie
Load-Date: April 6, 2018
End of Document
Low-cost airline market to reach $208bn in 2023
Low-cost airline market to reach $208bn in 2023
City A.M.
March 15, 2018 Thursday
Edition 1, National Edition
Copyright 2018 City A.M. All Rights Reserved
Section: NEWS; Pg. 13
Length: 127 words
Byline: ALEXANDRA ROGERS
Body
THE GLOBAL low-cost airlines market is projected to reach $208bn (£149bn) in 2023 thanks to the growth of the 
growth of the travel and tourism sectors.
A report by Allied Market Research said the market was valued at $117bn in 2016 but will grow substantially by 
2023 due to factors such as increased economic activity, ease of travel, travel and tourism industry, urbanisation, 
and a continuing consumer preference for low cost services.
The report also attributed the success of low-cost airlines such as Ryanair and Easyjet to an increase in purchasing 
power of middle-class households and increased e-literacy.
In 2016, there were an estimated 3.8bn global scheduled airline passengers, with 28 per cent of these passengers 
choosing to travel by low cost airlines.
Load-Date: March 15, 2018

Ryanair extends lead as Italy 's biggest carrier Ryanair consolidated its position as Italy 's largest airline by 
growing passenger numbers there more than 10% ....
Ryanair extends lead as Italy's biggest carrier; Ryanair consolidated its 
position as Italy's largest airline by growing passenger numbers there more 
than 10% in 2017, new figures from civil aviation authority ENAC show.
Flight International
March 13, 2018
Copyright 2018 Reed Business Information Ltd. All Rights Reserved
Section: FLIGHTGLOBAL.COM
Length: 378 words
Body
Ryanair consolidated its position as Italy's largest airline by growing passenger numbers there more than 10% in 
2017, new figures from civil aviation authority ENAC show.
The Irish budget carrier transported 36.3 million people in Italy last year, a rise of 11.2%. Alitalia's passenger 
numbers shrank 5.8% to 21.8 million.
EasyJet grew its figure 11% to 16.5 million and remains Italy's third-largest carrier. Vueling's numbers narrowed 
very slightly, by 0.5%, to 5.87 million, but it is still the country's fourth-largest airline, followed by Lufthansa with 4.5 
million.
The ENAC statistics show that Eurowings was the fastest-growing airline in the country last year, with passenger 
numbers rising 330%, from 354,000 to 1.53 million.
Ryanair is also Italy's largest airline in terms of international passengers, having carried more than 25 million in 
2017. EasyJet meanwhile carried 13.7 million and Alitalia 9.61 million.
The Italian flag carrier remains the largest airline in the domestic market, carrying 12.2 million passengers during 
the year, while Ryanair carried 11.1 million and EasyJet 2.83 million.
Ryanair operates the "top" domestic route in Italy, between Rome Fiumicino and Catania, and the main 
international route, which is Rome Ciampino to Stansted, says ENAC, without disclosing figures for the routes.
Italy's largest EU route by passenger numbers was between Rome Fiumicino and Barcelona, with a figure of 1.22 
million. Next is the route from the Italian capital to Amsterdam, with 1.11 million, and Madrid, with 1.09 million.
Ryanair extends lead as Italy 's biggest carrier Ryanair consolidated its position as Italy 's largest airline by 
growing passenger numbers there more than 10% ....
Six of the top 10 routes to EU states from Italy are operated from Rome Fiumicino. Milan Malpensa and Venice are 
also on the list.
The largest non-EU route by passenger numbers is Rome Fiumicino to New York JFK with 688,000, followed by 
Milan Malpensa to New York with 686,000 and Milan Malpensa to Dubai with 660,000.
Rome-Tel Aviv is the next largest non-EU route with 637,000 passengers; Rome-Dubai follows with 622,000.
Fiumicino remains Italy's busiest airport despite declining 1.8% to 40.8 million. Milan Malpensa grew its total 14% to 
22 million. Bergamo grew 6% to 12.2 million.
Total passenger numbers travelling to or within Italy grew 6.2% to 175 million. More than half of that number were 
carried by low-cost carriers.
Load-Date: March 17, 2018
End of Document

How far will US packaging firm go to box off Smurfit Kappa ?
How far will US packaging firm go to box off Smurfit Kappa?
Sunday Business Post
March 10, 2018
Copyright 2018 Post Publications Ltd. All Rights Reserved
Length: 1044 words
Byline: Ian Guider
Highlight: There is a rationale behind the move by International Paper, and though it has been rebuffed, there is 
speculation that a deal could be reached if the price was right, writes Ian Guider 
Body
Before there was CRH, Kerry Group or Ryanair, there was one business that could truly claim to be Ireland’s only 
multinational company. While turning paper into boxes may not have been the sexiest of industries, over the years 
Michael Smurfit transformed the factory he inherited from his father Jefferson into a world leader at a time when 
there were few Irish international success stories.
For decades, Jefferson Smurfit provided Michael Smurfit and his shareholders with enormous wealth. Michael may 
have cashed out when the company was eventually acquired by US private equity giant Madison Dearborn in 2002, 
but still the company bore the family name and his son Tony has since become chief executive.
Is all of that history about to end? Last week, Smurfit Kappa, as the company is now called following its merger over 
a decade ago with Dutch firm Kappa, said that it had been the subject of a takeover approach by the American 
packaging giant International Paper (IP). If the deal is sealed, it will be the largest-ever takeover of an Irish 
company.
Getting to that point, though, will probably cost International Paper a lot more money than it may want to pay. The 
formal approach by International Paper may have happened on St Valentine’s Day, but Smurfit Kappa has been on 
the mind of the Memphis-based company for some time. In April 2015, shares in Smurfit soared on speculation that 
a deal between the two companies might be in the offing.
As analysts at Citigroup wrote at the time, a takeover of Smurfit by IP would be highly complementary. It would 
have faced little regulatory opposition and had the potential to generate huge cost savings. While Smurfit is the 
biggest supplier of boxes in Europe and Latin America, International Paper is the leader in North America.
That bout of takeover speculation followed a $16 billion merger between MWV and RockTenn and ultimately went 
nowhere. (Coincidentally, Citigroup is now acting as one of the financial advisers to Smurfit Kappa.)
How far will US packaging firm go to box off Smurfit Kappa ?
That is, until International Paper made its approach on February 14, a week after Smurfit’s annual results. The two 
sides agreed to a meeting on February 23 at which International Paper executives laid out their proposal and 
presented a letter for Smurfit’s board to consider. The deal would be a mix of cash and shares.
[caption id="attachment_411541" align="alignleft" width="363"] Jefferson Smurfit[/caption]
Smurfit investors would get €22 in cash and 0.3 shares in the new entity. Based on exchange rates at the time it 
would be worth €36.46 a share to Smurfit - a chunky 30 per cent premium to the Irish company’s shares the day 
before International Paper made first contact.
Last Tuesday, Smurfit went public with the news of the approach and called the proposal that had been tabled 
highly opportunistic. Its business was motoring along, with record sales of €8.5 billion last year, and it had solid 
prospects for the next few years.
Its shares soared and continued to gain for most of last week. Although the two public statements from Smurfit have 
clearly rebuffed the American company, word has got around that a deal could still be reached, but at a price well 
above the current proposal, which valued Smurfit at €8.6 billion.
Just how far is International Paper, which is much larger than Smurfit, willing to go to get its hands on the prize? A 
figure of €40 a share has been mooted to get talks under way.
According to Cantor Fitzgerald analyst Will Heffernan the cash portion of the deal will also have to rise to tempt 
shareholders.
“IP’s first offer had approximately 60 per cent in cash. If you apply the same logic to the €40 level, it works out at 
€24 in cash. We do not think this would be sufficient for Smurfit shareholders and expect that IP would have to 
increase the cash element of its proposal.”
A €40 a share offer, though, could still be too low, “considering Smurfit’s growth prospects, solid balance sheet and 
peer and sector multiples”. If it went to €43 a share, with 70 per cent of it cash, Heffernan wrote in a research note, 
“some major Smurfit shareholders would be more comfortable with that. It should be noted some of the top 
shareholders in Smurfit include a US hedge fund and several sovereign wealth funds, whom in our opinion would 
prefer as large a cash component as possible”.
Many analysts think that a price above €40 a share gets a deal done, although Wells Fargo analyst Chris Manuel 
thinks that the current proposal of €36.46 represents an already full offer for shares.
While price might be the biggest gap between Smurfit and International Paper, there is little doubt that the rationale 
still exists. The credit ratings agency Moody’s said that while the deal would boost International Paper’s debt levels, 
it sees “long-term benefits to the potential acquisition, including enhanced geographic diversification and 
operational efficiencies”.
The paper and packaging sector is consolidating quickly. Financial news agency Bloomberg calculated last week 
that 44 deals, including the potential Smurfit one, have been announced in 2018 alone. The wave of deals is 
allowing companies to cut costs and also to capitalise on the boom in online shopping, which is creating extra 
demand for packaging, and to cater for discount retailers who want shelf-ready packaging. All of this is allowing the 
paper companies to grow earnings.
If a deal is ultimately agreed between Smurfit and International Paper, it will mark the end of one of Ireland’s 
corporate legends. Barring the five years when Smurfit was owned by Madison Dearborn, it has been an 
independent company.
The vast majority of its 46,000 staff may well have been located overseas, but this was very much an Irish 
company. There are not too many Irish companies with a market cap north of €8 billion.
How far will US packaging firm go to box off Smurfit Kappa ?
Will International Paper want to keep the Smurfit name over the door? That brand name may hold little sway in 
Tennessee, but it is a name synonymous with Irish business. A little piece of history may be about to end.
€8bn: Market capitalisation of Smurfit Kappa
46k: Number of staff worldwide in the packaging giant
€36: Rounded estimate of the per share value of takeover offer
44: Number of consolidation deals announced in paper and packaging sector so far this year, including Smurfit
Load-Date: March 10, 2018
End of Document
Irish rich listers Considine and Ledbetter back clean air firm
Irish rich listers Considine and Ledbetter back clean air firm
Sunday Business Post
March 10, 2018
Copyright 2018 Post Publications Ltd. All Rights Reserved
Length: 401 words
Byline: Róisín Burke
Highlight: Airmid Healthgroup already has traction in US and Canada 
Body
An anti-allergen company that counts global brands such as Dyson and Siemens among its clients has attracted 
backing from several wealthy business people and is ramping up expansion plans.
Dublin-based Airmid Healthgroup is backed by former aviation businessman Peter Ledbetter and wealthy Clare 
businessman Dominic Considine among other high net worth investors.
Ledbetter worked with Ryanair founder Tony Ryan to help set up Guinness Peat Aviation in the 1980s and was later 
in senior positions at Irish Permanent and Guinness & Mahon.
Considine sold his loyalty firm for €25 million, a substantial chunk of which he netted from the sale.
Founded by immunologist Dr Bruce Mitchell, Airmid has a significant market in the US, Canada and Asia. It is 
launching two new products this year, one globally and one in Ireland.
It was set up almost ten years ago to run tests for companies that made products such as vacuum cleaners, 
bedding and cleaning products, and provide anti-allergen certification for the effectiveness of the claims made for 
their products.
Launched in North America, it was highly successful there, and Airmid went on to develop tests for bacteria, moulds 
and viruses, and added companies in China to its international client list.
Its new global product is a test for bed bugs, which are a huge financial threat for businesses such as the hotel 
industry.
“If you go to a place with a lot of hotels like New York it’s a huge commercial and litigous issue,” said Mitchell. “So 
now we have a rapid test for bed bugs that we would hope to launch in the next six months.
Irish rich listers Considine and Ledbetter back clean air firm
“You’d be amazed at the impact that these kinds of critters can have in hotels, healthcare or dormitories.”
In Ireland Airmid is launching a programme called Health Friendly Air, which it will pitch to big corporates such as 
Google and Facebook and to the healthcare sector, testing for moulds, bacteria or viruses and overall air quality 
and issuing a Health Friendly Air logo where standards are met.
“It would be an Irish thing initially, with Ireland as a starting market,” said Mitchell. “We would plan to roll it out to 
North America.”
Airmid has been profitable for the last five years to the tune of around €250,000 a year, earnings of around €1.5 
million annually, and plans to build substantially on that in coming years.
It is backed by around €600,000, including from wealth funds where Ledbetter and Considine have invested.
Load-Date: March 10, 2018
End of Document
Upping the Ante: Canny punters see beyond the Cheltenham hysteria
Upping the Ante: Canny punters see beyond the Cheltenham hysteria
Sunday Business Post
March 10, 2018
Copyright 2018 Post Publications Ltd. All Rights Reserved
Length: 674 words
Byline: Johnny Ward
Highlight: The bigger festival may get all the hype, but the Midlands National offers attractive prospects 
Body
Cheltenham’s racing festival, taking place this week, is the fourth-largest sporting event in Britain, with a quarter of 
a million people attending.
That figure is swelled greatly by Irish racegoers, who spend more than €22 million at the four-day meet, with 
Ryanair and Aer Lingus boasting excellent business either side of that spend.
A study of Cheltenham’s economic impact carried out by Gloucestershire University showed that Irish people 
bought 57,375 tickets for the 2016 renewal. In this country, it is clear that no racing festival matters more than the 
one that takes place in England’s west country.
Last year, Irish-trained horses accounted for 19 of the 28 winners, a scarcely believable result, considering that in 
2012 there were just five triumphant horses there coming from this island. With Paul Nicholls, once the main British 
trainer, now operating at a much-less relevant level, the expectation is that either Gordon Elliott from Co Meath or 
Co Kilkenny native Willie Mullins will win the trainers’ title at the festival.
It is frequently said that racing’s hegemony is cyclical – yet British racing is suffering because prize-money at the 
lower level remains derisory. This has rendered the notion of owning a horse trained in Britain particularly illogical, 
even in the context of owning a racehorse having never been a pragmatic idea.
Results matter to Horse Racing Ireland, which has been critical to racing getting colossal funding every year, to the 
extent that half of the prize-money over here has been a government donation. British racing has had no such 
comfort.
Results matter to the bookmakers too; they often reference Cheltenham to explain good or bad quarterly results. 
“Cheltenham has a really large bearing on the year,” said a Paddy Power trader. “There is a proper buzz in the 
trading room, though it can get a little tense if results are going awry.”
Upping the Ante: Canny punters see beyond the Cheltenham hysteria
I was sucked into backing horses by going to the pub to watch this meeting for the first time many years ago. There 
is no doubt that backing a winner at the festival can hook you forever, whether you want that or not.
This column has put forward a handful of select wagers at prices ranging from 7/1 to 25/1. Our hopes next week 
rest on Saldier in the Triumph Hurdle, Mall Dini in the Kim Muir, Felix Desjy in the Champion Bumper and Melon (in 
the race to finish second to Buveur D’Air) in the Champion Hurdle.
There are 28 races, and almost limitless betting possibilities. The key for those punting is less in picking the right 
horses and more in dealing with losses. Even the most experienced can lose the head if results are going against 
them – and this is on the Tuesday, with less than a quarter of the festival over.
Even if you have an unprofitable Cheltenham, it is but a dot on the punting map. Indeed, the following day – 
Saturday upcoming – offers another opportunity, perhaps one greater than any available at Cheltenham, the value 
mainly gone after months of ante-post speculation.
Uttoxeter’s Midlands National in six days’ time has a purse (of £125,000) that would not be out of place at the 
Cheltenham Festival. It is a slog of a handicap steeplechase more appealing to certain horses than anything run 
earlier in the week and it tends to be less competitive.
You will hear so much about Cheltenham fever that the Midlands National tends to be ignored amidst the hysteria. 
Yet there is a 20/1 shot available who surely should be less than half those odds.
Back to the Thatch fell when cantering in the Eider last month when sent off 6/1 and Saturday’s race may not be 
much better.
“It was so frustrating,” wrote rider Richard Johnson in his blog. “I felt pretty confident he’d stay the trip and we know 
he goes in the soft ground.”
Given that his options are running out as the summer nears, it was no surprise Johnson mentioned Saturday’s race 
as his next possible engagement. The horse is open to lots of improvement too.
1pt win Back to the Thatch in Midlands National, 20/1 (scale 1-5)
Invested in 2018: 13pts
Profit/Loss: +8.75pts
Still running: 9pts
Load-Date: March 10, 2018
End of Document
Analysts Set Ryanair Holdings plc (RYAAY) Price Target at $109.00
Analysts Set Ryanair Holdings plc (RYAAY) Price Target at $109.00
Transcript Daily
March 10, 2018 Saturday 1:02 AM EST
Copyright 2018 Newstex LLC All Rights Reserved
Length: 864 words
Byline: Casey Walker
Body
Mar 10, 2018( Transcript Daily: https://transcriptdaily.com Delivered by Newstex)  Shares of Ryanair Holdings plc 
(NASDAQ:RYAAY) have received a consensus rating of 'Hold' from the ten research firms that are currently 
covering the stock, MarketBeat Ratings[1] reports. Two investment analysts have rated the stock with a sell rating, 
three have given a hold rating and five have given a buy rating to the company. The average 1 year price objective 
among brokerages that have issued a report on the stock in the last year is $109.00.  A number of research 
analysts recently issued reports on the company. 
Zacks Investment Research[2] upgraded Ryanair from a 'sell' rating to a 'hold' rating in a report on Thursday, 
January 25th. Citigroup assumed coverage on Ryanair in a report on Monday, November 20th. They set a 'buy' 
rating for the company. Sanford C. Bernstein upgraded Ryanair from an 'underperform' rating to a 'market perform' 
rating in a report on Monday, January 8th. BidaskClub downgraded Ryanair from a 'strong-buy' rating to a 'buy' 
rating in a report on Thursday, March 1st. Finally, ValuEngine[3] downgraded Ryanair from a 'buy' rating to a 'hold' 
rating in a report on Friday, December 15th. Several large investors have recently bought and sold shares of the 
stock. Shine Investment Advisory Services Inc. boosted its position in Ryanair by 1,715.1% during the fourth 
quarter. Shine Investment Advisory Services Inc. now owns 962 shares of the transportation company's stock 
valued at $100,000 after purchasing an additional 909 shares during the last quarter. Cornerstone Advisors Inc. 
boosted its position in Ryanair by 1,350.7% during the fourth quarter. Cornerstone Advisors Inc. now owns 1,088 
shares of the transportation company's stock valued at $113,000 after purchasing an additional 1,013 shares during 
the last quarter. US Bancorp DE boosted its position in Ryanair by 168.2% during the fourth quarter. US Bancorp 
DE now owns 1,172 shares of the transportation company's stock valued at $122,000 after purchasing an additional 
735 shares during the last quarter. Assetmark Inc. boosted its position in Ryanair by 64.0% during the fourth 
quarter. Assetmark Inc. now owns 1,322 shares of the transportation company's stock valued at $138,000 after 
purchasing an additional 516 shares during the last quarter. Finally, Tower Research Capital LLC TRC acquired a 
new position in Ryanair during the fourth quarter valued at approximately $148,000. Institutional investors and 
hedge funds own 42.21% of the company's stock.   Shares of Ryanair (RYAAY[4]) traded up $0.52 during trading 
on Tuesday, hitting $123.77. The company's stock had a trading volume of 167,103 shares, compared to its 
average volume of 368,466. Ryanair has a 12 month low of $80.01 and a 12 month high of $127.35. The company 
has a market capitalization of $29,137.19, a P/E ratio of 17.86, a P/E/G ratio of 0.98 and a beta of 0.67. The 
company has a quick ratio of 1.61, a current ratio of 1.61 and a debt-to-equity ratio of 0.77.  Ryanair 
(NASDAQ:RYAAY) last announced its quarterly earnings results on Monday, February 5th. The transportation 
company reported $0.52 earnings per share (EPS) for the quarter, topping the consensus estimate of $0.50 by 
Analysts Set Ryanair Holdings plc (RYAAY) Price Target at $109.00
$0.02. Ryanair had a return on equity of 32.17% and a net margin of 20.99%. The company had revenue of $1.65 
billion during the quarter, compared to the consensus estimate of $1.68 billion. equities research analysts expect 
that Ryanair will post 7.25 EPS for the current fiscal year.  Ryanair declared that its board has initiated a share 
buyback program on Monday, February 5th that permits the company to buyback shares. This buyback 
authorization permits the transportation company to repurchase shares of its stock through open market purchases. 
Stock buyback programs are typically an indication that the company's board believes its shares are undervalued. 
https://transcriptdaily.com/2018/03/10/analysts-set-ryanair-holdings-plc-ryaay-price-target-at-109-00.html. 
About 
Ryanair Ryanair Holdings plc (Ryanair Holdings) is a holding company for Ryanair Limited (Ryanair). Ryanair 
operates an ultra-low fare, scheduled-passenger airline serving short-haul, point-to-point routes between Ireland, 
the United Kingdom, Continental Europe, Morocco and Israel. Ryanair provides various ancillary services and 
engages in other activities connected with its core air passenger service, including non-flight scheduled services, 
Internet-related services, and the in-flight sale of beverages, food and merchandise. Receive News ...tings for 
Ryanair Daily - Enter your email address below to receive a concise daily summary of the latest news and analysts' 
ratings for Ryanair and related companies with MarketBeat.com's FREE daily email newsletter[5]. [ 1]:

Deal: Ryanair recognises pilot union Anpac
Deal: Ryanair recognises pilot union Anpac
City A.M.
March 9, 2018 Friday
Edition 1, National Edition
Copyright 2018 City A.M. All Rights Reserved
Section: NEWS; Pg. 13
Length: 166 words
Byline: PADRAIC HALPIN
Body
RYANAIR signed a deal yesterday recognising Italian pilots union Anpac, its second such agreement in a major 
market amid talks across Europe aimed at averting strike action.
The Irish budget airline halted widespread strikes before Christmas with a shock last-minute decision to recognise 
unions for the first time in its 32-year history. That came after it had to cancel 20,000 flights earlier last year due to a 
shortage of standby pilots.
Pilots in the airline's two largest markets - the UK and Italy - have reached agreement with management. Ryanair 
said this week that it expects to finalise a deal with pilots in its third biggest market in Spain within the next month.
The Italian union said in a statement that the agreement was "historical for Italian pilots", who had engaged for 
years in seeking union recognition together with clear job and salary conditions that are in line with other countries.
Ryanair operates from 86 airports across 34 countries in Europe and North Africa. Reuters
Load-Date: March 9, 2018
End of Document
Tolerance for discomfort can save money on trip to Europe
Tolerance for discomfort can save money on trip to Europe
Associated Press Financial Wire
March 8, 2018 Thursday 1:01 PM GMT
Copyright 2018 Associated Press All Rights Reserved
Section: BUSINESS NEWS; On the Money
Length: 756 words
Byline: By DAVID KOENIG, AP Airlines Writer
Dateline: DALLAS 
Body
DALLAS (AP) - Europe never seems to lose its appeal to American travelers, and the growth of discount airlines 
and alternatives to expensive hotels make visiting the Old World a bit more affordable.
Whether a first-time visitor or making your first trip in many years, travel experts say there are ways you can get to 
Europe for less and make your money go further once you're there.
FLIGHTS
Airfares to Europe this summer are expected to be slightly higher than last year - blame the rise in jet fuel prices - 
but that's an overall, average figure. On some routes, fares are running well below last year's prices.
Average 2018 prices are down 30 percent or more on a handful of popular routes, including New York's JFK Airport 
to Amsterdam; Newark, New Jersey, to Paris; and Chicago to Gatwick Airport outside London, according to travel-
search site Hipmunk.
Discount international airlines including Norwegian Air, WOW Air and tiny Primera Air are or will soon be flying on 
those and many other transatlantic routes. The bigger U.S. and European airlines with more familiar names have 
been forced to match or at least reduce their own fares.
Hipmunk CEO Adam Goldstein suggests looking at routes that didn't even exist a couple years ago because the 
European budget airlines "are often flying between secondary airports on both ends, like Oakland (California) to 
Gatwick."
George Hobica, a travel expert who founded airfarewatchdog.com, said that on the low-cost airlines you might have 
to pay extra for carry-on or checked bags, "but even with bag fees they're way less than in years past."
The bargain carriers get mixed reviews - with a Google search it isn't hard to turn up complaints.
Tolerance for discomfort can save money on trip to Europe
"You have to be honest with yourself about what level of discomfort you're willing to be in for a 10-hour flight" on a 
budget airline, says Lisa Friend, a travel consultant with Rick Steves' Europe, "but for just getting there, they can be 
an excellent introductory price."
If your plans include moving about once you're in Europe, there are cheap flights on budget airlines such as 
Ryanair - again, know what you're getting. If visiting three or more countries, Eurail is offering its discounted 
second-class pass, long a favorite among college students, to people over 27 through March 29. Renting a car may 
be best for visiting small towns, but be prepared for sharply higher gasoline prices than in the U.S., for tolls 
including for driving into congested zones.
Sarah Schlichter, a senior editor at SmarterTravel, also recommends limiting a short trip to one or two destinations. 
Many visitors "try to fit too many places in one trip and they end up spending a lot of money on plane flights or train 
tickets," she says.
LODGING
With many reasonable airfares out there, visitors to Europe are likely to spend a much bigger chunk of their budget 
on lodging. Hotel rates in tourist destinations (and important centers for business travel) such as London and Paris 
are very high.
It can be cheaper to rent an apartment or a house through Airbnb, VRBO and similar services, particularly if you're 
with a family or large group. Plus the kitchen means you can cook for yourself rather than eating every meal in a 
restaurant.
Friend says when she travels to Europe in the summer, especially to expensive cities like London, she often stays 
in dormitory rooms that universities rent out while students are on summer break. "It's a clean, safe, affordable 
room, usually with access to a kitchen," she says.
You could even book a stay at a monastery or farm. If you Google unusual lodging options, Schlichter advises that 
you make sure the place is on a legitimate booking site and has recent reviews (the more the better).
Credit-card offers can help with lodging. Marriott and Hilton have both run promotions with sizable bonuses after 
hitting minimum spending targets. The points cover two or three nights in a hotel, making a week in Europe more 
affordable.
SPENDING
The dollar isn't as strong as it was at this time last year, which will make everything from hotels and meals to 
tchotchkes more expensive.
Travel experts say there are other tricks for stretching your money. Restaurant prices are usually cheaper for lunch 
than dinner, so you can save by making lunch the biggest meal. Research tipping customs where you're going. The 
standard 15 percent to 20 percent in the U.S. might not apply.
Finally, make sure your credit card has no fee on international transactions. And don't exchange currency at the 
airport store fronts; you're likely to get a poor rate.
Load-Date: March 9, 2018
End of Document
ANALYSIS: Airline chiefs disagree on chances of Brexit disruption E The A4E Aviation Summit in early March 
showed that Europe’s biggest airlines can agree on so....
ANALYSIS: Airline chiefs disagree on chances of Brexit disruption;  E The 
A4E Aviation Summit in early March showed that Europe’s biggest airlines 
can agree on some issues, there will always be significant differences 
bubbling beneath the surface.
Flight International
March 8, 2018
Copyright 2018 Reed Business Information Ltd. All Rights Reserved
Section: FLIGHTGLOBAL.COM
Length: 1138 words
Body
The A4E Aviation Summit in early March showed that while Europe’s biggest airlines can agree on some issues, 
there will always be significant differences bubbling beneath the surface.
And if you need a topic to divide opinion, there are few more reliable choices than Brexit.
During a panel session at the Brussels event, the chief executives of Air France-KLM, EasyJet, IAG, Lufthansa and 
Ryanair were happy to agree that a reduction in the scope of open skies – a prospect if the UK fails to agree a new 
aviation deal with the European Union – would be a bad thing.
But stark differences emerged when it came to discussions around the likelihood of the UK's departure from the EU 
disrupting air service – and even the desirability of that happening.
"I think it’s in our interests – not for a long period of time – that aircraft are grounded," says Ryanair chief executive 
Michael O’Leary.
O'Leary, a vocal Remain supporter in the lead-up to the referendum, continues: "It’s only when you get to that stage 
that you’re going to persuade the average British voter that you were lied to in the entire Brexit debate. You were 
promised that you would leave the European Union and everything will stay the same. And the reality is, you leave 
the European Union, and everything will fundamentally change."
Recently appointed EasyJet chief executive Johan Lundgren was quick to jokingly lend his support to the idea of 
Ryanair grounding aircraft.
ANALYSIS: Airline chiefs disagree on chances of Brexit disruption E The A4E Aviation Summit in early March 
showed that Europe’s biggest airlines can agree on so....
But Lufthansa Group chief executive Carsten Spohr agrees with O’Leary regarding the potential for disruption to 
have a positive impact: "In theory, if we could use this industry to prove to the British how wrong their decision was, 
that might even be a good thing."
FAKE NEWS?
IAG chief executive Willie Walsh takes a different view, however. He is confident that a UK-EU agreement on 
aviation will be reached, and even labelled British newspaper the Financial Times the "Fake Times" for a story 
suggesting IAG is not prepared for Brexit.
"I'm a firm believer that this will get resolved,” Walsh states. “There’s no better industry at dealing with disruption 
than ours, [and] there's not a lot that needs to be sorted out."
Walsh was supported in his optimism about a smooth road towards Brexit by Air France-KLM chief executive Jean-
Marc Janaillac. He cites the example of Air France’s experience when an open skies agreement with the USA 
lapsed.
"I don’t believe there will be a problem," Janaillac says. "For example, some years ago, the agreement between 
France and the USA stopped and was not replaced because they didn’t agree, and the flights kept going. They 
found a temporary solution."
He goes on to suggest that there are plenty of precedents for the shape of the UK’s future relationship with the EU.
"We have many examples of different status, like with Norway, like with Switzerland, like with Canada and so on, to 
find a way of settlement between the UK and Europe. So I don’t see any great problem next year."
Asked whether he was concerned about Brexit’s impact on Virgin Atlantic – in which Air France-KLM is finalising a 
31% stake – Janaillac drew laughter by saying: "As for Virgin Atlantic, we rely on negotiations of Willie [Walsh]. We 
are, for once, behind IAG."
Walsh meanwhile expresses confidence that the UK will reach a new air services agreement with the USA. British 
Airways’ home country currently relies on its EU membership for its rights to serve US routes.
"There will be an agreement between the UK and the US. That will be a comprehensive open skies agreement," he 
states. "Anybody who doesn’t believe that is living in cloud cuckoo land.
"The UK government is determined to reach an agreement with the US. The US government is determined to reach 
an agreement with the UK. And that’s what will happen."
OTHER FORCES
Spohr notes, however, that there are forces beyond economic common sense at work when it comes to Brexit.
"In politics, there are things bigger than the economies and industry," he states. "This Brexit, none of us wanted it. 
[But] there is a tough negotiation going on and they all have sharp weapons in their pockets, and aviation is a sharp 
weapon.
"The French and the Germans, who are trying to keep Europe together, surely know that aviation can be used to 
put pressure on the British."
Those "sharp weapons" might be a strict insistence on majority-EU-ownership of airlines in the event of a "hard 
Brexit", or threats to restrict rights to fly between the UK and EU countries, for example.
Lundgren takes a different view to Spoor, however, suggesting disruption would not be in anyone's interests.
ANALYSIS: Airline chiefs disagree on chances of Brexit disruption E The A4E Aviation Summit in early March 
showed that Europe’s biggest airlines can agree on so....
"It would be inconceivable for me that there would be any politicians out there that would want to see planes being 
grounded," Lundgren states. "Everybody, I’m sure, is engaging with everybody to ensure that [a comprehensive 
agreement] happens."
O’Leary was quick to disagree in typically outspoken fashion.
"I think there is going to be a real crisis," O’Leary asserts. "I believe there will be disruption in flights between the 
UK and Europe. I think partly because it is in the German and French interest to push the ownership issue to the 
maximum extent."
Walsh hit back at this, saying "I don’t think it’s an issue that’s in the interests of France". He cites the fact that KLM 
"serves more UK cities than I do" to demonstrate that most stakeholders in Europe would want to avoid a messy, 
point-scoring Brexit.
But O'Leary also suggests that Walsh has his own motives for painting such a positive picture for IAG.
"Willie has to play the game, which is ‘it will all be solved and nice' and 'Theresa May will deliver us a deeper and 
special bloody partnership', which doesn’t mean anything," he says.
This prompted Walsh to further clarify his reasons for his optimism on a smooth Brexit, particularly on the issue of 
IAG’s ownership structure, reminding the audience that he and his company are European, and not British, despite 
its biggest airline being British Airways.
"I’m not British, I'm Irish," Walsh notes. "I work for a Spanish company. I have airlines operating in Spain, France, 
Ireland, the UK. I’ve got a big operation in Poland where we do all of our general support for the business.
"I have a European company. And the EU must be acting in my interests as a European company. And I’m sure 
they will. And the idea that Aer Lingus is not an Irish company or Iberia is not a Spanish company is just a 
nonsense – they are. They clearly are. Aer Lingus is an Irish company; [its] principle place of business is Ireland. It 
services Ireland, [and] it is run from Dublin. Same for Iberia – [it] is Spanish."
But whatever the differences in opinion on how the UK’s departure from the EU will play out, Spohr summed up the 
airline chiefs' sentiment towards Brexit as a concept: "As I said on the morning it happened, as a European I think 
it’s terrible."
Load-Date: March 9, 2018
End of Document
Ryanair announces new acceptance agreement with Discover Global Network
Ryanair announces new acceptance agreement with Discover Global 
Network
MarketLine NewsWire (Formerly Datamonitor)
March 8, 2018 Thursday 12:00 AM GMT
Copyright 2018 MarketLine All Rights Reserved
Section: AUTOMOTIVE, TRANSPORT AND LOGISTICS
Length: 291 words
Highlight: Ryanair has announced a new acceptance agreement with Discover Global Network, providing 
customers, business travellers and corporate travel departments with even more ways to book the lowest fares on 
the Ryanair.com website.
Body
Ryanair will now accept cards that run on the Discover Global Network, which includes Diners Club International 
card users from more than 55 countries worldwide, Discover card members in the United States and global alliance 
partner cards around the world.Ryanair's Chief Marketing Officer Kenny Jacobs said:"We are pleased to announce 
that we now accept Discover Global Network cards providing business and leisure customers with even more ways 
to book the lowest fares on Ryanair.com.Over 1.6 million US customers booked with us in the past 12 months on 
Ryanair's dedicated American website, which enables flight bookings to be made in dollars and now with the 
acceptance of Diners Club and Discover cards and the full range of cards in the Discover Global Network, we are 
making it even easier for our international customers to book their flights."Amy Parsons, Senior Vice President of 
Global Acceptance at Discover said:"We're always working with our partners to provide our cardholders around the 
world with unique features and benefits, which includes acceptance to many of the world's leading travel 
merchants. We're excited that our cardholders will now be able to easily use their cards to book low-cost travel with 
Ryanair."Ryanair customers can now book their business or leisure breaks as far out as March 2019, on even lower 
fares, and enjoy the latest "Always Getting Better" improvements including: Price Promise find a cheaper fare and 
we'll refund the difference + 5 to your My Ryanair account Punctuality Promise 90% of our flights will be on time 
Reduced checked-in bag fees lower 25 fee, bigger 20kg bag allowance Connecting flights at Rome, Milan & Porto 
with more airports to follow Ryanair Rooms with "10% back" Travel Credit
Load-Date: March 27, 2018
End of Document

Virgin revamps transatlantic economy travel Airlines
Virgin revamps transatlantic economy travel; Airlines
Financial Times (London, England)
March 8, 2018 Thursday
Edition 1, 
Copyright 2018 The Financial Times Limited All Rights Reserved
Section: COMPANIES AND MARKETS;BUSINESS; Pg. 14
Length: 344 words
Byline: TANYA POWLEY
Body
Virgin Atlantic is fighting back against the rise of low-cost competitors with its first hand-baggage only ticket for 
those wanting a cheap flight across the Atlantic.
The UK carrier, founded by Richard Branson, yesterday announced plans to launch three new economy fares as it 
looks to defend its position in the market from long-haul budget rivals such as Norwegian Air Shuttle.
Traditional transatlantic carriers are under increasing pressure from lowcost airlines such as Norwegian and 
WestJet, which have disrupted the market for long-haul travel in the way that Ryanair and easyJet have done for 
short-haul in Europe.
Craig Kreeger, chief executive of Virgin Atlantic, said its economy revamp would give it the capability to offer a very 
low fare that would be "intensely competitive."
"We don't feel we need to create a new airline, we feel we can offer a great Virgin experience at a price people 
wouldn't necessarily expect," he said.
Norwegian, in particular, has become a force in the European airline industry over the past few years, bringing 
down the cost of long-haul flying and forcing rivals to respond with their own budget services.
Virgin revamps transatlantic economy travel Airlines
Last year, International Airlines Group, which owns British Airways, launched Level, a low-cost transatlantic brand 
in response to this competition. Last week, the group also announced that, from April, it would introduce a basic 
hand baggage-only fare for transatlantic flights on BA and Iberia, its Spanish airline brand.
Yesterday, Virgin Atlantic outlined plans to compete on similar ground, offering three new economy price tiers: 
"economy delight", "economy classic" and "economy light".
Its most expensive economy ticket - economy delight - will give travellers a more spacious seat with 34 inch 
legroom, priority check-in and boarding as well as advanced seat assignment. Its cheapest ticket - economy light - 
will see seats assigned at check-in and no checked luggage. Seats will be packed closer together with 31 inch 
legroom. All flyers will continue to get inclusive food and drink and in-flight entertainment.
Load-Date: March 7, 2018
End of Document
Virgin Atlantic takes US flight fight to rivals with fare for hand baggage only
Virgin Atlantic takes US flight fight to rivals with fare for hand baggage only
Financial Times (London, England)
March 8, 2018 Thursday
Edition 1, National Edition
Copyright 2018 The Financial Times Limited All Rights Reserved
Section: COMPANIES AND MARKETS;BUSINESS; Pg. 15
Length: 323 words
Byline: TANYA POWLEY
Body
Virgin Atlantic is fighting back against the rise of low-cost competitors with its first hand-baggage-only ticket for 
those wanting a cheap flight across the Atlantic.
The UK carrier, founded by Richard Branson, yesterday announced plans to launch three new economy fares as it 
looks to defend its position from longhaul budget rivals such as Norwegian Air Shuttle.
Traditional transatlantic carriers are under pressure from low-cost airlines such as Norwegian and WestJet, which 
have disrupted the market for long-haul travel in the way that Ryanair and easyJet have for short-haul in Europe.
Craig Kreeger, chief executive of Virgin Atlantic, said its economy revamp would give it the capability to offer a very 
low fare that would be "intensely competitive".
"We don't feel we need to create a new airline, we feel we can offer a great Virgin experience at a price people 
wouldn't necessarily expect," he said.
Norwegian has become a force in the European industry over the past few years, bringing down the cost of 
longhaul flying and forcing rivals to respond with their own budget services.
Last year, International Airlines Group, which owns British Airways, launched Level, a low-cost transatlantic brand. 
Last week, the group announced that, from April, it would introduce a basic hand-baggage-only fare for transatlantic 
flights on BA and Iberia, its Spanish brand. Yesterday Virgin Atlantic outlined plans to compete on similar ground, 
Virgin Atlantic takes US flight fight to rivals with fare for hand baggage only
offering three new economy price tiers: "economy delight", "economy classic" and "economy light". Once a 
trailblazer, Virgin Atlantic has struggled over the past decade. Its fortunes were rescued by its venture with Delta, 
the US carrier, which took a 49 per cent stake in the company in 2012.
In a further shake-up in July, Virgin Atlantic announced that Air France-KLM was buying a 31 per cent stake in the 
airline as part of a plan to create "the most comprehensive transatlantic route network".
Load-Date: March 7, 2018
End of Document
Ryanair signs deal recognising Italy pilots union

Copyright 2018 Media World Ltd. All Rights Reserved

Ryanair signed a deal on Thursday recognising Italian pilots union ANPAC as part of talks across Europe aimed at 
averting strike action.
Pilots in two of the airline's largest markets - Britain and Italy - have reached agreement with management. The 
Irish budget airline said the two markets represent more than 45% of its pilots.
"This agreement validates the decision in December to recognise unions. We are making good progress with 
unions in other major EU countries and we hope to sign more recognition deals with pilots and cabin crew unions 
over the coming weeks and months," Chief People Officer Eddie Wilson said in a statement. &#8203; (Reuters)

Aer Lingus owner IAG confident of post-Brexit flying rights
Aer Lingus owner IAG confident of post-Brexit flying rights
Business World (Digest)
March 07, 2018 Wednesday
Copyright 2018 Media World Ltd. All Rights Reserved
Section: IRELAND
Length: 330 words
Byline: Business World
Body
The chief executive of Aer Lingus-owner IAG is confident a deal will be done to secure Britain's flying rights after 
Brexit, he said on Tuesday, dismissing a recent media report and a rival airline's prediction of disruption.
IAG's Willie Walsh told the Airlines For Europe conference that he expects Britain to secure deals to allow planes to 
keep flying and that he is relaxed about Brexit.
"I am a firm believer that this will get resolved," Walsh said on a panel.
He dismissed a report in Britain's Financial Times newspaper on Tuesday that said the United States had offered 
Britain a worse deal than it has under the EU-U.S. Open Skies agreement.
"The people who are involved in the negotiations say we're going to get a deal," Walsh said.
"There will be a comprehensive Open Skies agreement. Anyone who doesn't believe that is living in cloud cuckoo 
land."
Ryanair's chief executive was less optimistic, however, saying he expects disruption to flights between Britain and 
the rest of Europe in the immediate aftermath of Britain's planned exit from the European Union on March 29 next 
year.
"I think there will be a real crisis in April 2019. I believe there will be disruption to flights between the UK and 
Europe," Michael O'Leary told the conference.
Aer Lingus owner IAG confident of post-Brexit flying rights
After Brexit, British airlines want to be able to continue to benefit from EU flying rights and the British government 
has said it will try to secure an open-access deal.
Flying rights to, from and within the European Union, as well as between the United States and Britain, are currently 
covered by EU-wide Open Skies agreements.
Britain needs to agree new deals because, without membership of the EU, the country's aviation sector does not 
have a natural fallback arrangement that will keep airlines flying.
Lufthansa CEO Carsten Spohr said on the sidelines of the conference that he expected a longer transition period 
would be needed because of complexities of the overall Brexit process. (Reuters)
Source: www.businessworld.ie

EU will aim to avoid 'absurd' flight disruption after Brexit E The European Union will seek to avoid the 
"particularly absurd" prospect of flights between the c....
EU will aim to avoid 'absurd' flight disruption after Brexit;  E The European 
Union will seek to avoid the "particularly absurd" prospect of flights 
between the continental bloc and the UK being disrupted as a result of 
Brexit, European Council president Donald Tusk says.
Flight International
March 7, 2018
Copyright 2018 Reed Business Information Ltd. All Rights Reserved
Section: FLIGHTGLOBAL.COM
Length: 299 words
Body
The European Union will use upcoming trade talks with the UK to seek to avoid the "particularly absurd" prospect of 
flights between the two blocs being disrupted following Brexit, European Council president Donald Tusk says.
In a speech today laying out the European Union’s negotiating stance in upcoming trade talks with the UK, Tusk 
says that the two parties "must start discussions on this [flight disruption] issue as soon as possible".
Ryanair chief executive Michael O’Leary has previously warned that a ‘hard’ Brexit could result in a temporary 
disruption of flights between the UK and EU – a scenario which the European Commission’s director-general for 
Mobility and Transport Henrik Hololei told FlightGlobal on 6 March was not "impossible" to envisage.
Tusk says that as a result of the UK government’s plan to leave the EU’s single market, the customs union and the 
jurisdiction of European Court of Justice, this left the option of seeking to conclude a trade agreement with the UK 
"covering all sectors and with zero tariffs on goods".
The EU will also require an air transport agreement, combined with an aviation safety agreement, to ensure a 
"strong level playing field in a highly competitive sector".
In a joint statement airport associations ACI Europe and the AOA welcomed the comments "This charts the way 
forward for the future aviation relationship and thus potentially reduces uncertainty for our sector," it says.
"We call both on EU27 and UK negotiators to seek a future agreement that mirrors as closely as possible today’s 
arrangements. We note that the draft EU guidelines do not consider the rights of UK airlines to keep flying within the 
EU27 nor the right of EU27 airlines to keep flying within the UK, as a result of the UK leaving the single aviation 
market," they add.
EU will aim to avoid 'absurd' flight disruption after Brexit E The European Union will seek to avoid the 
"particularly absurd" prospect of flights between the c....
Load-Date: March 7, 2018

Ryanair braced for Easter and summer trouble
Ryanair braced for Easter and summer trouble
City A.M.
March 7, 2018 Wednesday
Edition 1, National Edition
Copyright 2018 City A.M. All Rights Reserved
Section: NEWS; Pg. 14
Length: 271 words
Byline: REBECCA SMITH
Body
LOW-COST carrier Ryanair is braced for some flight disruption over Easter and potentially over the summer months 
as it aims to press on with union negotiationss.
The airline's chief executive Michael O'Leary told a news conference yesterday he expected some impact on flights 
- specifically into and out of Ireland and Portugal - as Ryanair hashes out the details of union recognition and how it 
will work with pilot unions.
"We are very close to concluding agreements in Spain and Italy and expect them to be finalised within the next 
month," Reuters reported O'Leary telling the news conference in Brussels.
"We're not making as much progress in other countries, most notably Ireland, and in Portugal. We expect some 
disruptions, possibly over Easter, maybe over the summer period," he said.
Last year, Ryanair cancelled a raft of flights in September when it faced pilot rostering troubles, with a number of 
routes then suspended. The airline managed to quell a threat of strikes over the festive period, agreeing to 
recognise unions. In January, it struck a deal to recognise the British Airline Pilots Association as the sole 
representative body for Ryanair pilots in the UK.
And at the beginning of the year, Ryanair said pilots across all 15 of its UK bases had accepted a pay rise. The 
airline said pilots had voted in a secret ballot to back pay increases of up to 20 per cent.
However, last month, O'Leary faced a call from pilot group the European Employee Representative Council (EERC) 
calling on him to resign.
Ryanair braced for Easter and summer trouble
Ryanair though said the EERC has "no legal standing or validity".
Ryanair has been in talks to recognise unions

Ryanair introduces new environmental policy
Ryanair introduces new environmental policy
MarketLine NewsWire (Formerly Datamonitor)
March 7, 2018 Wednesday 12:00 AM GMT
Copyright 2018 MarketLine All Rights Reserved
Section: AUTOMOTIVE, TRANSPORT AND LOGISTICS
Length: 247 words
Highlight: Ryanair, Europe's greenest airline, has launched a new Environmental Policy, which commits to 
ambitious future environmental targets building on impressive achievements to date, including commitments to 
address climate change, and the priorities and policies which will allow Ryanair to continue to lower CO2 emissions 
and noise pollution.
Body
This Environmental Policy illustrates Ryanair's commitment to managing its impact on the environment by: Leading 
the way as Europe's greenest, cleanest airline Committing to ambitious environmental targets Investing billions in 
the newest, most fuel efficient aircraft Committing to eliminate all non-recyclable plastics within 5 years Allowing 
customers to offset the carbon cost of their flightsRyanair's Kenny Jacobs said:"As Europe's greenest airline, we 
are pleased to launch our Environmental Policy, a blueprint for our achievements to date and future targets. 
Operating the youngest fleet in Europe, high load factors and efficient fuel burn, has enabled us to continuously 
lower our CO2 emissions to become the greenest airline in Europe. 
Furthermore, customers can now offset the carbon cost of their flight by making a voluntary donation to a climate 
charity at the end of the booking process, and we have committed to going plastic free across our operations over 
the next five years."Ryanair's COO Peter Bellew said:"We are pleased to launch our Environmental Policy, which 
cements our commitment to continuously improving the carbon efficiency of our operations. By minimising fuel and 
energy consumption, reducing noise pollution and relentlessly supporting global emissions targets, we will play our 
part in addressing climate change. We will lead the way through these initiatives, and our progress will be published 
annually on our website and in our annual report."

Ryanair Warns Of Strikes As Airlines Fill Gap Left By Air Berlin
Ryanair Warns Of Strikes As Airlines Fill Gap Left By Air Berlin
Live Briefs PRO Global Markets
March 6, 2018 Tuesday 1:06 PM EST
Copyright 2018 MT Newswires All Rights Reserved
Length: 211 words
Body
 Irish budget airline Ryanair's marketing director warned on Tuesday that unions may disrupt their move to fill the 
gap in the market left by insolvent flight company Air Berlin.
"When you now have unions and you have union recognition, you can have some disruption," said Kenny Jacobs at 
a press conference in Berlin.
"We haven't had that yet, but we are saying it can happen at some point in the future."
Ryanair is planning to expand the number of services it runs to and from German airports from 24 to 243 by next 
winter.
This year the company aims to see a 13% increase of passengers flying from German airports, with the total rising 
to 19.7 million.
The airline's chief executive Michael O'Leary is due to meet German aviation union Vereinigung Cockpit.
In December, Ryanair agreed to recognize pilot unions for the first time as part of efforts to avoid planned strike 
action during the Christmas holiday season.
Various European budget airlines have made overtures to fill the gap left by the dissolution of German flight 
company Air Berlin after it stopped trading last October.
According to Lufthansa sister company Eurowings' own information, the firm plans to roll its service out with another 
70,000 flights carrying an additional 8 million passengers this year.

Ryanair Warns Of Strikes As Airlines Fill Gap Left By Air Berlin

Michael O'Leary says Aer Lingus connection deal a model for future cooperation
Michael O'Leary says Aer Lingus connection deal a model for future 
cooperation
Business World (Digest)
March 06, 2018 Tuesday
Copyright 2018 Media World Ltd. All Rights Reserved
Section: WORLD
Length: 239 words
Byline: Business World
Body
A connection deal between Ryanair and IAG's Aer Lingus could serve as a model for future cooperation between 
Europe's largest low-cost airline and long-haul carriers, Ryanair chief executive Michael O'Leary said on Tuesday.
Ryanair and Aer Lingus have signed a co-operation agreement to offer connecting flights on each other's services, 
Aer Lingus's CEO was quoted as saying on Sunday.
"I would hope that at some stage next summer, you will see us feeding Aer Lingus' transatlantic flights out of Dublin, 
and once we've done it once, I think we will provide a significant feed to lots of long-haul airlines," O'Leary told a 
news conference in Brussels.
O'Leary said there were still some issues to be resolved for the deal to go into force with Aer Lingus, especially 
finding a solution to using different reservation systems.
While transatlantic routes are among the industry's most popular and profitable, short-haul routes within Europe are 
often less attractive to operate as low-cost competition depresses ticket prices.
In response, airlines such as Lufthansa have established their own no-frills brands to reduce the cost of short-haul 
routes.
O'Leary said Ryanair was already in talks with other airlines to introduce connection deals.
"We're in talks with lots of other airlines about feeds," O'Leary said.
Michael O'Leary says Aer Lingus connection deal a model for future cooperation
Talks between Ryanair and Norwegian Air Shuttle on a similar agreement failed last year. (Reuters)
Source: www.businessworld.ie
Load-Date: March 26, 2018

Ryanair predicts Easter and summer disruption as union talks drag
Ryanair predicts Easter and summer disruption as union talks drag
Business World (Digest)
March 06, 2018 Tuesday
Copyright 2018 Media World Ltd. All Rights Reserved
Section: GENERAL
Length: 237 words
Byline: Robert McHugh
Body
Ryanair expects some disruption to flights in the coming months, notably into and out of Ireland and Portugal, as it 
discusses union recognition and working with pilot unions, chief executive Michael O'Leary said on Tuesday.
The airline averted widespread strikes ahead of Christmas by announcing plans to recognise pilots' unions for the 
first time in its 32-year history and is talking with unions across Europe on formal recognition.
"We are very close to concluding agreements in Spain and Italy and expect them to be finalised within the next 
month," O'Leary told a news conference in Brussels.
"We're not making as much progress in other countries, most notably Ireland and in Portugal. We expect some 
disruptions, possibly over Easter, maybe over the summer period," he said.
Chief Operations Officer Peter Bellew said at a separate news conference in Berlin that Ryanair expected to 
achieve a collective wage agreement in Germany over the coming months.
A meeting has been scheduled with German pilots' union Vereinigung Cockpit (VC) for next week, he said.
The union had called the first-ever pilots strike at Ryanair in December, saying it did not believe Ryanair was 
serious about negotiating with unions.
Ryanair has not yet sought similar collective agreements with staff other than pilots, though Bellew said there had 
been some early discussions with unions representing cabin crew. (Reuters)

Brexit situation 'stark' but UK could remain in EU: Ryanair chief; Ryanair chief executive Michael O'Leary today 
acknowledged a "somewhat stark" situation as th....
Brexit situation 'stark' but UK could remain in EU: Ryanair chief; Ryanair 
chief executive Michael O'Leary today acknowledged a "somewhat stark" 
situation as the UK moves towards its exit from the European Union, and 
highlighted that the Irish carrier's ownership structure would need to be 
addressed in the event of a "hard Brexit".
Flight International
March 6, 2018
Copyright 2018 Reed Business Information Ltd. All Rights Reserved
Section: FLIGHTGLOBAL.COM
Length: 307 words
Body
Ryanair chief executive Michael O'Leary today acknowledged a "somewhat stark" situation as the UK moves 
towards its exit from the European Union, and highlighted that the Irish carrier's ownership structure would need to 
be addressed in the event of a "hard Brexit".
Speaking in Brussels as the airline launched several Belgian routes, O'Leary said: "It appears to me that the 
Europeans, on the prompting of the Germans and the French, will insist on a strict application of the ownership 
rules."
He notes that "about 60-65%" of Ryanair's shareholding would be non-EU after a hard Brexit.
In such an outcome – where the UK effectively becomes a third-party state with no continuing access to the EU's 
common aviation area – majority UK-owned airlines would theoretically lose the right to serve EU destinations.
Ryanair would be faced with two options, O'Leary suggests: it could restrict the voting rights of its non-EU 
shareholders, or it could force them to sell their shares.
"We won't know until we get much closer to the date of the eventual Brexit termination," O'Leary adds.
The UK government has insisted it wants to retain a close aviation relationship with the EU post-Brexit and stated 
there will be no disruption to services. As with most issues relating to the UK's exit from the EU, however, detailed 
plans either do not exist or are being kept under wraps during the negotiation process.
Brexit situation 'stark' but UK could remain in EU: Ryanair chief; Ryanair chief executive Michael O'Leary today 
acknowledged a "somewhat stark" situation as th....
O'Leary describes Brexit as "the stupidest idea known to humankind – the first time in history people have voted to 
get poorer or be less well off, despite the rantings of the Daily Mail and some of those other people". He believes 
the UK's decision to leave the EU could still be reversed, however.
"I think there's a real prospect that the closer we get to the real Brexit termination that people in the UK will 
reconsider their position," he says.
Load-Date: March 6, 2018
End of Document
A quiet Neo year for orders; 2018 got off to a sedate start, with sales covering only a handful of narrowbodies 
and no widebodies , while deliveries also slippe....
A quiet Neo year for orders; 2018 got off to a sedate start, with sales 
covering only a handful of narrowbodies and no widebodies , while 
deliveries also slipped sharply from last December's peak in activity
Flight International
March 6, 2018
Copyright 2018 Reed Business Information Ltd. All Rights Reserved
Section: NEWS FOCUS
Length: 585 words
Body
After an exceptionally busy December for firm commitments, preliminary figures from Flight Fleets Analyzer show 
that 2018 began with a relatively quiet start in terms of commercial aircraft orders.
Manufacturers logged a total of 37 net orders in January: 27 more than the 10 units recorded in the same month a 
year earlier. The new commitments were headed by China Aircraft Leasing (CALC), which placed an order for 15 
Airbus A320neo-family aircraft, with Nordic Aviation Capital signing for the same total number of airframes, split 
between 12 ATR 42s and three ATR 72s.
The order from CALC was the only narrowbody deal recorded for the month in Fleets Analyzer figures, with the 15-
unit total again beating last year’s January performance of just seven single-aisles. Last December, the lessor took 
delivery of its first A320neo, with the twinjet now in use with US carrier Frontier Airlines.
No commercial order activity occurred in the widebody sector during January, making it the first monthly dry spell 
for orders in that category since August 2017.
In the regional sector, Nordic Aviation Capital’s ATR buy was boosted by aerial firefighting firm Conair’s order for six 
new-build Bombardier Q400s that will be used as multirole aerial firefighting aircraft. Toronto-based Longview 
Aviation Asset Management ordered a single Viking Air Series 400 Twin Otter.
At the end of January, the overall commercial aircraft order backlog stood at 15,212; down 21 from the previous 
month.
Fleets Analyzer information shows that 78 commercial aircraft were delivered in January, four fewer than during the 
same month in 2017. The reduced volume of shipments also represented the lowest total from within the last 13 
months, with 2018’s slow start following a record year for both Airbus and Boeing.
A quiet Neo year for orders; 2018 got off to a sedate start, with sales covering only a handful of narrowbodies 
and no widebodies , while deliveries also slippe....
Operators in the Asia-Pacific region accounted for 29 of the aircraft shipped during the month, while mainline 
operations represented more than half of the deliveries made.
There were 51 narrowbody and 19 widebody aircraft delivered in January, while regional jets and turboprops 
accounted for five and three units, respectively. Ryanair took delivery of six Boeing 737NGs, boosting its fleet of the 
type to more than 420 units. Southwest Airlines and Xiamen Airlines also took three 737NGs each, while Batik Air 
and Saudia each received three A320ceos.
Deliveries in the widebody sector for January included two 777s received by Air India, a pair of A350s taken by Thai 
Airways and two 787s shipped to United Airlines.
Regional deliveries included Aeroflot receiving a trio of Sukhoi Superjet 100s, and both KLM Cityhopper and 
SkyWest Airlines taking a single Embraer 175. Longview Aviation Asset Management received two Twin Otters, 
while a single ATR 72 was shipped to Alliance Air.
Fleets Analyzer data shows that the global in-service commercial fleet is approaching the 28,500 unit mark. More 
than 26,000 of this total are aircraft deployed in a passenger role, with the remainder being used for 
cargo operations.
Narrowbody aircraft are gradually expanding their overall share of the active fleet, now accounting for nearly 55% of 
the commercial in-service aircraft.
The fleet operated by carriers in the Asia-Pacific region accounts for 30% of the global in-service total, with 8,610 
units – now 170 more than the North American-based inventory, which had been the largest until late last year.
CALC has ordered 15 more A320neos after leasing its first of the type to Frontier Airlines
Airbus
Source: Flight Fleets Analyzer
Load-Date: March 6, 2018
End of Document
Ryanair Holdings introduces new routes from Bournemouth Liverpool to Paphos for Winter 2018
Ryanair Holdings introduces new routes from Bournemouth Liverpool to 
Paphos for Winter 2018
MarketLine NewsWire (Formerly Datamonitor)
March 6, 2018 Tuesday 12:00 AM GMT
Copyright 2018 MarketLine All Rights Reserved
Section: AUTOMOTIVE, TRANSPORT AND LOGISTICS
Length: 201 words
Highlight: Ryanair has launched new routes from Bournemouth and Liverpool to Paphos, which will operate twice

Ryanair and Aer Lingus sign flight-connection deal
Ryanair and Aer Lingus sign flight-connection deal
Business World (Digest)
March 05, 2018 Monday
Copyright 2018 Media World Ltd. All Rights Reserved
Section: GENERAL
Length: 239 words
Byline: Business World
Body
Ryanair and IAG's Aer Lingus have signed a co-operation agreement to offer connecting flights on each other's 
services, the Aer Lingus CEO was quoted as saying on Sunday.
In a first for Ryanair, Europe's largest budget airline will feed passengers from some of its European routes onto its 
Irish rival's transatlantic services, while Aer Lingus will connect ontoRyanair services to various European 
destinations.
Ryanair Chief Executive Michael O'Leary had long been opposed to selling journeys involving connecting flights but 
the company started trials on Ryanair-only connections last year.
"We will trial it in the marketplace. If it's successful, we will live with the problems of success. If not, we will learn the 
lessons and move on," Aer Lingus Chief Executive Stephen Kavanagh told Britain's Sunday Times newspaper.
Ryanair chief marketing officer Kenny Jacobs last week said that the company hoped to start operating connecting 
flights with Aer Lingus this year.
The Sunday Times said the service will be packaged by a third-party intermediary that will also offer passengers 
connection insurance to cover missed onward flights.
The risk of having to compensate passengers for missed connections was one of Ryanair's main reasons for 
shunning the idea of offering feeder flights for long-haul routes.
The Irish airline last year ended talks with Norwegian Air Shuttle on a similar arrangement. (Reuters)
Ryanair and Aer Lingus sign flight-connection deal
Source: www.businessworld.ie
Load-Date: March 22, 2018
End of Document

RYAAY has been the topic of a number of other research reports.
