Ryanair says cutting fares 30% to fill Catalonia flights
Ryanair says cutting fares 30% to fill Catalonia flights
Business World (Digest)
February 13, 2018 Tuesday
Copyright 2018 Media World Ltd. All Rights Reserved
Section: WORLD
Length: 362 words
Byline: Business World
Body
Ryanair has been cutting fares by up to 30% to fill flights to Barcelona and other cities in Catalonia as 
holidaymakers are nervous of political upheaval in the Spanish region, Chief Executive Michael O'Leary said on 
Tuesday.
Tourist numbers in Barcelona dipped after an attack in August left 16 people dead and an illegal independence vote 
prompted scenes of police violence and mass protests, but have since rebounded.
Ryanair still plans to increase capacity in Spain as a whole sharply in the coming year, adding 9% more flights in 
the year to March 2019, O'Leary said, compared with an increase of 6% in its network as a whole.
"To fill the aircraft we had to lower the fares (for flights to Barcelona) very significantly," O'Leary told a press 
conference in Madrid. "The fares are significantly lower as we approach the summer than they were last year," he 
said, though demand for travel to Madrid remained strong.
Capacity in Spain has increased in recent years as operators have moved from destinations in the Middle East and 
North Africa in the wake of attacks on tourists.
The number of international tourists visiting Spain broke records for a fifth straight year in 2017, climbing 8.9% year-
on-year to 82 million.
One threat to Ryanair's rapid expansion plans are relations with pilots. While strike threats in December were 
averted by a pledge to recognise labour unions for the first time, the airline has so far only managed to reach a 
recognition agreement with one of the seven unions with which it is in talks.
Ryanair says cutting fares 30% to fill Catalonia flights
O'Leary said Spain's SEPLA pilots' union had not yet responded to offers of a pay rise and terms for union 
recognition and Ryanair was considering bypassing the union and offering the increase directly to pilots - something 
it has done in Ireland.
"With SEPLA we're trying to say: let's have a vote on the Spanish pilots' pay increase, even when we're trying to 
finalise the agreement. If you don't, we'll offer it directly to the Spanish pilots," he said.
SEPLA last week said it would launch a legal action against Ryanair and said it had been naive to think 
management wanted to change "toxic labour relations." (Reuters)
Source: www.businessworld.ie
Load-Date: February 28, 2018
End of Document
Frankfurt sees strong rise in flights and passengers in January
Frankfurt sees strong rise in flights and passengers in January
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
February 13, 2018 Tuesday 2:11 PM GMT
Copyright 2018 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 168 words
Byline: Christian Ebner in Frankfurt
Dateline: Frankfurt (dpa) - 
Body
Almost 4.6 million passengers passed through Germany's largest airport near Frankfurt in January, up 7.6 per cent 
on the year, according to figures released by the operating company Fraport on Tuesday.
The figure was a record for the month, the company said, adding that the gaps created in the German market by 
the bankruptcy of Air Berlin had been closed. The budget carrier initiated insolvency proceedings in August.
New routes to European destinations led to an increase in flight movements of 8.6 per cent, with additional routes 
provided by budget carriers Ryanair and Wizz leading the rise.
Among the new offerings were classical holiday destinations around the Mediterranean, including Turkey, where 
there was evident growth for the first time since the start of the financial crisis.
Long-haul routes grew less strongly at 2.6 per cent, although there was a rise in flights to South Korea ahead of the 
Winter Olympics.
Editorial contactsEditing by: Bill Heaney, +49 30 2852 31472, <international@dpa.com;
Load-Date: February 14, 2018
End of Document

       FRANKFURT (dpa-AFX) - Almost 4.6 million passengers passed through Germany's largest airport near 
Frankfurt in January, up 7.6 per cent on the year, according to figures released by the operating company Fraport 
on Tuesday.  The figure was a record for the month, the company said, adding that the gaps created in the German 
market by the bankruptcy of Air Berlin had been closed. The budget carrier initiated insolvency proceedings in 
August.  New routes to European destinations led to an increase in flight movements of 8.6 per cent, with additional 
routes provided by budget carriers Ryanair and Wizz leading the rise.  Among the new offerings were classical 
holiday destinations around the Mediterranean, including Turkey, where there was evident growth for the first time 
since the start of the financial crisis.  Long-haul routes grew less strongly at 2.6 per cent, although there was a rise 
in flights to South Korea ahead of the Winter Olympics.   Copyright dpa

No Headline In Original
No Headline In Original
Flight International
February 13, 2018
Copyright 2018 Reed Business Information Ltd. All Rights Reserved
Section: FEATURES
Length: 632 words
Byline: XX XX
Body
In the UK and several of its other big markets, Ryanair is the airline passengers and the media love to hate – thanks 
to its cost-slashing philosophy and aviation establishment-baiting boss. In Rzeszow, locals have a different 
perspective on the Irish budget carrier. For years, Ryanair provided the southern Polish city’s only direct connection 
to Western Europe, with a daily flight to London Stansted. Today, the airline also flies to four other UK airports, plus 
Dublin, making for an easier commute for those working for an increasing number of British companies basing 
themselves in Poland’s main aviation cluster, Aviation Valley.
Aneta Cygan-Rzeminska, project manager with start-up Poeton Polska, is one. She flies “very cheaply” via Bristol to 
meetings at her parent company, a surface treatment specialist based in Gloucester and Cardiff. She can see the 
terminal from her first floor office in a “business incubator” owned by Podkarpackie’s provincial government. The 
Ryanair connection was also crucial to Bristol-based engine components manufacturer McBraida’s decision to set 
up next to the airport in 2013. In addition to Bristol, the airline flies to East Midlands, Glasgow and Manchester as 
well as Mediterranean routes in the summer.
Although the Dublin-based airline is responsible for three-fifths of Rzeszow’s traffic – “Ryanair feeds us,” says 
Michal Tabisz, president of the board of Rzeszow airport – it is not the only carrier offering direct routes out of 
Poland. Lufthansa flies daily to Munich, and there are discussions with the airline to increase that frequency to 
twice-daily, with an early flight making day trips possible for business travellers connecting to other European cities 
through the German hub. Polish flag carrier LOT also offers four daily flights to Warsaw, allowing passengers to 
transfer to its international network.
new terminal
Provincial government-owned Rzeszow’s three-storey, glass-plated terminal replaced its tiny, box-like predecessor 
in 2012 and annual passenger numbers stand at around 700,000. This is only around half its capacity of 1.3 million, 
but “puts us at the top of the second division of Polish airports, behind the top five”, says Tabisz. The airport has a 
No Headline In Original
short-term “strategic target” of 1 million passengers. However, Tabisz adds: “It is not a race. What matters is that 
we are meeting the needs of the region. It’s an airport that can still grow.”
Tabisz identifies freight as a potential growth segment for the airport, which opened a cargo terminal in 2017. With 
one of Poland’s longest runways, Rzeszow can accommodate the largest freighters. “Cargo is what we really want 
to go with,” says Tabisz. “We would love a Chinese company. Our advantage is that we are close to the rest of 
central Europe and we have plenty of room. If you go to Warsaw, you won’t get treated as a priority customer. 
Come here and you will get every benefit going.”
Maintenance, repair and overhaul is another target. The airport, which is 90km (56 miles) from its closest rival, 
Krakow, owns land around the perimeter and two MRO companies – Heli-One and Linetech – have already set up 
operations. The Linetech hangar, owned by the airport, is the largest in Poland. Tabisz would especially like to 
attract a carrier – including Ryanair – to establish a hub at Rzeszow, creating local jobs for crew and line 
maintenance. “We don’t have any airlines based here, but that would really help me,” he says.
flights Murdo Morrison Rzeszow
“It is not a race. What matters
is that we are meeting the
needs of the region”
Michal Tabisz
President of the board, Rzeszow airport
Rzeszow airport has a short-term strategic target of attracting
1 million passengers
Rzeszow Airport
Connecting region to the world: airport puts faith in freight and low-cost leader
Load-Date: February 13, 2018
End of Document
No Headline In Original

short-term “strategic target” of 1 million passengers. However, Tabisz adds: “It is not a race. What matters is that 
we are meeting the needs of the region. It’s an airport that can still grow.”

customer. Come here and you will get every benefit going.”
Maintenance, repair and overhaul is another sector being targeted. The airport, which is 90km from its closest rival, 
Krakow, owns land around the perimeter and two MRO companies – Heli-One and Linetech – have already set up 
operations. The Linetech hangar, owned by the airport, is the largest in Poland. Tabisz would especially like to 
attract a carrier – including Ryanair – to establish a hub at Rzeszow, creating local jobs for crew and line 
maintenance. “We don’t have any airlines based here, but that would really help me,” he says.
flights Murdo Morrison Rzeszow
“It is not a race. What matters
is that we are meeting the
needs of the region”
Michal Tabisz
President of the board, Rzeszow airport
Rzeszow airport has a short-term strategic target of attracting 1 million passengers
Rzeszow Airport
Connecting region to the world: airport puts faith in freight and low-cost leader
Load-Date: February 13, 2018
End of Document
Ryanair Holdings PLC (RYAAY) Receives $109.00 Consensus PT from Brokerages
Ryanair Holdings PLC (RYAAY) Receives $109.00 Consensus PT from 
Brokerages
Watchlist News
February 12, 2018 Monday 9:23 PM EST
Copyright 2018 Newstex LLC All Rights Reserved
Length: 757 words
Byline: Mark Dietrich
Body
Feb 12, 2018( Watchlist News: http://www.watchlistnews.com/ Delivered by Newstex)  Ryanair Holdings PLC 
(NASDAQ:RYAAY) has earned an average recommendation of 'Hold' from the eleven ratings firms that are 
currently covering the firm, MarketBeat Ratings[1] reports. Two research analysts have rated the stock with a sell 
rating, three have assigned a hold rating and six have assigned a buy rating to the company. The average 1 year 
target price among analysts that have issued a report on the stock in the last year is $109.00.  RYAAY has been the 
topic of several research analyst reports. 
BidaskClub raised Ryanair from a 'hold' rating to a 'buy' rating in a research note on Tuesday, January 23rd. UBS 
Group raised Ryanair from a 'neutral' rating to a 'buy' rating in a research note on Thursday, January 11th. Citigroup 
initiated coverage on Ryanair in a research note on Monday, November 20th. They set a 'buy' rating on the stock. 
ValuEngine[2] raised Ryanair from a 'hold' rating to a 'buy' rating in a research note on Friday, February 2nd. 
Finally, Zacks Investment Research[3] raised Ryanair from a 'sell' rating to a 'hold' rating in a research note on 
Thursday, January 25th. Ryanair (RYAAY[4]) traded up $1.56 during trading hours on Friday, reaching $115.69. 
The company had a trading volume of 339,900 shares, compared to its average volume of 413,175. The firm has a 
market capitalization of $27,580.73, a price-to-earnings ratio of 16.77, a PEG ratio of 0.92 and a beta of 0.67. The 
company has a quick ratio of 1.61, a current ratio of 1.61 and a debt-to-equity ratio of 0.77. Ryanair has a fifty-two 
week low of $78.35 and a fifty-two week high of $127.35.  Ryanair announced that its Board of Directors has 
approved a share buyback plan on Monday, February 5th that permits the company to buyback outstanding shares. 
This buyback authorization permits the transportation company to repurchase shares of its stock through open 
market purchases. Shares buyback plans are typically a sign that the company's management believes its stock is 
undervalued. Several institutional investors have recently bought and sold shares of the stock. First Republic 
Investment Management Inc. bought a new stake in Ryanair in the fourth quarter worth approximately $837,000. 
Comgest Global Investors S.A.S. increased its holdings in Ryanair by 5.9% in the fourth quarter. Comgest Global 
Investors S.A.S. now owns 39,400 shares of the transportation company's stock worth $4,105,000 after purchasing 
an additional 2,200 shares in the last quarter. FDx Advisors Inc. increased its holdings in Ryanair by 90.8% in the 
fourth quarter. FDx Advisors Inc. now owns 19,328 shares of the transportation company's stock worth $2,014,000 
after purchasing an additional 9,199 shares in the last quarter. Tower Research Capital LLC TRC bought a new 
stake in Ryanair in the fourth quarter worth approximately $148,000. Finally, Bank of New York Mellon Corp 
increased its holdings in Ryanair by 2.8% in the fourth quarter. Bank of New York Mellon Corp now owns 139,612 
shares of the transportation company's stock worth $14,547,000 after purchasing an additional 3,774 shares in the

brokerages/1861838.html.  Ryanair Company Profile Ryanair Holdings plc (Ryanair Holdings) is a holding company 
for Ryanair Limited (Ryanair). Ryanair operates an ultra-low fare, scheduled-passenger airline serving short-haul, 
point-to-point routes between Ireland, the United Kingdom, Continental Europe, Morocco and Israel. Ryanair 
provides various ancillary services and engages in other activities connected with its core air passenger service, 
including non-flight scheduled services, Internet-related services, and the in-flight sale of beverages, food and

announced that its board has approved a stock repurchase plan on Monday, February 5th that allows the company 
to repurchase outstanding shares. This repurchase authorization allows the transportation company to purchase

Ryanair sets new course with union agreement Airline vows to protect its low-cost model after being forced to 
recognise pilots' representatives following roster....
Ryanair sets new course with union agreement; Airline vows to protect its 
low-cost model after being forced to recognise pilots' representatives 
following rostering chaos
Financial Times (London, England)
February 12, 2018 Monday
Edition 1, National Edition
Copyright 2018 The Financial Times Limited All Rights Reserved
Section: COMPANIES AND MARKETS;BUSINESS; Pg. 17
Length: 995 words
Byline: TANYA POWLEY
Body
For the past two decades Ryanair's voluble chief executive Michael O'Leary has been adamant that hell would 
freeze over or he would supposedly cut off his arms before he agreed to sit down with trade unions.
But late last year, faced with growing pressure from pilots and threats of strike action in the run-up to Christmas, 
Europe's biggest low-cost airline shocked investors with a surprise decision to reverse its longstanding policy and 
recognise unions for the first time in Ryanair's 32-year history.
It pushed forward with those plans last month, signing its first union deal with British pilots' group Balpa - a 
significant move as the UK accounts for about a quarter of Ryanair's pilots and aircraft.
"It's a critical junction in the airline's history," says Daniel Roeska, aviation analyst at Bernstein. "Its non-union 
stance was one of the big hallmarks of Ryanair's 'why we are very different' story. The reputational significance 
here is that it's not that different any more. Ryanair still has great airline managers, it's still a great business model 
but ... it's becoming more similar to other airlines."
The change of course comes after a difficult time. A pilot rostering mess-up in September saw it cancel more than 
20,000 flights, slow its growth plans for winter and next summer and go on a hiring spree for cockpit crew.
Ryanair sets new course with union agreement Airline vows to protect its low-cost model after being forced to 
recognise pilots' representatives following roster....
The fiasco dealt a severe blow to Ryanair, which has built its reputation as an efficient, safe and reliable operator.
It also sparked a battle with pilots, who were emboldened to push for better terms in the wake of the crisis.
Several analysts think its decision to recognise unions is one of the biggest U-turns in Ryanair's history, noting that 
its non-union stance has been key in helping the carrier build itself into the juggernaut it is today with its aggressive 
focus on cutting costs. In Europe, along-side easyJet, it has upended the industry over the past 30 years with a 
singleminded focus on cheap fares, which has seen legacy airlines such as British Airways, Lufthansa and Air 
France-KLM cede as much as 40 per cent of the shorthaul market to their budget rivals. Keeping labour costs low 
has been a core part of Ryanair's successful business model. Its pilots are a mix of fulltime employees and 
independent contractors. Its refusal to recognise unions meant it was able to drive productivity harder than legacy 
flag carriers.
"If they move to a unionised workforce, I would expect that to lead to normal industry working practices with local 
employment contracts and permanent employment contracts," says Andrew Lobbenberg, aviation analyst at HSBC. 
"A key part of Ryanair's success has been how flexible the business has been. And part of that has been their 
contractual ability to move people around, which has come from their employment structure."
Ryanair has spent the past four months attempting to fix problems with its pilots by offering to increase pay by 20 
per cent, but has only agreed deals with just over half of its 87 bases.
Some analysts think Ryanair had to change. "They were in a place where their natural established behaviour, which 
is to respond assertively or aggressively to labour or where people are challenging them, was only going to make 
the situation worse," says Mr Lobbenberg of HSBC. "It would only serve to accelerate the attrition [of pilots] and put 
them into deeper trouble."
Mr Roeska says it is crucial for Ryanair to "safeguard the number of employees they have" in order to keep to flying 
schedules and the 2024 target of carrying 200m passengers a year, up from 130m this year.
"That's why they are so adamant in pushing through the wage rises. It's seldom that an employer is so desperate to 
give people more money," he says.
While there are concerns about the impact of unionisation on Ryanair's business, its management team has been 
quick to deny that it will affect its low-cost, high-productivity model.
Last week, the airline said recognising unions and agreeing new pay deals would cost it (EURO)100m a year from 
2019, which includes any future deals reached with cabin crew unions. It also maintained its full-year profit forecast 
of (EURO)1.4bn-(EURO)1.45bn.
But while Ryanair has done a deal with the British pilots union, and expects to conclude others shortly, it is facing 
more of a battle with some, including those in Ireland, Germany and Spain.
However, Ryanair showed it has not lost its combative streak, with Mr O'Leary warning at its third-quarter results 
the airline could be hit with further strikes as it was facing "laughable demands for legacy-type inefficiencies" from 
some unions across Europe. He added: "We are fully prepared to face down any such disruption."
Eddie Wilson, Ryanair's chief people officer, said the airline had become more "mature" in terms of its approach. 
"We would have fought to have kept the model that we have because it gives you flexibility, but the world has 
moved on," he says. "The business has changed. You have to adapt to it. If you can't win something, then you just 
have to change." But he reiterated that there would be conflict with unions and pilots if they tried to seek anything 
that would "attack" its low-cost, high-productivity model. "If suddenly pilots said they only wanted to fly 400 hours a 
year like elsewhere, then yes, there would be conflict," he says.
For now, it is likely to take months or even years to see the full implication of union recognition on Ryanair's low-
cost business.
Ryanair sets new course with union agreement Airline vows to protect its low-cost model after being forced to 
recognise pilots' representatives following roster....
Gerald Khoo, aviation analyst at Liberum, says: "Fundamentally they are still in a strong position, with a very 
competitive cost base, high margins and a very strong balance sheet. It's not going to be crippled by this. The 
underlying business model is still absolutely viable and successful."
Sources: Bloomberg; Thomson Reuters Datastream Ryanair hits headwinds Net income ((EURO)bn) -0.4 0 0.4 0.8 
1.2 1.6 1998 2005 10 15 17 Share prices (rebased) 90 100 110 120 130 140 150 160 170 Jan 2017 2018 Feb 
Ryanair'syjet IAG

Ryanair's managing director Eddie Wilson, right, meets union representatives in Copenhagen - Tariq Mikkel 
Khan/GettyTariq Mikkel Khan/Getty
Load-Date: February 11, 2018

has driven the carrier's success and seen legacy carriers cede large parts of the market.

Sunday Papers: Tesco ’s secret plot for cut-price chain
Sunday Papers: Tesco’s secret plot for cut-price chain
Citywire
February 11, 2018 Sunday 4:49 AM GMT
Copyright 2018 Citywire Financial Publishers All Rights Reserved
Length: 730 words
Byline: Himanshu Singh
Highlight: And hidden report reveals ministers exaggerated UK fracking boom.
Body

O’Leary offers pilots 20 per cent pay hike ‘and that’s it’
O’Leary offers pilots 20 per cent pay hike ‘and that’s it’
Sunday Business Post
February 10, 2018
Copyright 2018 Post Publications Ltd. All Rights Reserved
Length: 440 words
Byline: Ian Guider
Highlight: The Ryanair boss has warned that it faces potential disruption to its services in the coming month, but 
has said there will be nothing extra on the table
Body
Ryanair’s chief executive Michael O’Leary has said the airline will not be upping its offer of a 20 per cent pay hike 
for pilots in Dublin.
The Ryanair boss has warned that it faces potential disruption to its services in the coming month, but said there 
will be nothing extra on the table. Pilots across Ryanair are being offered a 20 per cent pay rise as the company 
negotiates directly with unions for the first time. Some of its Dublin-based pilots have held out against the offer and 
the airline has written to them urging them to accept it.
“We have now the crazy situation that the union, instead of securing a 20 per cent pay increase for some of our 
Dublin pilots, we’re having to write to them directly to offer them the right to accept a 20 per cent pay increase in the 
February payroll, having lost out on that increase in January and December,” O’Leary said on a conference call with 
analysts last week.
“Now, I think that’s inevitable that kind of mindless interference by people who are promoting an Aer Lingus agenda 
rather than a Ryanair agenda, it will lead to some disruptions somewhere. So it’s not that I think we are definitely 
going to face strikes, but I want our investors and analysts to be, look, grow up. There is going to be some 
disruptions here.
“The pay increase is 20 per cent. It’s not going to be 21 per cent. It’s not going to be 25 per cent. It’s going to be 20 
per cent, and that’s it.”
Ryanair in December conceded that it would negotiate pay with unions after a months-long stand-off that saw pilots 
across dozens of European bases seek collective bargaining. It is the first time in the company’s history that it sat 
down to discuss pay with representatives of a union. The offer of a 20 per cent pay rise for pilots in key bases came 
after it was forced to cancel thousands of flights to cope with a shortage of pilots.
O’Leary offers pilots 20 per cent pay hike ‘and that’s it’
O’Leary also said that while there was a tightening in the supply of experienced pilots, there was no shortage of 
new recruits.
“We’ve hired over 1,100 pilots in calendar 2017 and expect to do a similar number again this year. The question for 
us is, as some of the flakier competitors who couldn’t make money when oil was under $40 a barrel last year, is, 
how long they survive when oil is at $70 a barrel, and they will lose even more money and are frantically selling off 
what limited assets they have to provide the cash for them to continue to operate.”
Even after the cost of the flight cancellations and the cost of hiring extra staff, Ryanair said it will still be on course 
to generate a profit of of between €1.4 billion and €1.45 billion in the 12 months to the end of March.
Load-Date: February 10, 2018
End of Document
Ryanair Holdings PLC (RYAAY) Given Consensus Rating of "Hold" by Analysts
Ryanair Holdings PLC (RYAAY) Given Consensus Rating of "Hold" by 
Analysts
American Banking and Market News
February 9, 2018 Friday
Copyright 2018 American Banking and Market News All Rights Reserved
Length: 608 words
Body
Ryanair logo Shares of Ryanair Holdings PLC (NASDAQ:RYAAY) have been given a consensus recommendation 
of "Hold" by the eleven brokerages that are currently  covering the company,            Marketbeat  reports. Two 
research analysts have rated the stock with a sell rating, three have given a hold rating and six have given a buy 
rating to  the company. The average 1-year price objective among analysts that have issued a report on the stock in 
the last year is $109.00.  
A number of equities research analysts have recently issued reports on the stock. Zacks Investment Research  
raised shares of Ryanair from a "sell" rating to a "hold" rating in a research note on Thursday, January 25th. 
BidaskClub raised shares of Ryanair from a "sell" rating to a "hold" rating in a research note on Friday, January 5th. 
Credit Suisse Group cut shares of Ryanair from an "outperform" rating to a "neutral" rating in a research note on 
Monday, December 18th.            ValuEngine  raised shares of Ryanair from a "hold" rating to a "buy" rating in a 
research note on Friday, February 2nd. Finally, UBS Group raised shares of Ryanair from a "neutral" rating to a 
"buy" rating in a research note on Thursday, January 11th. 
Shares of Ryanair (NASDAQ:RYAAY ) opened at $114.13 on Friday. Ryanair has a 12 month low of $78.35 and a 
12 month high of $127.35. The stock has a market cap of $23,150.00, a price-to-earnings ratio of 15.53, a PEG 
ratio of 0.92 and a beta of 0.64. The company has a quick ratio of 1.62, a current ratio of 1.61 and a debt-to-equity 
ratio of 0.77.  
Ryanair announced that its Board of Directors has initiated a share buyback plan on Monday, February 5th that 
allows the company to repurchase    shares. This repurchase authorization allows the transportation company to 
reacquire shares of its stock through open market purchases. Shares repurchase plans are generally a sign that the 
company's board believes its shares are undervalued.  
Institutional investors have recently made changes to their positions in the company. WCM Investment 
Management CA purchased a new stake in  Ryanair during the 4th quarter valued at $368,207,000.  AXA 
purchased a new stake in  Ryanair during the 3rd quarter valued at $35,271,000.  Bank of Montreal Can boosted its 
position in  Ryanair by 625.2% during the 4th quarter. Bank of Montreal Can now owns 350,215 shares of the 
transportation company's stock valued at $36,489,000 after buying an additional 301,925 shares during the period.  
Adelphi Capital LLP boosted its position in  Ryanair by 31.9% during the 4th quarter. Adelphi Capital LLP now owns 
611,951 shares of the transportation company's stock valued at $63,759,000 after buying an additional 147,972 
shares during the period.  Finally, Manning & Napier Advisors LLC boosted its position in  Ryanair by 26.7% during 
Ryanair Holdings PLC (RYAAY) Given Consensus Rating of "Hold" by Analysts
the 3rd quarter. Manning & Napier Advisors LLC now owns 609,344 shares of the transportation company's stock 
valued at $64,236,000 after buying an additional 128,331 shares during the period. 40.49% of the stock is owned 
by institutional investors.  
About Ryanair
Ryanair Holdings plc (Ryanair Holdings) is a holding company for Ryanair Limited (Ryanair). Ryanair operates an 
ultra-low fare, scheduled-passenger airline serving short-haul, point-to-point routes between Ireland, the United 
Kingdom, Continental Europe, Morocco and Israel. Ryanair provides various ancillary services and engages in 
other activities connected with its core air passenger service, including non-flight scheduled services, Internet-
related services, and the in-flight sale of beverages, food and merchandise.

Vote secures easyJet 's right to continue flying after Brexit Airlines
Vote secures easyJet's right to continue flying after Brexit; Airlines
Financial Times (London, England)
February 9, 2018 Friday
Edition 1, 
Copyright 2018 The Financial Times Limited All Rights Reserved
Section: COMPANIES AND MARKETS;BUSINESS; Pg. 13
Length: 368 words
Byline: TANYA POWLEY
Body
EasyJet has pushed ahead with plans to protect its flying rights after Brexit following a shareholder vote in favour of 
legal changes to help ensure the lowcost airline meets EU ownership rules.
The move makes it the latest carrier to make changes in preparation for Britain's departure from the EU as fears 
grow that a turbulent exit could cause disruption across the aviation market.
Airlines are grappling with a range of regulatory puzzles in the wake of Britain's decision to leave the EU.
These include agreeing a new legal basis for British airlines to operate flights between EU countries and ownership 
rules requiring carriers operating in the region to be majority controlled by entities within the bloc.
Yesterday, shareholders at easyJet's annual meeting approved changes to its articles of association that will ensure 
it is EU-owned and controlled after Brexit.
The move means it has the power to force UK shareholders to divest their shares if the airline needs them to.
John Barton, chairman, said: "Brexit is one of the biggest issues facing the European airline industry." He said that 
while the airline had no "immediate intention" of using these powers, they were an "important element in ensuring 
that easyJet plc has the ability to maintain EU ownership and control at all times should we need to do so".
Vote secures easyJet 's right to continue flying after Brexit Airlines
EasyJet said close to 50 per cent of its shares were already held by European Economic Area nationals. It also said 
it expected the Civil Aviation Authority, Britain's aviation regulator, to grant it an air operator's certificate in the 
coming weeks to cover its UK-based aircraft.
It added the government had confirmed the airline, easyJet UK, would be treated as a British carrier after Brexit and 
its parent company was EU-owned.
The airline was one of the first to make moves to protect flying rights following Britain's decision to quit the EU. Last 
year, it set up an EU-based airline to ensure that it could continue intra-European flights regardless of Brexit talks. 
In recent months, other European carriers have taken similar steps.
Ryanair confirmed last month that it had applied for a British air operating certificate to ensure it could continue 
flights in the country after Brexit.
Graphic
 
EasyJet will now be able to maintain ownership within the EU after Brexit
Load-Date: February 8, 2018
End of Document
Vote secures easyJet 's right to fly after Brexit Airlines ; Carrier will be able to force sales of shares to meet EU 
ownership rules
Vote secures easyJet's right to fly after Brexit; Airlines ; Carrier will be able 
to force sales of shares to meet EU ownership rules
Financial Times (London, England)
February 9, 2018 Friday
Edition 1, National Edition
Copyright 2018 The Financial Times Limited All Rights Reserved
Section: COMPANIES AND MARKETS;BUSINESS; Pg. 18
Length: 449 words
Byline: TANYA POWLEY
Body
EasyJet has pushed ahead with plans to protect its flying rights after Brexit following a shareholder vote in favour of 
legal changes to help ensure the low-cost airline meets EU ownership rules.
The move makes it the latest carrier to make changes in preparation for Britain's departure from the EU as fears 
grow that a turbulent exit could cause disruption across the aviation market.
Airlines are grappling with a range of regulatory puzzles in the wake of Britain's decision to leave the EU.
These include agreeing a new legal basis for British airlines to operate flights between EU countries and ownership 
rules requiring carriers operating in the region to be majority controlled by entities within the bloc.
Yesterday, shareholders at easyJet's annual meeting approved changes to its articles of association that will ensure 
it is EU-owned and controlled after Brexit.
The move means it has the power to force UK shareholders to divest their shares if the airline needs them to.
John Barton, chairman, said: "Brexit is one of the biggest issues facing the European airline industry." He said that 
while the airline had no "immediate intention" of using these powers, they were an "important element in ensuring 
that easyJet plc has the ability to maintain EU ownership and control at all times should we need to do so".
Vote secures easyJet 's right to fly after Brexit Airlines ; Carrier will be able to force sales of shares to meet EU 
ownership rules
EasyJet said close to 50 per cent of its shares were already held by European Economic Area nationals. It also said 
it expected the Civil Aviation Authority, Britain's aviation regulator, to grant it an air operator's certificate in the 
coming weeks to cover its UK-based aircraft.
It added that the government had confirmed that easyJet UK would be treated as a British carrier after Brexit even 
though its parent was EU-owned.
The airline was one of the first to make moves to protect flying rights following Britain's decision to quit the EU. Last 
year, it set up an EU-based airline to ensure that it could continue intra-European flights regardless of Brexit talks.
In recent months, other European carriers have taken similar steps. In October, Wizz Air, central and eastern 
Europe's largest low-cost carrier, announced it was accelerating contingency planning for Brexit.
Low-cost airline Ryanair confirmed last month that it had applied for a British air operator's certificate to ensure it 
could continue flights in the country after Brexit.
Britain's £60bn aviation industry has made clear its preference for maintaining access to the EU's Open Skies 
regime, which gives all EU airlines the right to fly between member states and domestically within member states.
'Brexit is one of the biggest issues facing the European airline industry' John Barton, easyJet chairman

CAE posts Q3 fiscal 2018 results
CAE posts Q3 fiscal 2018 results
MarketLine NewsWire (Formerly Datamonitor)
February 9, 2018 Friday 12:00 AM GMT
Copyright 2018 MarketLine All Rights Reserved
Section: AEROSPACE
Length: 418 words
Highlight: CAE has reported revenue of $704.4 million for the third quarter of fiscal year 2018, compared with 
$682.7 million in the third quarter last year.
Body
Third quarter net income attributable to equity holders from continuing operations was $117.9 million ($0.44 per 
share) compared to $67.6 million ($0.25 per share) last year. Third quarter fiscal 2018 results include an income tax 
recovery related to the US tax reform and a net gain on the fair valuation of CAE&#39;s prior investment in the 
Asian Aviation Centre of Excellence (AACE). Excluding these elements, earnings per share would have been 
$0.28. EPS before specific items was $0.26 last year. All financial information is in Canadian dollars unless 
otherwise indicated."CAE remains on track to deliver on our growth outlook and we are well positioned to benefit 
from the secular tailwinds driving our markets," said Marc Parent, CAE&#39;s President and Chief Executive 
Officer. 
"We had year-over-year growth in all segments this quarter, as well as strong order intake and free cash flow. In 
Civil, market activity was especially strong as we received a quarterly-record, $1 billion in new orders for our 
comprehensive training solutions. And in Defence, growth momentum increased in the quarter and we continued to 
win important training systems and services contracts, adding to a large year-to-date order book."Civil Aviation 
Training Solutions (Civil)Third quarter Civil revenue was $413.7 million, compared to $412.8 million in the same 
quarter last year. Segment operating income was $78.6 million (19.0% of revenue) in the third quarter, which 
includes a gain on the fair valuation of CAE&#39;s prior AACE investment and some reorganizational costs. Before 
this net gain, operating income would have been $74.6 million (18% of revenue) up 4% compared to the third 
quarter last year. Third quarter Civil training centre utilization(7)was 75%.During the quarter, Civil signed training 
solutions contracts with a record quarterly order intake value of $1.0 billion. They include exclusive long-term 
training services contract extensions with AirAsia, Air Transat, Mesa Aviation, and Jazz Aviation. As well, Civil won 
26 full-flight simulator (FFS) orders from customers including: Ryanair; Air France; ATR; Lufthansa Flight Training; 
Air Canada; Jeju air; Xiamen Air; Donghai Airlines; Xinjiang Yuxiang Flight Training; and Fiji Airways. This brings 
the Civil FFS order intake for the first nine months of the fiscal year to 45 FFSs.The Civil book-to-sales(3)ratio was 
CAE posts Q3 fiscal 2018 results
2.43x for the quarter and 1.43x for the last 12 months. The Civil backlog at the end of the quarter was a record $3.8 
billion.

Ryanair 's perception climbs again after winter turbulence
Ryanair's perception climbs again after winter turbulence
City A.M.
February 7, 2018 Wednesday
Edition 1, National Edition
Copyright 2018 City A.M. All Rights Reserved
Section: NEWS; Pg. 13
Length: 341 words
Byline: Stephan Shakespeare
Body
RYANAIR has posted a 12 per cent rise in profits after tax in the three months to December. So what has happened 
to the carrier's consumer perception since September when it was beset by flight cancellations and issues 
surrounding pilot holiday? YouGov brand tracking data indicates that following its difficulties in early autumn, the 
airline's impression score (whether someone has a positive impression of the brand) dropped from negative 31 to 
negative 52 among the general public. Since that time, with operations back on track and a spell out of the 
headlines, it has almost recovered, rising by 16 points to negative 36.
The carrier's buzz score (whether someone has heard anything positive or negative about the brand) follows a 
similar trend.
It dropped to negative 45 at its lowest point but has now recovered somewhat, climbing to negative 18.
However, it should be noted that Ryanair remains bottom of the airline sector in terms of both Impression and buzz.
The airline may soon face more adverse press.
The Civil Aviation Authority recently announced a review often top airlines' seating policies to find out whether 
operators deliberately split up groups of passengers travelling together in order to profit from allocated seating. Data 
released this week revealed that those who flew with budget airline Ryanair were the most likely to report being 
separated from their group after deciding not to pay more money to sit with their travel companions.
The good news for Ryanair is that its key selling point remains attractive to its core audience.
Ryanair 's perception climbs again after winter turbulence
While its Value score remains low among the general public (at negative seven), it does far better among its current 
customers (25).
It is a similar story when it comes to the airline's purchase consideration score.
While it currently sits at 20 among the population as a whole, among those who have flown with Ryanair it is a 
much more solid 62.
Ryanair may not win the admiration of all segments but it knows how to play to its target market.
£ Stephan Shakespeare is the chief executive of YouGov
Load-Date: February 7, 2018
End of Document
Europe ADRs Tumble as Healthcare Sector Drags
Europe ADRs Tumble as Healthcare Sector Drags
MT Newswires Live Briefs
February 6, 2018 Tuesday 11:57 AM EST
Copyright 2018 MT Newswires All Rights Reserved
Length: 226 words
Body
 American depositary receipts of European stocks were trading 4.1% lower at 139.38 on the Bank of New York 
Mellon Europe ADR index on Tuesday.
Decliners in Continental Europe were led by Denmark-based drug makers Forward Pharma (FWP) and Zealand 
Pharma (ZEAL), down 5.2% and 4%, respectively; France-based biopharmaceutical DBV Technologies (DBVT), 
down 3.6%; and Germany-based manufacturer of three-dimensional printers voxeljet (VJET), 2.4% lower.
In the United Kingdom, shares of Cambridge-based GW Pharmaceuticals (GWPH) were down 6.9%; London-based 
Akari Therapeutics (AKTX) fell 5%; Irish medical diagnostics company Trinity Biotech (TRIB) declined 2.7%, and 
oncology company Adaptimmune Therapeutics (ADAP) decreased 2.5%.
Gainers in Continental Europe were led by French maker of geophysical equipment CGG (CGG), up 6.5%; followed 
by dating company Sparks Networks (LOV), 5.6% higher; France-based genome engineering company Cellectis 
(CLLS), up  2.9%, and Finnish mobile network technology company Nokia (NOK), 2.8% higher.
And, in the UK, shares of oncology-focused drug maker Midatech Pharma (MTP) rose 12.6%; Edinburgh-based 
biopharmaceutical NuCana (NCNA) increased 7.8%; Dublin-based budget carrier Ryanair (RYAAY) gained 1.9%; 
and London-based mining and metals company Rio Tinto (RIO) increased 1.7%.

Feb 06, 2018( Watchlist News: http://www.watchlistnews.com/ Delivered by Newstex)  Ryanair Holdings PLC 
(NASDAQ:RYAAY)'s share price was down 6.1% during mid-day trading on Monday . The company traded as low

ValuEngine[1] downgraded shares of Ryanair from a 'buy' rating to a 'hold' rating in a research note on Friday, 
December 15th. BidaskClub upgraded shares of Ryanair from a 'hold' rating to a 'buy' rating in a research note on

20th. They set a 'buy' rating on the stock. Finally, UBS Group upgraded shares of Ryanair from a 'neutral' rating to a 
'buy' rating in a research note on Thursday, January 11th. Two investment analysts have rated the stock with a sell 
rating, three have issued a hold rating and six have assigned a buy rating to the company's stock. The company 
presently has an average rating of 'Hold' and a consensus target price of $96.00. The company has a market cap of 
$22,420.00, a P/E ratio of 15.33, a price-to-earnings-growth ratio of 0.97 and a beta of 0.64. The company has a 
current ratio of 1.62, a quick ratio of 1.62 and a debt-to-equity ratio of 0.79.  A number of institutional investors and 
hedge funds have recently made changes to their positions in RYAAY. AXA acquired a new stake in Ryanair in the 
third quarter valued at approximately $35,271,000. Bank of Montreal Can raised its holdings in shares of Ryanair by 
625.2% in the fourth quarter. Bank of Montreal Can now owns 350,215 shares of the transportation company's 
stock worth $36,489,000 after buying an additional 301,925 shares during the last quarter. Adelphi Capital LLP 
raised its holdings in shares of Ryanair by 31.9% in the fourth quarter. Adelphi Capital LLP now owns 611,951 
shares of the transportation company's stock worth $63,759,000 after buying an additional 147,972 shares during 
the last quarter. Manning ...pier Advisors LLC raised its holdings in shares of Ryanair by 26.7% in the third quarter. 
Manning ...pier Advisors LLC now owns 609,344 shares of the transportation company's stock worth $64,236,000 
after buying an additional 128,331 shares during the last quarter. Finally, American Century Companies Inc. raised 
its holdings in shares of Ryanair by 8.5% in the fourth quarter. American Century Companies Inc. now owns

Unions tell Ryanair to start negotiating Joint le tt er sets out demands for uniform pilot pay rises and urges 
carrier to make "credible" steps towards recognit....
Unions tell Ryanair to start negotiating; Joint le tt er sets out demands for 
uniform pilot pay rises and urges carrier to make "credible" steps towards 
recognition
Flight International
February 6, 2018
Copyright 2018 Reed Business Information Ltd. All Rights Reserved
Section: AIR TRANSPORT
Length: 952 words
Body
Relations between Ryanair and European pilot unions appear to have soured after nearly a dozen of them issued a 
set of demands calling on the carrier to change the way it negotiates during pay and recognition talks.
In a joint letter seen by FlightGlobal, issued in late January, 11 pilot unions – including ANPAC in Italy, BALPA of 
the UK, France’s SNPL and Vereinigung Cockpit in Germany – call on the airline to address seven areas in its 
labour relations strategy in order to make its stated intent to recognise trade unions “credible”.
They urge the company to “meet, recognise and negotiate” with all the representative national pilot unions and 
associations that contact them, desist from interfering in the type of pilots chosen to represent the unions in their 
company councils and negotiating teams, and from excluding pilots employed as contractors.
The unions point to the need for agency flightcrew to be involved in the negotiations, and make the case for pilots’ 
freedom to sign contracts governed by the laws in the country where they are based. They also warn the airline 
against attempts to pursue pay deals with conditions attached at individual bases, outside of formal union 
negotiations.
Pan-Europe deals
Where Ryanair wants to unilaterally increase pilot pay, such agreements must in no way constitute a union-
negotiated arrangement and in no way impinge on union-negotiated deals, and pay rises must also be uniform 
across Europe, the unions argue.
Ryanair rebuts the letter’s contents in strong terms, describing the claims as “materially inaccurate”. It denies it is 
seeking to push through a pay-rise offer and accuses unions of showing a “lack of democracy and shameful 
lethargy” by failing to ballot their members on the airline’s offer.
Unions tell Ryanair to start negotiating Joint le tt er sets out demands for uniform pilot pay rises and urges 
carrier to make "credible" steps towards recognit....
To date, the carrier has sought to paint its negotiations with pilots in a positive light, highlighting progress earlier in 
January in concluding pay deals with all of its flightcrew bases in the UK and Ireland except Dublin.
But union recognition talks have been less fruitful. While the carrier on 30 January recognised BALPA, discussions 
with pilot groups in Belgium, Germany, Ireland, Italy, Portugal and Spain have failed to yield agreements.
The airline tells FlightGlobal that some of these negotiations are “progressing well” while others have made “little 
progress”. It attributes this to the “slow or no response from some national unions/company councils”.
So why is Ryanair pursuing this two-tier strategy in its negotiations with pilots, and why has it drawn such 
widespread criticism from unions?
Joe Lappin, a solicitor with UK law firm Stewarts, believes the primary motivation for Ryanair is to conclude pay 
deals with its pilots as quickly as possible in order to prevent them being poached by rival airlines.
“The decision to negotiate pay with Ryanair pilots must be seen in the context of low staff morale stemming from 
the decision by Ryanair to announce in September last year that pilots would be forced to cancel their holiday plans 
to ensure the airline could keep enough planes in the sky in September and October,” he says. “Ryanair pilots have 
been attracted to rival airlines, including Norwegian, who have promised better pay and working conditions.”
Philip von Schoppenthau, secretary-general of the European Cockpit Association, which represents pilots across 
Europe but has no role in the negotiations, makes a similar point.
Von Schoppenthau says the budget carrier was probably sincere in its wish to pay pilots more – a move he 
welcomes – in order to retain its staff, but he feels that the company needs to be more explicit that these talks are 
separate from recognition discussions.
“A lot of Ryanair’s publicity is probably targeted mostly at investors about the pay-rise offer, which it is pushing 
through at its individual bases across Europe asking pilots to take it or leave it,” he says. “This process is taking 
place in parallel with union recognition talks, but Ryanair has presented them in such a way that some may 
perceive that the processes are linked.”
Learning curve
Ryanair is, von Schoppenthau suggests, “still in the process” of getting acquainted with engaging with unions, 
having previously conducted all of its labour relations through employee representative committees.
Attempts to exclude self-employed or agency pilots, or union representatives who work for competitor airlines, 
“could cause a problem”, he warns.
Lappin suggests that, in the UK at least, the practice of excluding agency workers is not necessarily a flawed 
strategy for Ryanair as they, along with self-employed pilots, would not be included within a bargaining unit.
However, he notes that “any terms negotiated by the union on behalf of its members employed by Ryanair” would 
likely flow back to the airline’s self-employed pilot population too.
He notes that many self-employed pilots are likely to be members of BALPA, “and BALPA will make a case on their 
behalf”.
Ryanair still has a strong hand to play in its negotiations with its pilots. As Europe’s largest airline and one that 
consistently posts strong financial results, it appears to offer stability in an industry still coming to terms with the 
collapse of operators such as Air Berlin and Monarch.
But in the aftermath of its pilot rostering crisis last year, the days of Ryanair holding closed-door meetings at each of 
its bases around Europe and setting the tempo for wage negotiations seem very much to be over.
Unions tell Ryanair to start negotiating Joint le tt er sets out demands for uniform pilot pay rises and urges 
carrier to make "credible" steps towards recognit....
The airline admits talks have made “little progress” in some regions
Andrew Parsons/REX/Shutterstock
“A lot of Ryanair’s
publicity is probably
targeted mostly at
investors about the
pay-rise offer”
Philip von Schoppenthau
Secretary-general, European Cockpit Association
Load-Date: February 6, 2018

Stock Buyback Plan Initiated by Ryanair (RYAAY) Board of Directors
Stock Buyback Plan Initiated by Ryanair (RYAAY) Board of Directors
American Banking and Market News
February 6, 2018 Tuesday
Copyright 2018 American Banking and Market News All Rights Reserved
Length: 388 words
Body
Ryanair logo Ryanair (NASDAQ:RYAAY) announced that its Board of Directors has initiated a share buyback plan, 
which permits the company to repurchase  outstanding  shares on Monday, February 5th, EventVestor reports. This 
repurchase authorization permits the transportation company to repurchase shares of its stock through open market 
purchases. Stock  repurchase plans are generally a sign that the company's board believes its stock is 
undervalued.  
RYAAY has been the topic of a number of research reports. BidaskClub upgraded Ryanair from a "hold" rating to a 
"buy" rating in a research note on Tuesday, January 23rd. UBS Group upgraded Ryanair from a "neutral" rating to a 
"buy" rating in a research note on Thursday, January 11th. Citigroup initiated coverage on Ryanair in a research 
note on Monday, November 20th. They issued a "buy" rating on the stock. ValuEngine  upgraded Ryanair from a 
"hold" rating to a "buy" rating in a research note on Friday. Finally,            Zacks Investment Research  upgraded 
Ryanair from a "sell" rating to a "hold" rating in a research note on Thursday, January 25th. Two research analysts 
have rated the stock with a sell rating, three have assigned  a hold rating and six have assigned  a buy rating to the 
company. The stock  has an average rating of "Hold" and an average target price of $96.00. 
Shares of Ryanair (NASDAQ RYAAY ) traded up $3.23 on Tuesday, hitting $116.33. The stock had a trading 
volume of 375,486 shares, compared to its average volume of 381,795. Ryanair has a 12-month low of $78.35 and 
a 12-month high of $127.35. The company has a market capitalization of $28,705.98, a PE ratio of 16.66, a PEG 
ratio of 0.97 and a beta of 0.67. The company has a debt-to-equity ratio of 0.79, a quick ratio of 1.62 and a current 
ratio of 1.62.  
About Ryanair
Ryanair Holdings plc (Ryanair Holdings) is a holding company for Ryanair Limited (Ryanair). Ryanair operates an 
ultra-low fare, scheduled-passenger airline serving short-haul, point-to-point routes between Ireland, the United 
Kingdom, Continental Europe, Morocco and Israel. Ryanair provides various ancillary services and engages in 
other activities connected with its core air passenger service, including non-flight scheduled services, Internet-
related services, and the in-flight sale of beverages, food and merchandise.

Stock Buyback Plan Initiated by Ryanair (RYAAY) Board of Directors

Ryanair : holdings pattern Twitter : @FTLex Email: lex@ft.com
Ryanair: holdings pattern; Twitter: @FTLex Email: lex@ft.com
Financial Times (London, England)
February 6, 2018 Tuesday
Edition 1, 
Copyright 2018 The Financial Times Limited All Rights Reserved
Section: BUSINESS; Pg. 10
Length: 440 words
Body
In theory, the Irish airline could use its regular share buybacks to help make sure it is controlled by EU-resident 
institutions after Brexit. In reality, that is difficult - not least because the American Depositary Receipts tend to trade 
at a premium to the ordinary shares listed in Dublin and London Ordinary share count (bn) Ryanair ADR premium 
($) 120 1.5 1.4 1.3 100 1.2 Actual ADR price Implied ADR price 1.1 80 1.0 60 2009 10 11 12 13 14 15 16 17 18 
Ryanair share buybacks ((EURO)bn) 1.0 40 0.8 0.6 20 0.4 0.2 0 0 Thank you for flying www.Ryanair.Be aware that 
your flight may be cancelled at short notice if we need to teach our pilots a lesson. Passengers endure the 
privations of Ryanair in return for cheap fares. Likewise, great returns have encouraged shareholders to play down 
risks.
Third-quarter results yesterday came with the usual predictions of fare wars and a warning of more strikes as 
Ryanair talks pay with its newly unionised pilots. There was also a (EURO)750m share buyback.
These are nothing new; Ryanair has spent (EURO)3.9bn buying back stock since 2007. But they may come under 
more scrutiny as Brexit approaches, given their potential to change the composition of the share register.
About 60 per cent of Ryanair shareholders are EU-based. Within that, analysts estimate 20 per cent are in the UK. 
Maintaining EU majority ownership, as required for intra-EU flights, will be a problem after Brexit.
There are solutions. One is to focus buybacks on the American Depositary Receipts. Ryanair has had a mandate to 
buy back ADRs since 2012, but prefers the ordinary stock since the ADRs are tightly held and tend to trade at a 
premium to their implied value. If UK holders were all reclassified as ex-EU, it could cost (EURO)4.8bn to buy back 
enough ADRs to keep EU ownership at 51 per cent, assuming it is feasible to target one set of investors in this way.
Ryanair : holdings pattern Twitter : @FTLex Email: lex@ft.com
Some UK institutions could transfer holdings to subsidiaries in the EU, but it is unclear that would pass muster if the 
beneficial owner remained UK-based. Ryanair could tender for shares held by UK-based investors. More 
laboriously, it could encourage UK investors to swap Ryanair shares for some newly listed UK-only entity, a bit like 
GE did with Synchrony.
A simpler solution is to deem UK-held shares "restricted" and compel holders to sell to an EU investor. Ryanair's 
articles of association permit this. It is a risk that may get more attention if talks do not result in a better solution, 
such as deeming UK investors equivalent to EU ones. "Thank you for investing in www.Ryanair.Be aware that you 
may be forced to sell your shares at short notice."
Load-Date: February 5, 2018
End of Document

Ryanair expects Brexit worries to hold back fares Airlines ; Budget carrier to add ticket refund clause next year 
in case EU talks fail
Ryanair expects Brexit worries to hold back fares; Airlines ; Budget carrier 
to add ticket refund clause next year in case EU talks fail
Financial Times (London, England)
February 6, 2018 Tuesday
Edition 1, National Edition
Copyright 2018 The Financial Times Limited All Rights Reserved
Section: COMPANIES AND MARKETS;BUSINESS; Pg. 18
Length: 471 words
Byline: NAOMI ROVNICK
Body
Ryanair has warned that airlines operating out of the UK will struggle to raise fares for the summer holiday season 
and into 2019, as uncertainty over how Brexit will affect Britons' travel rights makes them cautious about travelling 
abroad.
"We do not share the optimism of competitors and market commentators for summer 2018 fare rises," Ryanair also 
said alongside quarterly results.
"The lack of clarity on Brexit continues to overhang fares and pricing on routes to [and] from the UK. We would, 
even at this early date, urge extreme caution on investor and analyst assumptions for fares [in 2019]."
This followed an upbeat update from rival easyJet last month, which talked of reduced competitive pressure on 
prices following several airline bankruptcies.
Ryanair's shares closed down 2.4 per cent at (EURO)15.74 yesterday, even though the budget airline announced a 
(EURO)750m share buyback and revealed its revenues and traffic grew, despite flight disruption last autumn due to 
problems with pilot rosters.Net profit increased 12 per cent to (EURO)106m for the three months to December 31, 
compared with the same period last year. Its revenues gained 4 per cent to (EURO)1.4bn and passenger numbers 
were up 6 per cent to 28.8m.
Ryanair expects Brexit worries to hold back fares Airlines ; Budget carrier to add ticket refund clause next year 
in case EU talks fail
Ryanair's outspoken chief executive Michael O'Leary has taken a more negative view of the willingness of British 
customers to travel because the post-Brexit status of the Open Skies agreement, which allows EU airlines to fly 
freely in the bloc, remains unresolved.
Ryanair plans to add a Brexit refund clause to its tickets from summer 2019, the airline said last week, as it warned 
customers their flights may not be valid if aviation regulations were not finalised by then.
"We are going to see increasing press on this and so while Ryanair has been encouraging people to book flights 
with confidence, what they are saying today is that they obviously are going to also price tickets in a way that 
encourages them to fly," said Mark Simpson, an analyst at Goodbody in Dublin. Ryanair has also bowed to 
pressure from its cockpit crew to recognise trade unions across the world. But the company warned yesterday that 
allowing unions to represent its pilots was not the end of the story. "As we finalise union discussions along similar 
lines to that agreed in the UK, we expect some localised disruptions and adverse PR so investors should be 
prepared [for this]."
The airline also told investors to expect rising staff and fuel costs: "In certain jurisdictions, unions representing 
competitor airlines will wish to test our commitment to our low cost, high pay/ high productivity model to disrupt our 
operations. We are fully prepared to face down any such disruption if it means defending our cost base."
See Lex
'As we finalise union discussions, we expect some localised disruption and adverse PR'

February 6, 2018 Tuesday 2:46 AM GMT

covenant.

single-day points decline on record.

Brexit will have on EU flights in a cautious trading update that sent shares in the budget airline down 3%.

model launches on a 25% fall in pre-tax profits.

carmaker and its Chinese joint venture partner planning to invest Rmb60 billion ($9.5 billion) into becoming 
a top-three China brand.

UK and Ireland after it bought the cash-and-carry group for £3.7 billion.

laying off another tranche of workers employed by the failed contractor.

says he is prepared to take legal action if a new mining code in the Democratic Republic of Congo 
becomes law.

complained they found it too confusing.

questioning more members of its top management in connection with the Unaoil scandal.
•

convicted on corruption charges, setting back hopes of reformers that Seoul had turned a corner in taking 
on its powerful chaebol conglomerates.
•
Financial Times: Chinese technology investors in Silicon Valley are being thwarted by the country’s capital 
controls, in a sign of the unintended consequences of Beijing’s move last year to curb cash outflows.

divestments by the company over the past six months.

hospitals and defence sites, is to be taken over by the insurer Fairfax Financial Holdings for an undisclosed 
amount.

Profits climb at Ryanair despite passenger chaos
Profits climb at Ryanair despite passenger chaos
City A.M.
February 6, 2018 Tuesday
Edition 1, National Edition
Copyright 2018 City A.M. All Rights Reserved
Section: NEWS; Pg. 11
Length: 203 words
Byline: JASPER JOLLY
Body
RYANAIR profits rose at the end of 2017 in spite of rostering chaos which saw swathes of flights cancelled in the 
run-up to Christmas.
CEO Michael O'Leary yesterday said the budget carrier had a "cautious" outlook for the final quarter of its financial 
year, although he upgraded his traffic expectations slightly.
Profit after tax rose by 12 per cent to break through the (EURO)100m (£88m) mark during the three months to the 
end of December. Revenues rose by four per cent to (EURO)1.4bn, while passenger numbers rose by six per cent. 
Unit costs fell by one per cent, although costs excluding fuel rose by three per cent in part because of the 
compensation costs from the cancellation of thousands of flights in September. However, the debacle had the 
paradoxical effect of improving punctuality to above 90 per cent. The lack of clarity on Brexit continues to hang over 
the UK operations, said O'Leary, a prominent critic of the decision to leave.
Looking forward, O'Leary urged "extreme caution" on predictions. He said: "While we have practically zero visibility 
on full-year 2019 fares, and our budget is not yet finalised, we do not share the optimism of competitors and market 
commentators for summer 2018 fare rise."
Graphic
 
The carrier cancelled thousands of flights at the end of 2017

Pre-Market Briefing: US Equities Futures Extend Decline Amid Fears of Faster Rate Tightening
Pre-Market Briefing: US Equities Futures Extend Decline Amid Fears of 
Faster Rate Tightening
MT Newswires Live Briefs PRO
February 5, 2018 Monday 4:40 AM EST
Copyright 2018 MT Newswires All Rights Reserved
Length: 394 words
Body
 US equities futures were lower again Monday, adding to the sell-off Friday that saw the Dow plunge 666 points, as 
the fear of faster tightening of economic policy spread to Asian and European markets. The stronger-than-expected 
employment report on Friday showed higher wages, spurring concerns that inflation could push central banks to 
hike rates faster than previously expected. 
- The S&P 500 future was down 0.23% recently, the Dow was down 0.41% and Nasdaq was down 0.09%.
- Crude oil futures were lower with West Texas Intermediate crude oil for delivery in March down 0.6% at $65.08 
and Brent crude for delivery in April down 0.7% at $68.12. 
- In economic data, the Purchasing Managers' Services index is out at 9:45 am ET, followed by the Institute for 
Supply Management's non-manufacturing index at 10 am. 
- Companies reporting earnings Monday morning include Arconic (ARNC), Booz Allen Hamilton (BAH), Bristol-
Myers Squibb (BMY), Catalent (CTLT), Church & Dwight (CHD), Hess Corporation (HES), Mercury General 
Corporation (MCY) and Sysco Corporation (SYY)

February 5, 2018 Monday 11:57 AM EST

Body
 American depository receipts of European stocks were trading 1.24% lower at 143.61 on the Bank of New York 
Mellon Europe ADR Index on Monday.
In continental Europe, the gainers were led by Biotech firm argenx (ARGX), and hotel booking and comparison site 
Trivago (TRVG), which rose 3.7% and 4.1% respectively. They were followed by geophysical equipment maker, 
CGG (CGG), and network infrastructure operator Nokia (NOK), which climbed 2.0% and 1.4%.
The decliners in continental Europe were led by online dating site Spark Networks (LOV), and Oasmia 
Pharmaceutical (OASM), which lost 6.6% and 5.7% respectively. They were followed by telecommunications 
providers Ericsson (ERIC), and Telecom Italia (TI), which fell 3.5% and 2.4%.
In the UK and Ireland, the gainers were led by Trinity Biotech (TRIB), and mining company Rio Tinto (RIO), which 
climbed 2.4% and 1.2% respectively. They were followed by biopharmaceutical company NuCana (NCNA), and 
mining company BHP Billiton (BBL), which rose 0.4% and 0.4%.
The decliners in the UK and Ireland were led by airline operator Ryanair (RYAAY), and biopharmaceutical company

Vodafone Group (VOD), and BT Group (BT), which were off 4.1% and 1.0%.

Ryanair Cautious for Fourth Quarter as CEO Prepared to Face Down Trade Union Disruptions
Ryanair Cautious for Fourth Quarter as CEO Prepared to Face Down Trade 
Union Disruptions
MT Newswires Live Briefs PRO
February 5, 2018 Monday 6:39 AM EST
Copyright 2018 MT Newswires All Rights Reserved
Length: 555 words
Body
 Low cost air carrier Ryanair (RYAAY, RYA.L) reported early Monday a double-digit growth in profit with a 96% load 
factor as it guided to a cautious fiscal fourth quarter, setting the stage for a showdown with trade unions whose 
growing influence across its European operations is threatening the airline's lower cost model via higher staffing 
costs.  
Total operating revenues at Ryanair rose to 1.41 billion euros ($1.76 billion) in the three months to December 31 
from 1.35 billion euros a year ago as traffic grew 6% to 30.4 million, the carrier said in its earnings statement.  
Ryanair, which noted that the European airline consolidation and bankruptcies are providing more growth 
opportunities in the UK, Italy and Germany in particular, reported a 12% jump in profit after tax to 105.6 million 
euros from 94.7 million euros even as average fares fell 4% to 32 euros per customer. 
But, Ryanair's profit could have been higher had it not been for the rostering debacle last year which led to 
thousands of flight cancellations in September and October and, more importantly, forced the carrier to engage with 
trade unions for the first time in 30 years and pushed up staffing costs higher.  
Even though Ryanair reported unit costs were down 1% in the quarter, its ex-fuel costs rose 3% due to higher 
staffing costs, which the company forecasts will rise by an additional 45 million euros in this financial year as the 
budget carrier rolls out pilot pay increases of up to 20% and raises its crew ratios in response to a tightening market 
for experienced pilots.
Ryanair, whose staff costs accounted for 10% of total revenue in the last financial year, has vowed to "not allow our 
industry leading productivity to decline" as it prepares to engage with trade unions across Europe. 
The carrier is still forecasting a 2% decline in unit costs in the current financial year and has maintained its full-year 
guidance in a range of 1.40-1.45 billion euros. It, however, cautioned that this outlook "depends heavily" on the 
absence of union disruptions, unforeseen security events and close-in Easter bookings. As a result, it has tempered 
Ryanair Cautious for Fourth Quarter as CEO Prepared to Face Down Trade Union Disruptions
the outlook for traffic growth to an increase of 8% to 130 million, from 129 million it had forecast earlier. Full-year 
fares are also seen lower by at least 3%.
"In certain jurisdictions, unions representing competitor airlines will wish to test our commitment to our low cost, 
high pay/high productivity model to disrupt our operations," Chief Executive Officer Michael O'Leary said in the 
statement. "We are fully prepared to face down any such disruption if it means defending our cost base or our high 
productivity model."
Stating its "cautious" outlook for the remainder of fiscal 2018, Ryanair said it expects some localized disruptions as 
it finalizes trade union discussions along lines to that agreed in the UK, where it has concluded the first recognition 
agreement with British Airline Pilots Association, underscoring the fact that the UK accounts for more than 25% of 
its total pilot count. The carrier has also held preliminary discussions with pilot unions in Ireland, UK, Spain, 
Germany, Italy, Portugal, Belgium and France over salaries. When this process has completed, Ryanair expects to 
have similar engagement with cabin crew unions.
Price: 120.41, Change: , Percent Change: 
Load-Date: February 6, 2018
End of Document
European Stocks Tumble Amid Global Selloff, Weak UK Service Sector Data
European Stocks Tumble Amid Global Selloff, Weak UK Service Sector Data
MT Newswires Live Briefs PRO
February 5, 2018 Monday 5:21 AM EST
Copyright 2018 MT Newswires All Rights Reserved
Length: 352 words
Body
 European equity benchmarks were sharply lower on Monday morning amid a global stock selloff, mixed earnings 
results and a disappointing set of economic data on the UK's service sector. 
Activity growth softened in Britain's services sector in January amid subdued inflows of new work, according to 
survey data compiled by IHS Markit and the Chartered Institute of Procurement and Supply. January's data pointed 
to a slowdown in growth of services activity across the UK, which stemmed from relatively weak gains in new work. 
Job creation nonetheless picked up as companies retained positive expectations surrounding the outlook. 
Across the globe, Asian equity gauges finished the day mainly lower with the exception of China's Shanghai 
Composite Index, which finished higher, after US stocks ended last week deep in the red.
In equities, Scottish Mutual Investment Trust (SMT.L) was leading the decliners on London's FTSE 100 Index, 
down by 3.3%, followed by Ryanair (RYA.L), down by 3.2% after posting a jump in revenue in its third quarter while 
advising that investors should be prepared for some "localized disruptions" as it finalizes discussions with unions. 
Old Mutual (OML.L), a financial services provider, was 2.7% lower and equipment rental company Ashtead Group 
(AHT.L) was down by 2.5%. Just Eat (JE.L), which operates a food delivery platform, was also 2.5% lower. 
On Frankfurt's DAX, entertainment company ProSiebenSat1 Media (PSM.DE) was 1.9% lower, followed by Henkel 
vz (HEN.DE), a chemical and consumer goods company, down by 1.3% and car-maker Volkswagen (VOW.DE), 
1.2% lower and skincare company Beiersdorf (BEI.DE), down by 1.1%. 
And, on Paris' CAC-40, Airbus (AIR.PA), a manufacturer of aircraft parts, was 2.2% lower, LafargeHolcim 
(LHN.PA), a construction materials company, was down by 1.9% and Bouygues (EN.PA), a diversified industrial 
group, was 1.7% lower. Car-maker Renault (REN.PA) was 1.6% lower. 
The pan-European Stoxx 600 Index was 0.96% lower, London's FTSE 100 Index was down by 1.09%, Frankfurt's 
DAX was 0.46% lower and Paris' CAC-40 was down by 0.78% at the time of writing.
European Stocks Tumble Amid Global Selloff, Weak UK Service Sector Data

European Markets Weaken Further On Inflation Concerns
European Markets Weaken Further On Inflation Concerns
Live Briefs PRO Global Markets
February 5, 2018 Monday 12:08 PM EST
Copyright 2018 MT Newswires All Rights Reserved
Length: 596 words
Body
 The European markets ended the first trading day of the new week firmly in negative territory. The loss extended 
the recent losing streak across the pond to six straight sessions.
Global equity markets were under pressure after Friday's strong US employment report cemented the belief among 
investors that the Federal Reserve will likely hike interest rates again in March. This has raised concerns among 
investors about rising inflation.
Investor sentiment also took a hit after coalition negotiations between German Chancellor Angela Merkel's 
conservative party and the Social Democrats broke down over the weekend.
The pan-European Stoxx Europe 600 index weakened by 1.56%. The Euro Stoxx 50 index of eurozone bluechip 
stocks decreased 1.27%, while the Stoxx Europe 50 index, which includes some major UK companies, lost 1.58%.
The DAX of Germany dropped 0.76% and the CAC 40 of France fell 1.48%. The FTSE 100 of the UK declined 
1.46% and the SMI of Switzerland finished lower by 1.30%.
In Frankfurt, Lufthansa rose 0.71% after it unveiled plans to replace top management at Brussels Airlines.
In Paris, global consulting and IT service firm Capgemini lost 1.95% after announcing the acquisition of LiquidHub.
In London, Ryanair dropped 1.89% as the budget carrier warned of some localized disruptions and adverse PR in 
the months ahead.
Randgold Resources sank 7.38% after its fourth quarter profit fell from a year ago.
Lloyds Banking Group PLC slid 0.99% after it reportedly banned credit card customers from buying Bitcoin.
Engineering group Sandvik finished lower by 1.90% in Stockholm after its fourth-quarter core profit topped 
forecasts.
European Markets Weaken Further On Inflation Concerns
Leonardo tumbled 4.56% in Milan after UBS downgraded its rating on the stock to "Neutral" from "Buy."
The euro area economy expanded at the fastest pace since mid-2006 in January, final data from IHS Markit 
showed Monday. The final composite output index rose more than initially estimated to 58.8 in January from 58.1 in 
December. The flash score was 58.6.
Eurozone investor confidence weakened in February, survey data from think tank Sentix showed Monday. The 
investor sentiment index fell unexpectedly to 31.9 from 32.9 in January. The score was forecast to rise to 34.5.
Eurozone retail sales declined in December after recovering a month ago, Eurostat reported Monday. The volume 
of retail trade dropped 1.1% month-on-month in December, in contrast to the 2% rise posted in November. Sales 
were forecast to drop 1%.
British service sector activity expanded at a slower pace in January, largely reflecting weak gains in new work as 
Brexit remains the main course of concern, survey data from IHS Markit showed Monday.
The IHS Markit/Chartered Institute of Procurement & Supply Purchasing Managers' Index, dropped more-than-
expected to 53.0 in January from 54.2 in December. The expected reading was 54.0.
China's private sector activity expanded at the fastest pace in seven years in January driven by accelerated rates of 
activity growth across both manufacturing and services. 
The Caixin composite Purchasing Managers' Index rose to 53.7 in January from 53.0 in December, data from IHS 
Markit showed Monday.
The US ISM services index hit its highest level since mid-2005, a sign of further strength in the nation's economy. 
Economic activity in the non-manufacturing sector grew in January for the 96th consecutive month, according to a 
survey of purchasing managers.
The ISM's NMI index registered 59.9%, which is 3.9 percentage points higher than the seasonally adjusted 
December reading of 56%. Economists had expected a reading of 56.2.

 European stocks fell for a sixth day running on Monday as investors fretted about higher interest rates and coalition 
negotiations between German Chancellor Angela Merkel's conservative party and the Social Democrats broke 
down over the weekend.
French President Emmanuel Macron's party lost two by-elections for parliamentary seats on Sunday and the dollar 
paused after recovering somewhat on Friday on the back of robust US employment data, further weighing on 
markets.
The pan-European Stoxx 600 was down nearly 1% at 384.14 in late opening deals after falling 1.4% on Friday amid 
across the board selling.
The German DAX was declining half a percent and France's CAC 40 index was losing 0.9%, while the UK's FTSE 
100 was down more than 1% ahead of a crucial week for negotiations between Britain and the EU on their future 
relationship.
Ryanair tumbled 3.5% as the budget carrier warned of some localized disruptions and adverse PR in the months 
ahead.

prices.
Global consulting and IT service firm Capgemini lost 1.6% in Paris after announcing the acquisition of LiquidHub.

Swedish engineering group Sandvik was little changed after its fourth-quarter core profit topped forecasts.
Deutsche Bank recovered from an early loss to trade about 0.4% higher.
European Shares Extend Losses As Global Selloff Spreads

flash score was 58.6.

December after recovering a month ago, separate reports showed.
Elsewhere, British service sector activity expanded at the slowest pace in nearly one-and-a-half years in January, 
survey data from IHS Markit showed.

TOP NEWS SUMMARY: UK Service Sector Growth Weakest In 16 Months
TOP NEWS SUMMARY: UK Service Sector Growth Weakest In 16 Months
Live Briefs PRO Global Markets
February 5, 2018 Monday 6:18 AM EST
Copyright 2018 MT Newswires All Rights Reserved
